Forms of Literature [ENG-1001] [ENG-1001-1]

Faculty Name
Jonathan Gil Harris [jgharris@ashoka.edu.in] ,Shinjini Dey [shinjini.dey_phd24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course is the gateway course to the English major and minor at Ashoka University.  It introduces English students to literary history as articulated through different genres: the epic, the tale, the novel, the lyric, the drama, and the short story.  Rather than regarding literary forms as fixed categories with specific rules, we will instead examine them as dynamically shaped by, and in conversation with, their social and historical contexts.  We will consider how these forms have meant different things at different times, both to understand the transformations of literature and the changing meanings of genre itself.  We will look at epic and how its world view has transformed from Gilgamesh to John Milton’s Paradise Lost; tales and how their preoccupations have changed from Geoffrey Chaucer’s Canterbury Tales and Kalyana Malla’s Suleiman Charitra to T.S. Eliot’s Waste Land; novels and how their social function and meaning vary from Joseph Conrad’s Heart of Darkness to Amruta Patil’s Kari; lyric poetry and how its modes of intimacy have transformed from Sappho’s fragments, Amir Khusro’s ghazals, and William Shakespeare’s Sonnets to Audre Lorde’s poetry; drama and how its representation of gender has morphed from Kalidasa’s Shakuntala to Caryl Churchill’s Top Girls; and short stories and how their uncanny imaginative scope has been reconfigured from E. T. A. Hoffman to Saadat Hasan Manto and Ismat Chughtai.  We will also read some theories of literature and literary transformation, including essays by Karl Marx, Mikhail Bakhtin, T. S. Eliot, Bertolt Brecht, and Sigmund Freud.

Forms of Literature [ENG-1001] [ENG-1001-2]

Faculty Name
Mandakini Dubey [mandakini.dubey@ashoka.edu.in] ,Amrutha Nathan [amrutha.nathan_asp25@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Forms of Literature is the first ‘gateway’ course into the English major/minor at Ashoka—a gateway we enter to consider, together, some significant literary modes as they have emerged historically. We will be reading and discussing epic, tragedy (and drama more broadly), lyric poetry, the short story and the novel. Our focus on the making of these genres will allow us some freedom in the worlds we roam—from the classical to the contemporary, traversing many parts of the globe through different literary cultures.

In thinking through form historically, we will begin by assuming that literary genres articulate the material foundations we recognize in their social and historical contexts. We will trace how the evolution and sedimentation of these forms reflects the conditions of their making. Along the way, we’ll think about the many ways in which human beings have considered their place in the world, about what it means to be, live, love, act, work, desire, write and create—questions that seem to reach out from the particular places and times in which they are asked, even as they tell us all the more about how those places and times were inhabited and imagined. 

Our readings will include epic texts like The Odyssey and Paradise Lost; drama that includes both Sophocles’ Antigone and Bertolt Brecht’s Mother Courage and Her Children; works by Chaucer and T. S. Eliot, poetry from down the ages and across the globe, including Sappho and Du Fu, Shakespeare and Kabir, Langston Hughes and Meena Kandasamy; and fictional writing that includes story cycles from earlier eras, some of the great short stories of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, and a novella. We will also be reading supplementary theoretical works by Karl Marx, Mikhail Bakhtin, T. S. Eliot, and Bertolt Brecht.

Overview

This course takes an intellectual history approach to the study of Indian civilizations. It considers civilization as an actor category. It explores how different conceptualizations of civilization have shaped India, and how India has shaped the concept of civilization. We will focus mainly but not exclusively on British/Western colonialists and thinkers on one hand and South Asian intellectuals on the other to embark on a journey that will begin from the middle of the eighteenth century and go right up to the present. The course will give students a fresh perspective on and a critical re-introduction to Indian history, how historical knowledge (including the kind of history that is taught in schools) is produced, and the many consequences of such knowledge in the making of our past, present, and future.

 

The following themes will be covered in the course (Note: this is subject to change on the instructors' discretion).

10. Colonial Construction of Indian Civilization and Culture II

Week 6:

11 Civilization and Culture of the colonized I

12. Civilization and Culture of the colonized II

Week 7:

14. The Many meaning of Hindustan II

Week 9:

Week 12:

Week 13:

26. Recap

 

 

 

 

 

 

Learning Outcomes

— You will understand the history of the concept of "civilization."

— You will learn what is at stake in deploying the concept of "civilization" for making sense of the past and present.

— You will learn how the elements that most people constitute Indian civilization with have been assembled and how it has changed over time.

— You will gain a fresh understanding of the history of India and more broadly, of history as a discipline.

Indian Civilisations [FC-0201] [FC-0201-2]

Faculty Name
Indivar Kamtekar [indivar.kamtekar@ashoka.edu.in] ,Esther Larisa David [esther.david_tf@ashoka.edu.in] ,Yaruipam Muivah [yaruipam.muivah_tf@ashoka.edu.in] ,Susan Philip [susan.philip_asp25@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What is ‘Indian civilization’ and when was it formed? Did it get created in classical antiquity? Or was it a product of the colonial encounter? Discussions about Indian civilization are usually attentive to antiquity, or to what has been labelled as a ‘composite culture’ fostered by the advent of Islam in medieval times. This course will suggest that the term ‘composite culture’ is perhaps more appropriate to describe the modern Indian living conditions, habits and identities which burgeoned during British rule, and have flourished thereafter. It addresses the making of modern Indian civilization, not so much by looking at a distant past, but by examining developments in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. We shall discuss politics and economics, but also – among other topics – food and dress, technology and health, the adoption of new technologies, and new items of mass consumption. To a greater extent than many people wish to admit, we are constituted by colonialism. Even the drinking of tea and coffee, so much a part of our culture now, dates to our relatively recent past, and provides a fascinating history to explore.

Indian Civilisations [FC-0201] [FC-0201-3]

Faculty Name
Nayanjot Kaur Lahiri [nayanjot.lahiri@ashoka.edu.in] ,Aritra Ghosh [aritra.ghosh_tf@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This is a small course about a large and fascinating subject, that of Indian Civilizations. It has been structured in a way that it can be immersed in, we hope, with enjoyment.  The course will draw out civilizational elements from prehistory till the present – through travels and lives, through ideas and art forms – in which small phenomena will be linked to the larger world of the Indian subcontinent and beyond. In the process, the course will explore a varied and rich tapestry that includes rock art, the Harappan Civilization, the Mahabharata’s many stories, the iconic emperors Ashoka and Akbar,  and the words of the Buddha and the   Bhakti saints. Indian civilization, as the course will emphasize, is not to be seen merely as part of the dead past but as an element that continued to be invoked in present times, by literary giants like Rabindranath Tagore and statesmen like Jawaharlal Nehru, and by more ordinary people in India’s villages and towns. Readings will be electronically shared with  students.

Faculty Name
Bittu R [bittu@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sushmita Anant [sushmita.anant_tf@ashoka.edu.in] ,Arshia Mittal [arshia.mittal_ug25@ashoka.edu.in] ,Eshani Arora [eshani.arora_ug25@ashoka.edu.in] ,Krishna Dipesh Dalal [krishna.dalal_ug25@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course will introduce you to questions of mind and behaviour and their relationship to the brain and body, and will encourage you to think critically and scientifically through your own ideas around these relationships. In this course we will try to understand ourselves, the people and animals around us, and all the ways in which our interactions produce learning. Every conversation, every memory, even your reading of this course outline, structurally and functionally changes your brain, but not everything that the brain processes seems to make it to the realm of conscious perception. We will think about various seemingly intangible aspects of the mind and try to imagine how to make sense of them. The goal of the course is to provide you with the tools with which to ask these questions and begin answering them.

 

We will take a look at complex and interesting phenomena such as motivation, emotion, language, consciousness and attention. We will explore the specific question of how we learn, how we absorb and retain new material, the ways in which our brains tend to conflate correlation and causation, how we make decisions, and what critical thinking means. We will think through inter individual behavioural differences and what kinds of evidence we require to draw conclusions about group behaviour. We will focus on the limitations of what we collectively understand and the ways in which we might imagine advancing our collective knowledge about the mind and behaviour.

Faculty Name
Arpan Banerjee . [arpan.banerjee@ashoka.edu.in] ,Bhismadev Chakrabarti [bhismadev.chakrabarti@ashoka.edu.in] ,Rohit Singh [rohit.singh_tf@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The purpose of this course is to ask critical questions on mind and behaviour and their relationship to the brain and body. We will quickly review the philosophical theories of mind and behaviour, specifically the dominant views that have guided empirical studies. Subsequently we will review the different methods for studying mind and behaviour in empirical setting. With the help of basic research methodological tools, we would explore how perception, action, attention, memory and consciousness can be understood from the operational principles and complex mechanisms in relevant brain areas. In the second part of the course we will explore building blocks of social behaviour, such as - emotion, empathy, and social cognition and individual differences therein.

Symbolic Logic [PHI-1060] [PHI-1060-1]

Faculty Name
Alexander Iain Siantonas [alexander.siantonas@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Instructor: Dr Alec Siantonas, alexander.siantonas@ashoka.edu.in

 

I: Course Overview. This is an introduction to logic as a resource for philosophy, though it should benefit many who do not mean to make philosophy their primary subject of study. Logic is concerned with truth; in learning it, we learn to evaluate how well our thoughts and arguments are tied to truth. We will study several artificial formal languages, especially first-order propositional and predicate logic, as well as modal ogic. We will think about their relation to the natural language of English, and to the world, as it is independent of all our speech. 

 

II: Learning Objectives. 

 

By the end of this course, you will be able to:

Understand the fundamental ideas of logic.

Translate sentences of English into well-formed sentences of logical languages, and vice versa. 

Determine the formal properties of arguments, such as validity and soundness,  as they are used in philosophical writing and elsewhere. 

Construct formal proofs for sentences of our formal languages. 

Recognise some of the philosophical implications and applications of logic. 

 

III: What to Expect. This is a demanding course, covering a good deal of challenging technical ground. It is still an introductory course, intended primarily to prepare philosophers for work across that subject. It is not an advanced course, exploring the field of logic for its own sake, in the manner of an advanced metaphysics course. But as an introductory logic course, it is more advanced than most (including, for instance, the logic course offered by the excellent department at Leeds, in Britain’s prestigious Russell Group). Some of the topics covered towards the end are at the edge of active research. You will have to work hard, and you may well feel yourself struggling at times. If you are prepared to put in the work, and square up to the struggle, you will learn a lot, and be equipped both to follow and create philosophical arguments at the highest level. 

 

IV: Resources. The main texts we will be working from are Volker Halbach’s The Logic Manual and Ted Sider’s Logic for Philosophy, as well as my Modal Logic Manual. There are also plenty of free online resources you may draw upon for the earlier sections of the course, too. See eg the materials developed by Tim Button, as well as Garson’s Modal Logic for Philosophers.

 

V: Plan. 

 

Week 1 & 2: What is logic, and what do we want from it?

See Logic Manual 1

 

Week 3: Syntax and semantics of propositional  logic

See Logic Manuel 2

 

Week 4: Formalization in propositional logic

See Logic Manual 3

 

Week 5: Syntax of predicate logic

See Logic Manual 4

 

Week 6: Semantics of predicate logic

See Logic Manual 5

 

Week 7: Natural deduction

See Logic Manual 6

 

Week 8: Formalization and Identity

See Logic Manual 7 & 8

 

Week 9: Review and Exam

 

Week 9: Introduction to Modal Propositional Logic

See Modal Logic Manual 1 and 2

 

Week 10: Semantic Proof for Modal Logic 

See Logic for Philosophers 9

 

Week 11: Natural Deduction for Modal Logic


 

Week 12: Review

We we will have periodic homework assignments, as well as two exams, one around the middle and one at the end of the course. Marks can also be gained by good participation (repeated attendance of office hours, going beyond given assignments, etc)

Natania Narang [natania.narang_ug22@ashoka.edu.in] ,Supriya Ray [supriya.ray@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sushmit Gupta [sushmit.gupta_ug25@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Course Overview

"The business of the statistician is to catalyze the scientific learning process." ― George E. P. Box

"Without data, you’re just another person with an opinion" ― W. Edwards Deming

“I couldn't claim that I was smarter than sixty-five other guys--but the average of sixty-five other guys, certainly!”― Richard P. Feynman [In 'Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman: Adventures of a Curious Character']

 

In this course, you will learn how to use statistical tools (central tendency, variability, probability, hypothesis testing (e.g., t-tests, ANOVAs), regression, etc.) to answer questions of psychological interest. The emphasis will be given on understanding statistical concepts and performing basic statistical analyses, not on mathematical formulas and derivations. Many students, for whom the world of numerals and symbols has been a ‘no-go’ area, begin their statistics course with a fear of doing mathematics. However, statistics is not about (re-)learning summation; instead, statistics summarizes the data in a comprehensive manner.
 

COURSE STRUCTURE

Lecture Sessions are scheduled on _______ and __________,  in addition Dr. Ray will hold office on __________ every week. The aim will be to give a foundation on the topics listed below. Reading the corresponding topic before attending the lecture is expected, but not mandatory, for better understanding and interaction. Lectures are designed to supplement the assigned readings.

WEEK                                                                    TOPIC

1.                                 Scientific Approach to psychological research, Experiment design in psychology

2.                                 Introduction to frequentist statistics (conceptual primer)

3.                                Types of Data, Types of Statistical Analysis

4.                                Describing data using frequency distributions, graphs

5.                                Measures of Central Tendency, Measures of Spread, Skewness, Kurtosis

6.                                Introduction to Probability, Probability Distributions, z-statistics, Point estimation, Confidence interval

7.                                Introduction to Testing of Hypothesis, Finding outliers, Testing for difference between samples

8.                                Normality and significance testing

9.                                Analysis of variance (ANOVA), F-Ratio statistics, A priori and post-hoc comparison

10.                             Non-parametric tests of hypothesis

11.                              Correlation, Regression, Goodness of Fit

12.                              Effect size, Statistical Power, Sample size

Learning Outcomes

This course is primarily designed for undergraduate students. By the end of this course you
will be able to

  • Understand basic theoretical and applied principles of statistics.
  • Gain proficiency in using statistical software for data analysis.
  • Appreciate why data triumphs anecdotes.
  • Understand basic theoretical and applied principles of statistics.
  • Interpret complex statistical findings.
  • Communicate quantitative data in statistics, graphs, and tables

"Research Methods and Statistics in Psychology" by Hugh Coolican  (Hodder Education, Taylor & Francis)

Cognitive Psychology [PSY-2021] [PSY-2021-1]

Faculty Name
Dipanjan Ray Ray [dipanjan.ray@ashoka.edu.in] ,Deeksha Rai Rathore [deeksha.rathore_tf@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course is currently undergoing design and modification. Please check this location frequently for updates and changes.

Cognitive psychology is the study of how we think, and how we make sense of the external (and internal) environment using our prior experiences, and determine how to respond to an ever changing environment. While the main purpose of this course is to introduce you to the scientific study of the mind, you will also begin to understand the central role cognition plays in our everyday lives. 

Learning Outcomes

Upon completing this course, students should be able to:
• Trace the history of cognitive psychology and its influence on other fields of psychology.
• Critically compare and contrast different theories of cognitive function.
• Demonstrate knowledge of the basic methods of cognitive research, plus their strengths and weaknesses.
• Apply communication skills using oral and written materials to discuss topics related to human cognition or to critically review a paper.
• Explain how theories and research findings from cognitive psychology can inform everyday problems

Recommended Text

Overview

 Social psychology is the branch of psychological science that examines how an individual's thoughts, emotions and behaviours are shaped by social norms and the larger social context. We will explore how the presence of others shapes and influences our motivations, cognition, attitudes, emotions and behaviours, by looking at group processes involved in cooperation, conflict and competition. 

Learning Outcomes

Understanding major theories, concepts, empirical findings and debates in social psychology. 

Familiarity with methods within social psychological research.

Critically engaging with social psychological findings and exploring how they apply to our cultural contexts. 

To understand the intersections between ‘social’ and ‘individual’ and the multi-layered problems that social psychologists examine. 

Development of interest in exploring social psychological questions of enquiry among students.

Overview

Course Code: ECO-2400

Course description

By the end of the semester, the students are expected to be at ease with basic econometric techniques such as setting up a model, testing assumptions and have a critical view on econometric results. Computer classes introduce the student to real life problems and help to understand the theoretical content of the lectures. The course reviews the linear model, ordinary least square regression, hypothesis testing, heteroskedasticity and endogeneity.

Course objectives

To understand classical linear model assumptions, it’s violations, and solutions.

To estimate linear regression models and test its violation using STATA software.

Topics

1. The Simple Regression Model

2. Multiple Regression Analysis: Estimation

3. Multiple Regression Analysis: Inference

4. Multiple regression analysis: Further issues

5. Heteroskedasticity, Autocorrelation, Multicollinearity.

6. More on specification and data problems

7. Multiple regression analysis with qualitative information: Dummy variables

8. Limited dependent variable models.

9. Introduction to OLS using Matrix Algebra

Learning Outcomes

Learning outcomes

After completing this course, students will be able to

1. Identify modelling problems relating to continuous endogenous variables

2. To solve problems relating to continuous endogenous variables through empirical analysis

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Mandatory reading

Wooldridge, J.M. (2007): Introductory Econometrics: A Modern Approach, Fourth Edition, Thomson South- Western.

Econometrics [ECO-2400] [ECO-2400-5]

Faculty Name
Pragya Jain [pragya.jain@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This will be an introductory course in econometrics. It will build on the concepts of statistical inference with the aim to apply them to data and enable understanding of economic relationships. The course will have both a theoretical and an application-based part. The theory will involve understanding the method of least squares estimation.

Learning Outcomes

The crux of econometrics is to be able to test hypothesis about a population using a sample. We begin by building on our understanding of a population and a sample and the basics of hypothesis testing. The course then moves onto the methods of estimation to understand causal relationships between variables. These methods are not just restricted to economics but are also relevant to the study of political science, sociology and public policy in general. The emphasis will be on inferring causality throughout the course. By the end of this course you should be able to understand and apply the taught econometric methods to test a relevant hypothesis of interest using data, interpret the results and draw appropriate conclusions.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Prerequisites:

• Statistics; Hard Work

• Calculus and algebra will be used in the theory.

Required Course Material:

• Jeffrey M. Wooldridge [JMW], Introductory Econometrics: A Modern Approach, 4th or 5th edition.

• Cameron, A.C. and Trivedi, P.K [CT]. Microeconometrics using Stata, 2nd ed., Stata Press, 2010

• Mastering Metrics, Joshua Angrist (Optional)

Grading Rubric

Student grades have four components: final exam (50% weightage), first mid-term (15% weightage), second mid-term exam (15% weightage), and the total score in all problem sets combined (20% weightage). The syllabus for the first and second mid-term exams will be announced in class and on AMS.

Attendance Policy

1. If you miss 8 classes or less than that, you will be awarded an extra credit of 2%. If you miss either 9 or 10 classes, you will be given 1% extra credit. If you miss more than 10, you will not be given any advantage. Attendance will not be used as an eligibility to sit for exams and will not count towards any assessment but is highly encouraged. Attendance during mid-term exams and final exams is compulsory, no exam will be re-taken.

2. Attending a class means sitting in the classroom for the full 90 minutes. Repeated entry and exit from the class will not be allowed. This means that once you exit the class before the class ends, you will not be allowed to re-enter and will be marked absent.

Overview

In this survey course we will read a selection of texts written by British poets, novelists, painters and philosophers from the late 17th to the 19th century in order to examine how they participated in the creation and construction of Empire. We will read texts ranging from Aphra Behn’s Oronooko and Alexander Pope’s The Rape of the Lock to William Wordsworth’s Lyrical Ballads and Adam Smith’s Wealth of Nations, Mary Shelley’s Frankenstein, Emily Bronte’s Wuthering Heights, the Sherlock Holmes novels as well as a few colonial subjects who write back to Empire (mostly from the Urdu literary tradition) such as Sir Syed Ahmed Khan.

Overview

In this course, we’ll read a range of texts written both by the British and by colonised subjects between the 17th and 20th centuries. We’ll examine the written word’s role in Empire’s formation and functioning. We’ll consider the many ways to approach these texts today and understand their afterlives that shape our current world. We’ll read early novels such as Oroonoko, and Robinson Crusoe, Equiano’s slave narrative, key archival documents, Romantic poetry, and popular illustrations of racialized subjects. Overview

Field theory/Galois theory can be considered as one of the fundamental courses considered as 

learning outcomes in undergraduate mathematics (Others being Complex Analysis, Fourier theory with applications

to basic PDE, some bit of number theory).  

 

The classical problems which the Greeks raised but

could not solve are the following: using ruler and compass constructions,

can one trisect any angle? can the cube of unit length be doubled and finally

can the circle be squared. To this, we can add the problems of explicitly solving higher

degree polynomial equations in one variable, just as it can be done for the quadratic

equation; or which regular n-gons can be constructed?

 

The solutions to this questions come from a study of

polynomial equations, what is known as field theory.

The answer given by Galois (Gauss, Abel and others) is to consider

the symmetries of the roots of a polynomial equation, bringing in

group theory and linear algebra.

 

If time permits, we may cover further topics oriented towards number theory or

geometry.

Learning Outcomes

Galois theory

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

1. Ian Herstein, Algebra (Section on Field theory). 

2. Dummit and Foote, Algebra

3. Jacobson, Basic Algebra

It is very important to solve exercises and learn the basic examples. 

It is also advisable that before the semester begins, to read a bit about 

the course from the book by Dummit and Foote (Field theory/Galois theory). 

Grading Rubric

40percent quizzes; at least one mid term and one end semester exam. 

These will make up for the rest 60percent.

Attendance Policy

Highly desirable. Lagging behind by more than a lecture will mean 

that you will not be able to follow the course. So keep up (in fact, 

try to read a bit about the topics in advance  before coming for the 

lectures).

Faculty Name

Overview

Movement, text, sound, music- these are some of the areas touched upon while developing skills in performance.  The emphasis is on building a vocabulary of performance techniques. These techniques can include breathing, movement improvisation, and voice modulation, as well as exercises in awareness and musicality. These ‘tools of performance’ are often tempered by a plethora of contemporary performance outlooks. The emphasis in this most preliminary of Ashoka’s performing arts courses is on the individual as a performing entity. The consciousness of one’s own self vis-à-vis performative potentialities lays the foundations for the group work so essential to later performing arts courses.  The course work will proceed in a series of ‘etudes’ or studies which will result in small performance ‘moments’ or phrases. Some of the coursework will be based on texts and scripts to be chosen afresh each semester.  Other coursework can be based on non-textual concepts.

No previous experience is required. This course is a presumed prerequisite for higher-level performing arts courses.

This course is mandatory for all students wanting to pursue a minor in performing arts.

Overview

Developmental Psychology is a systematic approach to study the biopsychosocial dimensions of human development across the lifespan. The course will cover fundamental theories relative to cognitive development, moral development, language development, identity formation etc from the period of the prenatal period to death. During the course, students will engage in key theoretical concepts in human development and their cultural application, critique the idea of normative development and develop a grounded sensibility towards development oriented concerns and challenges. The course will follow a critically reflexive pedagogy, urging students to consistently question developmental givens, introspect on their development and hence develop a nuanced understanding of technical concepts. Pedagogical tools will include a combination of play, reflexive exercises, art work and film clippings. The course intends to  ask the following questions: How do nature and nurture together shape development? How do children shape their own development? In what ways is development continuous, and in what ways is it discontinuous? How does the socio-cultural context influence development? What are the ethical research practices when studying developmental patterns?

Learning Outcomes
  • Develop a thorough understanding of major development theories.
  • Develop a critical approach to linear models of human development.
  • Relate key concepts of the scientific method to research in child development.
  • Identify and illustrate how biological, cognitive and social-emotional processes interact to influence human development.

Overview

Quantitative psychological data is frequently a bunch of structured numbers. These cannot be interpreted meaningfully until one understands and appreciates how the data came about and what can be properly inferred from the data. In this course, we will focus on quantitative methodology. This course is for students who know the basics of statistical analyses. The aim is to develop a trained eye for sound methodology to better evaluate other scientists’ research, as well as their own. Students will also learn about planning, ethical conduct, and reporting of findings from a survey and experimental study. Along with some of the most widely-used quantitative methods in psychology (e.g., surveys and experiments), students will also understand how these methods are different from alternative methodologies (i.e., qualitative methods, mixed methods).

 

Learning Outcomes

By the end of this course, you will be able to:

  • Understand various quantitative methods that psychologists use to investigate research questions.
  • Plan, design, and conduct a psychometrically-sound survey; formulate hypotheses, test them, analyze the results, interpret them
  • Write report of a survey study to effectively communicate your results
  • Plan, design, and conduct an experimental study; formulate hypotheses, design and conduct an experiment to test the hypotheses, analyze the results, interpret them
  • Write report of an experimental study to effectively communicate your results
  • Understand alternative methodologies available for researchers (qualitative and mixed-method) and when to use them
  • Grasp, analyze, and critique academics research papers in psychology
  • Become literate consumers of scientific information.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Prerequisites: Pass in Statistics and Research Methodology I, or equivalent modules in math, economics, or political science.

Shaughnessy J. J., Zechmeister, E. B., Zechmeister, J. S., & (2012). Essentials of research methods in psychology. (9th ed.) Tata McGraw-Hill.

Additional excused absences are  possible only if the past five absences have been due to health reasons and have proper  documentation.

Overview

This course focuses on understanding the phenomenology (description), etiology (causes), and treatment of abnormal behavior. Major psychological syndromes will be discussed along with the current APA classification system (DSM-5) and other classification systems. Genetic, biological, social, and psychological parameters implicated in the etiology of these syndromes will be introduced. Students will learn the principles of clinical assessment and the 5P model of psychological assessment and case formulation. 

Prerequisites: SRM1 +  Either Introduction to Psychology /TLAP 

Learning Outcomes
  • Understand the merits and limitations of research methods and assessment techniques for clinical psychology
  • Learn basics of critical and analytical skills required to read a journal article on clinical psychology
  • Understand and be able to describe the current APA classification system (DSM-5) and show appreciation for other classification systems internationally
  • Understand and be able to describe the major psychological disorders
  • Describe the genetic, biological, social, and psychological influences on these disorders
  • Understand the influence of societal, cultural, historical, and environmental influences on these disorders
  • Appreciate the concept of comorbidity
  • Discuss mental health services historically, and in today’s India, and appreciate cross-cultural differences
  • Understand ethical issues involved with mental health services
  • Learn the importance of vocabulary, empathy and nuances in abnormal behavior
  • Be able to navigate and think through elementary clinical problems in practice
  • Learn to write an interview questionnaire based on a clinical case study

Faculty Name
Pritam Ghosh [pritam.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course will serve as an introduction to the theory of differential geometry. Topics which will be covered include:

Topic 1) (1 week) Review of some basic concepts. 

Topic 2) (3 weeks) Theory of curves - Smooth curves, tangents, curvature, torsion, planar curves, Frennet frame.

Topic 3) (5 weeks) Theory of surfaces - Manifold structure, First and second fundamental forms, Curvatures, Gauss' excellent theorem, Parallel transport and geodesics.

Topic 4) (4 weeks)  Integration on manifolds,  Gauss-Bonnet and other miscelleneous topics. 

Approximately one assignment every alternate week, roughly 12 - 15 problems in every set. Revise your Multivariable Calculus (especially the differentiation part) and Linear Algebra thoroughly before the semester begins.

Learning Outcomes

This is your first foray into studying geometry formally. After this course, you will be able to undertand and visualise many concepts you have learned in Linear algebra and multivariate calculus and also under the geometric structure of many everyday penomenon around us. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Revise your Linear ALgebra (vector spaces, basis, dimension, isomorphisms, rank-nullity, eigenvalues and vectors, inner product, orthogonality, orthonormal basis, orthogonal and symmetric matrices and their properties), Multivariate calculus (continuity, differentiation, partial derivaties, chain rule, implicit functions, jacobian, line integrals, surface integrals) and real analysis thoroughly. This course requires solid foundation in all three courses. 

Grading Rubric

Quiz: 20 %, Midsem 1 : 25  % , Midsem 2: 25 % , Final 30 %

All exams are in-person. No take home or online exams. There may be viva components as part of the second midsem and/or the final exam. 

"A" grade is absolute - 90 or higher scores. Below 30 is "F".  The rest of the grades are scaled by median score. 

There will be no makeup quizzes under any circumstances. You will get a 0 if you miss any. Best 5 of 7 quizzes will be counted. In case you miss a midsem due to exceptional circumstances and provide proper documentation - the weight will be shifted to the other exams. No makeup exam is provided. If not informed (with documentation) at least 48 hours before the exam, your score will be recorded as 0. 

 

 

 

In order to pass the course you must score at least 30% in the final exam AND any two of the other three evaluation components. Unable to do so will result in an "F" grade. 

Attendance Policy

Not compulsory but strongly encouraged. Students who do not attend classes usually perform poorly. And I do not give any "extra-credit" assignments etc.

Overview

There are several problems in diverse areas like physics, engineering and economics, where a quantity (eg the temperature at a place or the price of some goods) depends on several variables. In this course we devlop the calculus of  such functions. We will mainly study differential calculus of real functions of several real variables, and then go on to integrals. We will learn how to solve problems of maxima and minima.

The course will also help us revise and understand better what we learnt in the first Calculus course.

 

Learning Outcomes

Facility with calculus of several variables. Better understanding of the general ideas of mathematical analysis. Developing abilities to solve problems, to understand rigorous proofs and to write clear proofs.

2 Also recommended, S. Lang, Calculus of Several Variables.

A combination of class quizzes, a midterm exam and  a final exam. The exact weight of each will be discussed early in the course.  

Attendance Policy

Regular attendance is essential and is encouraged. Coming late to class is not allowed.

It is essential that students put in 6-8 hours of work per week at home. This should be done right from the beginning of the course.

Faculty Name
Advaita Rajendra [advaita.rajendra@ashoka.edu.in] ,Ekanto Ghosh [ekanto.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sagar Singhal [sagar.singhal@ashoka.edu.in] ,Anshika Bhatnagar [anshika.bhatnagar_asp25@ashoka.edu.in] ,Tia Garg [tia.garg_asp25@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course aims to support students to create and build organisations that are
ecologically sensitive and socially relevant. In the changing context of the urgent
need to handle climate change, environmental degradation, and increasing social
inequality, the course walks students through opportunities and challenges for
organisations.
The course will draw on cases from a wide variety of settings varying from large
organisations like Patagonia to smaller startups like Skrap and lessons from the
margins -- newspaper vendors, street vendors, traditional arts and crafts -- lessons of
management from the unexplored sector of the informal. Through critical readings,
analysis of videos, and case discussions, participants will engage with the social and
environmental challenges the society is facing.
During field visits, through deeper engagements with organizations and collectives
that have been developing a path of environmentally and socially conscious journeys,
participants will set foot on such paths, by developing the possibilities and potentials
to create more of such paths, not only at a larger scale of building new organizations
but also by incorporating and integrating versatile and pluralistic values and logics of
environmentally and socially conscious decision making.
In-class discussions will be largely based on the cases and readings assigned to the
sessions. This will create a space to learn ways in which collectives and organizations

Quantitative Reasoning and Mathematical Thinking [FC-0306] [FC-0306-2]

Faculty Name
Sagar Shrivastava [sagar.shrivastava@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Observe the environment surrounding you; it is filled with technology that employs numbers and codes to perform remarkable tasks. This enables activities such as online shopping, sending delightful emojis to friends, or even reading this very text. All of this is made possible through extraordinary engineering, which is grounded in fundamental physical laws that we can represent mathematically, allowing us to make informed predictions. This is one of the many places where a mathematical model allows us to make predictions that can be employed for other uses.

 

In this course, we will explore various methods of utilizing mathematics to model problems and apply these models to generate predictions that can significantly impact our daily lives. We will go over the enderlying mathematics that would be required to come up with such models.

 

The emphasis of the course will be on the conceptual framework and methodology rather than on computational techniques. Throughout the course, we will introduce several tools designed to facilitate calculations and enhance visualization.

 

Throughout the course, we’ll pass through the following topics:

  • How much change do I have to give at the supermarket? 

  • What is the language of mathematics?

  • Am I going on a straight line or in a circle?

  • Are numbers really Real?

  • How to survive barter system

  • How many leaves does a tree have?

  • What are the chances of winning in a game of poker?

  • How do I do my taxes?

  • This statement is a lie!

 

 

 

 

 

Learning Outcomes

It is expected that students would understand the words underlying "QRMT - Quantitative Reasoning and Mathematical Thinking" both separately and together as well. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

This course does not require any prior knowledge; all that is needed is a willingness to engage with mathematics and reasoning, as well as the determination to conquer any apprehensions related to the subject. I will supply resources as we advance through the lectures, although there is no specific textbook mandated. Various books will be referenced during the course, and some will be designated for reading assignments.

Grading Rubric

Quantitative Reasoning and Mathematical Thinking [FC-0306] [FC-0306-3]

Faculty Name
Gautam Iqbal Menon [gautam.menon@ashoka.edu.in] ,Manpreet Singh [manpreet.singh_tf@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

I plan to base the course on observations of the world around us as well as data regarding the world, on how one should reason quantitatively about these observations, and how one can use mathematics to advance our reasoning. 

I will stress estimation and approximation techniques, including order-of-magnitude arguments and the ability to understand graphs and plots and how  different functions “should” behave. I will do some combinatorics, as well as probability and statistics including Bayesian methods, showing how they are, in fact, how we reason in practice about the world. Examples such as Simpson's paradox, the prosecutors fallac, fractals and the use of Benford's law in detecting financial fraud will all be featured.

Some part of the course will describe models, how to construct them and how to interpret them, such as the random walk and its many applications, in physics as well as in finance.

Some specific areas of science that I plan to draw from when constructing my examples are: climate change, neural networks and machine learning, infectious diseases, energy and sustainability, population growth, inequality measures and genetics.

Learning Outcomes

It is expected that students will complete this course with a clearer understanding of why thinking quantitatively about the world about us is important, but also the idea that the ability to quickly estimate things is something that is both enjoyable and instructive. I will use so-called "Fermi problems" as my examples.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

No pre-requisites exvept a willingness to learn and to surmount any prior fear of mathematics. I plan to use no single book but will suggest readings as appropriate in class.

Grading Rubric

Grading will be based on regular in-class quizzes, a mid-semester examination and an end-semester examination. The end-semester examination will count for 30% of the grade, the mid-semester examination for 20% of the grade and assignments/quizzes for 50%. Active participation in discussions us encouraged.

Overview

When we observe things around us that are affecting our health, such as poor air quality, unhealthy water quality, declining nutrition of food etc. how do we react? Human involvement in environmental changes is currently an important topic of concern, but it is clear that we need to improve our understanding of how ecological and environmental systems work to participate in shifting the framework from discourse to action. This course provides an overview of global ecological systems, environmental change and natural patterns, using specific case studies, to set the stage for more informed discussion and debate. Building a fundamental ecological understanding is an important part of this course. Simultaneously we will examine how environmental crises are framed, compare it with the science, and critically evaluate the solutions currently on offer. Students will have opportunities to deep dive into “green” solutions in light of the big philosophical debates underpinning them with a view to promote critical analyses.

Overview

EVS FC: Contemporary Environmental Challenges

The contemporary world is beset with growing environmental problems. The global focus on economic growth and development has led us onto an unsustainable path: growing scientific evidence now suggests that the Earth may not be able to cope with the demands imposed on it.  This has created an urgent need to critically examine complex environmental issues from a variety of perspectives. It is necessary to inculcate holistic thinking on environmental challenges and their purported solutions, that includes concerns of social and ecological sustainability.  This course will discuss some of the most current concerns related to the environment, as well as societal responses to them, from a multidisciplinary perspective. Water scarcity, climate change, forest degradation, biological extinction, pollution and agrarian distress are some of the issues that will be studied. This course is intended to familiarise students with environmental problems  and engender a holistic perspective in understanding causes and possible solutions through the lens of science and equity. This course will encourage students to synthesize information across a variety of sources.Practically the course will be taught using a combination of lectures, movies, slideshows and in-class discussions. Discussion on assigned readings will engender critical thinking and debate in class. Students will undertake group projects on current case studies (such as river pollution, tiger tourism etc.). Assessments will be based on class tests, group projects and class participation.

 

Learning Outcomes
  • The course will create an awareness of, and sensitivity to the complexities of contemporary environmental challenges;
  • Students will learn to analyse environmental issues from a multidisciplinary perspective;
  • Students will learn to think and write analytically about complex issues
  • They will be taught to synthesize knowledge from different sources including scholarly papers, visual media and local traditional knowledge

Overview

This Course is titled 'Environment, Development, Climate Change.' This course offers an overview of the interrelationship between environment, development and climate change. It examines various concepts and components of ecosystem and biosphere, and diverse ways in which human-non human lives exist, cooperate and compete with each other. It traces the history of development through different phases of human-nature correlation and explains how theories, practices and questions of globalisation, sustainability, transition, inter-generational equity, gender, health, disasters and green growth have important bearings on our understanding of ecology in present times. In this course, environment and development are also inferred in the context of climate change. It analyses not only how development has led to climate change, but also how climate change is defining our development, which incorporates socio-economic distribution of impacts and burden, energy and carbon emissions, politics of climate change and justice, and alternatives of renewable energy and sustainable transition.

Learning Outcomes

The course is organized around weekly lectures and discussions based on the readings. Students will be asked to write an essay on one of the topics of the course, with footnotes and bibliography, and further readings will be given to them on their chosen topic, so that they can go in much more depth on a particular topic.

Unit 2: (Week 3 & 4): Historical Evolution and Critical perspectives on Development, Growth, Industrialisation, Sustainable Development and Development Indexes.

Unit 3: (Week 5): Energy, Environment, Development

Unit 4: (Week 6): Rural, Land, Agriculture, Livelihood, Environment, Development

Faculty Name
Madhusudan Mysore Doreswamy [mdmadhu@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Course Description:

This course explores a fundamental question of the human-nature relationship: to what extent are humans a part of the natural environment, and to what extent are we apart from it? With an anchor in with the most idealised representations of nature—the setting aside of wild, mostly unpeopled spaces—students will explore how these landscapes, far from being isolated sanctuaries, are deeply embedded within human social, economic, and political systems. With these protected areas at one end, where biodiversity, ecosystem services and their conservation are key ideas, seeking to separate humans from nature seems a reasonable goal. Over the semester, we interrogate this idea of separation as we widen our circle of exploration and examine the nature-human interface at increasingly broader scales in the contexts of agriculture, natural resource extraction, infrastructure and industrial development, urbanisation, and climate change. Through critique, we hope to arrive at the reality that addressing environmental challenges is less about how we separate the natural and human worlds, and much more about how they can better share a single planet.

Weekly themes guide the exploration along an arc that begins with foundational ideas about nature as part-biological-reality and part-cultural-construct, before moving through the dynamics of biodiversity, resource governance, and agriculture as pivotal interfaces between human and natural systems. The course then expands outward to examine the cascading impacts of urbanisation, industrial development, and climate change. At each stage, students will analyse how environmental challenges unfold across interconnected scales, from local ecosystems shaped by traditional practices to global processes driven by industrialisation and policy frameworks. These themes highlight biodiversity as a cornerstone of ecological resilience, agriculture as a key driver of environmental transformation, and urbanisation as both a challenge and an opportunity for sustainable futures. Throughout, the emphasis remains on the tensions and trade-offs inherent in balancing sustainability with equity and justice.

By engaging with the course’s interdisciplinary perspectives, students will develop a comprehensive understanding of environmental challenges across scales and contexts. They will learn to critically analyse the interconnectedness of biodiversity, resource governance, agriculture, urbanisation, and climate change, uncovering how these themes are shaped by historical contingencies and power dynamics. The course emphasizes the development of skills to recognise and navigate trade-offs and tensions in environmental decision-making, equipping students to apply frameworks that address sustainability, justice, and resilience. By the end of the course, students should be envision the natural and the human worlds as deeply connected, and contemplate equitable and sustainable future for both.

Tentative Weekly Themes:

1. The Idea of Nature

2. Biodiversity and Conservation

3. Human-Nature Relationships

4. The Commons and Natural Resource Governance

5. Agriculture and the Environment

6. Industrialisation, Development and Sustainability

7. Waste, Pollution, and Urbanization

8. Climate Change

9. Environmental Justice

10. Political Ecology and Power

11. Collective Action, Movements and Resistance

12. Synthesis and Reflections

Faculty Name
Ekanto Ghosh [ekanto.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ,Priyank Narayan [priyank.narayan@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sagar Singhal [sagar.singhal@ashoka.edu.in] ,Shubha Mahajan [shubha.mahajan_tf@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

“Is AI really taking jobs away?” is a question that we often get asked by students.
While everyone has their own way of answering this question, the answer often
revolves around the word ‘creativity’. The World Economic Forum’s Future of Jobs
report year after year ranks creativity as the most sought after skill in the job
market. This course teaches you exactly that - creative problem solving.
The ability to create and innovate isn’t just a skill, it's a mindset. This course will
guide you through the process of enhancing your creative abilities, helping you
recognize and nurture your innate potential. With hands-on activities and case
studies, you’ll learn to generate original ideas and turn them into actionable
solutions. Every good solution begins with a well-defined problem. Defining
problems and being creative about solving problems has come to be known as
design thinking.
Design thinking is a human-centered approach to innovation that’s used by some of
the world’s leading companies like Apple, Google, and Airbnb. Through this course,
you’ll learn how to empathize with users, define problems clearly, ideate, prototype,
and test solutions. It’s more than just theory—you’ll walk away with practical skills
that can be applied across industries. You will learn design thinking through live
action projects. In this project, you will provide consulting services to startups, and
use design thinking methodology to solve their problem statements.
This is a 13-week course comprising 39 classroom hours and approximately 20 hours
of project work, group assignments and book readings. The Mid Term Project and
the End Term Project will be team-based submissions.

description:
Physics Lab 1:Introduction to Physics through Experiments [PHY-1010] [PHY-1010-1]

Faculty Name
Amin Ahmad Nizami [amin.nizami@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This is a gateway course — mandatory for those intending to major or minor in physics, though also of more general interest. The purpose of this course is to introduce students to the way in which physicists observe the world around them — what they notice, how they design experiments and make observations, how they analyse the information collected, how they match them against theory-based expectations, and how in general they draw inferences. Anyone with an interest in experimental science is welcome — there are no pre-requisites.

Learning Outcomes

Designing (and appreciating the design of) experiments.
Understanding instruments, appreciating their design, and using them appropriately.
Acquiring data correctly, using appropriate instruments.
Understanding the limits of your measuring instruments, which are related to their least count and, in the case of time measurement, also to your reaction time. This leads to what is usually called error (but perhaps better called precision).
Recording data appropriately in your logbook, with the correct units.
Graphing your data, and fitting lines and curves to them if necessary.
Doing the necessary calculations, with sensitivity to dimensions and units.
Drawing conclusions, and stating them correctly. This includes understanding how measurement errors propagate into your conclusions.
Writing lab reports.

Grading Rubric

Continuous evaluation based on lab reports (60%), 3 lab vivas (15%); final exam 20%,  lab attendance (5%)

Attendance Policy

Full attendance is expected, with exceptions only for compelling reasons.  You should write to the TF (cc to the instructor) if you are unable to make it to a particular session. Note that no extra make-up sessions (outside the Tue -Thurs lab sessions) can be arranged.   You can not pass the course with less than 75% attendance. If you are more than 5 minutes late for a lab session, you will be marked absent.

Overview

India has undergone multiple transformations in its 75 year journey as an independent nation-state.  There is no doubt that India is significantly behind on several indicators, but its achievements in many areas are remarkable too. The goal of this course is to understand structures and processes that shaped India post-independence. We will use various social science concepts to reflect on contemporary Indian politics and develop an understanding about important arenas that are keenly contested in terms of ideological world-view as well as policy choices.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

This course is designed to develop a more rounded and holistic view of contemporary India There are no prerequisites for this course. However, to better appreciate the course, students should be informed about contemporary political issues and developments on a regular basis. This can be done by reading a national daily newspaper and regularly following the editorial pages to understand how there could be different perspectives on the same issue. Students are expected to read at least 60-70 pages per week.

Grading Rubric

The final grades in the course will be based on a continuous assessment system, i.e., participation in the class including attendance (15%), three short assignments (35%), a mid-term (20%) and a final exam (30%). 

Active participation is a significant component of the course, and will require more than just turning up to class. Doing the readings, and making comments and questions that reveal your familiarity will go a long way in securing a full participation grade.

Attendance Policy

The course material requires students to attend lectures regularly and participate in discussion. A significant percentage of your final grade is based on attendance/participation during the lecture.

Please send a formal email to your Teaching Fellows (TFs) if you are missing any lecture. If you miss more than two classes without a validated proof of exceptional circumstances, you will lose grades.

Introduction to Comparative Politics [POL-1005] [POL-1005-1]

Faculty Name
Kaustav Dhar Chakrabarti [kaustav.chakrabarti@ashoka.edu.in] ,Kartika Jamdar [kartika.jamdar_ug25@ashoka.edu.in] ,Qousain Latief [qousain.latief_ug25@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The course is a survey of major themes in the study of comparative politics. It asks a broad range of questions that are both theoretically and substantially important. What are states and how did they become the primary form of political organization in the world? Why are some states more capable than others? Why are some countries more prosperous than others, is there one or many paths toward economic development? Why is inequality rising across the world? What is ethnicity and nationalism and why is it associated with conflict and violence? What is globalization, and why is it celebrated in the Global South and associated with rising populism in the West? We will integrate theory with case studies from across the world.

As an introductory course, it will also place an equal emphasis on familiarising students with the political science ‘approach’ to studying politics and society. A thorough understanding of the scientific enquiry will prepare you to expertly read empirical (that is, research that is based on observation) journal articles and books. We will understand the logic of comparing cases to draw inferences in a scientific manner. We will become comfortable with thinking about politics in terms of unit of analysis, independent and dependent variables, and alternative explanations. The course will also explain how political science attempts to reach causality, that is, how evidence is used to make convincing claims that a particular factor “causes” a phenomenon (state capacity, economic development, civil wars) more significantly than others.

Learning Outcomes

The goals of the course are three-fold. By the end of the course, students should have an overview of some of the major debates in the field of comparative politics. This will prepare students to take advanced courses in political science and other social science departments. Second, the course will reinforce the department’s continuous training in analytical thinking. It will bolster students’ ability to distinguish between different theoretical explanations, evaluate the merit of competing arguments made in the literature, and communicate their arguments clearly in written form. Finally, the course will also augment students’ intellectual ability to take an informed stand in contemporary political debates and become more consummate readers of news and popular media.

Faculty Name
Ratul Lahkar [ratul.lahkar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This is a course on game theory and applications. We will study the four fundamental types of games. They are (1) static games of complete information, (2) dynamic games of incomplete information, (3) static games of incomplete information and (4) dynamic games of incomplete information. In each of these topics, we will study the fundamental game theoretic solutions and important economic applications.

Learning Outcomes

1. Static games of complete information: Dominant strategies, rationalizability, Nash equilibrium and applications like oligopoly and externalities. 

2. Dynamic games of complete information: Backward induction, subgame perfection and applications like limit pricing, bargaining and repeated games. 

3. Static games of incomplete information: Bayesian Nash equilibrium and applications like auctions and mechanism design.

4. Dynamic games of incomplete information: Perfect Bayesian equilibrium and applications like adverse selection and moral hazard.

Overview

This is a compulsory Economics course offered by the Department of Economics at Ashoka University for all MA Economics and PhD students. This is the second course in the macroeconomics sequence for first-year MA and PhD students. Having been exposed to ideas and models of macroeconomic growth in Macroeconomics I, this course introduces students to modern macroeconomic theories of Real Business Cycles and New Keynesian Economics. Moreover, the course will focus on the micro-founding behavior of economic agents that is absent in introductory macroeconomics by discussing theories on consumption and saving. description:
Axiomatic Methods, Fair Division Problems and Welfare Economics [ECO-3102] [ECO-3102-1]

Faculty Name
Mihir Bhattacharya [mihir.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

1. Fair division problem: Proportional, uniform gains/losses and equal surplus/equal losses. Applications: mergers and acquisitions, bankruptcy problems and task scheduling problems. Axioms: merge-proof, split-proof, resource monotonicity, population monotonicity, envy-freeness and strategy-proofness. 

2. Topics in welfare economics: Cardinal models of interpersonal comparisons in the context of division problems. Welfarism and three methods: Utilitarian, Egalitarian (or Egalitarian*) and Nash's method for maximizing social welfare. Applications: u-equal sacrifice method of taxation, work-leisure allocation between two agents when the planner is utilitarian or egalitarian.

3. Cooperative game theory and bargaining theory: Shapley value and the Core and some results on their axiomatic properties. We will then discuss Nash's bargaining model and introduce the utilitarian, egalitarian, Nash's and the Kalai-Smorodinsky solution to the problem. Theorems from classic papers like Nash(1950) and Kalai(1977).

Learning Outcomes

Students will learn about fairness notions in Economic design, axioms and properties which should be met in sharing of divisible goods and resources. They will learn about division rules and their applicability in different settings: bankruptcy, cost sharing, and surplus sharing.

In the second half students will learn different concepts from cooperative decision-making: how to maximize social welfare, and different notions of welfare: utilitarianism, egalitarianism and the Nash solution. They will learn about the ideal properties a solution should satisfy in different settings.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)
  1. Fair division and collective welfare, by Hervé J. Moulin (MIT Press, 2004)
  2. Axioms of cooperative decision making, by Hervé J. Moulin (Econometric Society Monographs, 1988)

Articles from Econometrica, Journal of Economic Theory, Journal of Public Economics, Social Choice and Welfare and others.

Faculty Name
Amin Ahmad Nizami [amin.nizami@ashoka.edu.in] ,Suratna Das [suratna.das@ashoka.edu.in] ,Prashant Kumar Bai [prashant.bai_phd24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Brief Course Description:
This mathematical physics course aims to be an introduction to differential equations with a view towards physical applications (in particular in later physics courses). The course will be in two parts. Part I on first order ODEs, non-linear systems and dynamical systems will be taught by Amin A. Nizami and Part II on second order ODEs, special functions, Fourier analysis and PDEs will be taught by Suratna Das.
Part 1 (AAN, 12 lectures)
Ordinary differential equations (first order): Overview and importance. Rate of change problems, modeling simple systems, radioactive decay; logistic curve, population growth, resource depletion and harvesting. First order linear equations, Integrating factors. linear ODEs with constant coefficients. Dynamics in the phase plane, coupled systems of linear first order ODEs.
Nonlinear ODEs and Dynamical systems: phase portraits, flows and vector fields, phase plane analysis, linearisation about fixed points, stability analysis, limit cycles and bifurcations. Topological index of a closed curve and index theorems. Lotka-Volterra (competitive and/or prey-predator) model; non-linear oscillators, brief discussion of Poincare-Bendixson theorem and basic ideas of chaotic dynamical systems.

Part 2 (SD, 12 lectures)
Second order ODEs:  Power series solutions, some special functions (Bessel, Legendre and Hermite).
Fourier Series and Fourier integrals with a few physical applications
Partial differential equations: Linear first and second order PDEs, separation of variables, illustration through Laplace’s equation/ wave equation/ diffusion equation.

Learning Outcomes

A familiarity with linear differential equations and analytical ways of solving them; Also an acquaintance with basic geometric/qualitative ways of understanding nonlinear sytems (linearisation, stability, fixed points, flows, phase portraits etc.)

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Prerequisites: Multivariable calculus and partial differentiation besides the differential and integral calculus covered at the senior secondary school level. Some familiarity with basic linear algebra - eigenvalues and eigenvectors.

We will use the following textbooks:

G F Simmons, Differential Equations with Applications and Historical Notes 2nd edition (McGraw Hill)

Steven Strogatz, Nonlinear Dynamics and Chaos, 2nd edition (CRC press) 

Other books useful for reference and supplementary reading are:

Edwards and Penney, Differential Equations and Boundary Value Problems (Pearson)

Smale, Hirsch and Devaney, Differential equations, dynamical systems and an introduction to chaos, 3rd edition (Academic Press)

These are all available in Indian editions

Part 2: Assignments (30%), (endterm) Exam (70%).

Students are expected to attend all the lecture and DS sessions. To write the midterm and final exams, you need to have 75% class attendance

Overview

The course is designed to familiarize students with the basic theoretical treatment of oscillatory phenomena which are abundant in nature. In the first part of the course (oscillations and waves), we shall discuss oscillations and waves in mechanical, electrical and acoustic systems and try to draw parallels between them. At points, we shall try to illustrate similarities between oscillatory behaviours in different systems. Students may get a better understanding of the theoretical treatments of some of the ideas when they perform experiments in PHY-2020 course. In the second part of the course, we shall focus exclusively on electromagnetic waves and their properties with particular emphasis on visible window of electromagnetic waves and its interaction with the matter. The theoretical treatments that you have studied in the last semester (PHY-2210 and PHY-2310) are essential for this course, and this course, in some sense,  is a continuation of those two courses at a slightly advanced level. A fair familiarity with calculus is very essential to follow the mathematical treatment of the subject; we shall give a basic introduction to complex exponential representation of waves, Fourier analysis and partial differential calculus; students are recommended to familiarize themselves with all these mathematical techniques.

Faculty Name
Anuradha Saha [anuradha.saha@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The process of economic growth and differences in patterns of growth within and across economies are some of the most interesting areas in economics. This course provides an introduction to the study of economic growth. The first two units of the course will be a theoretical exploration on the different sources of growth – population growth, technological change, accumulation of physical and human capital, geography, government and structural change. The analysis of these economic models will set the stage for the last unit where we will look at empirical studies on current patterns of growth. Students must be mathematically comfortable with concepts of functions, derivatives, integrals, and ordinary differential equations. Some basic knowledge on regression analysis is also required.
 

Learning Outcomes
  • Students should understand growth concepts like: technological progress, capital accumulation, source of growth, endogenous growth, to name a few
  • Students should be well aware of the growth experiences of various countries or regions in the past few decades
  • Students must be well-read on stylized facts on economic growth
  • Students must be able to write on topics in economic growth
  • Exceptional students shall be comfortable with inter-temporal problems. They should be able to convert such questions in mathematical equations as well as English language
     
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Introduction to Economic Growth, by Charles I. Jones and Dietrich Vollrath. Third Edition
Economic Growth, by David N Weil. Third Edition
Students should have a hard or soft copy of the textbooks. They should be able to do all end-of-chapter questions.
 

Grading Rubric

The average grade for the course would be about B. 

Attendance Policy

If a student misses 6 or more classes, they get two grade cuts (A- will be lowered to B, B+ to B- and so on).

In the past, students have failed the course for missing classes.

This is the second course in the Macroeconomics sequence at the undergraduate level.

Faculty Name
Sanjukta Datta [sanjukta.datta@ashoka.edu.in] ,Aarushi Verma [aarushi.verma_ug25@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This introductory course on ancient India provides a broad overview of the period between 2 million years ago and the 2nd century BCE, tracing the journey from the establishment of prehistoric horizons to the decline of the first empire. Some of the important milestones in this journey include the consolidation of food production, efflorescence of the Harappan culture as the first urban civilization, diversity of non-Harappan Chalcolithic cultures, proliferation of state systems coinciding with second urbanization, and the transformation of one such state into a trans-regional empire. By incorporating new research in the field, the course delves into exciting themes such as the historical traditions of early India, the beginnings of social stratification, and India's linkages with the wider world through migrations, invasions, politico-diplomatic exchanges and religious missions.

This course unravels the profound changes that South Asia went through in the first three quarters of the second millennium CE. We will begin our journey in the early-eleventh century with the maritime invasions of Southeast Asia by the Chola navy of South India and the invasion of North India by Turko-Afghan horse-warriors. We will end with the fragmentation of the Mughal Empire and the rise of regional states in the eighteenth century. Within this time-frame, we will explore the rise and fall of sultanates and kingdoms, the dynamics of commercial production and mercantile traffic, the workings of kingly power, the techniques of military engagements, and the nature of social hierarchies and oppression. We will also closely study the relationships between gender and politics, religion and society, language and power, art and statecraft, language and culture. We will look at sufis and merchants, rulers and slaves, princesses and labourers, horses and elephants. In the process, we will uncover the diversity, dynamism, and connections South Asia embodied during this period.

NOTE: There are no pre-requisites for this course. The four History of India courses can be taken in any order.

Learning Outcomes

This course will impart in students a sound understanding of the history of medieval and early modern South Asia.

Is it wrong to slap a child? If it is, is it wrong in every society and in every age, or is its wrongness relative to those factors? What is knowledge? What kind of knowledge do we have? Faculty Name
Swargajyoti Gohain [swargajyoti.gohain@ashoka.edu.in] ,Venkatraman P C [venkatraman.c_phd23@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course explores important concepts and approaches in sociology and anthropology. The syllabus is designed to familiarize the students with select concepts and ethnographies of the discipline. We will discuss the sociology and anthropology of kinship, social stratification (caste, race, tribe), cities, migration, nationalism, and environment. Rather than treating these as independent concepts, we seek to show their inter-relation with other social phenomena. For example, how are notions of family and kinship intertwined with science and technology studies; what is the connection between migration and urban transformations, how does one critically study the relation between environment and tourism etc. By doing this, the course demonstrates how the sociological approach explores and finds relations and connections between people, places, and objects. The objective of this course is to develop students’ appreciation of concepts and categories and their evolution and innovation. This course will also demonstrate to students how theory, ethnography and critical thinking can be integrated. Course materials will include examples from India as well as other parts of the world, and will offer a representative overview and not exhaustive coverage of all topics and perspectives existing in the discipline. Evaluation will be on the basis of written assignments, discussion board responses and class participation.

courseTitle: Gift, Commodity and the Exchange of Values
description:
Gift, Commodity and the Exchange of Values [SOA-2102] [SOA-2102-1]

Faculty Name
Mekhala Krishnamurthy [mekhala.krishnamurthy@ashoka.edu.in] ,Ajayant Katoch [ajayant.katoch_phd23@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What kinds of things are gifts and commodities? What does their exchange tell us about the relations between persons and things, between things and things, and between different persons party to an exchange? What gives a thing a sense of value? Are there such things that are useful but that are not up for exchange? What kinds of debts are generated when gifts and commodities are exchanged? Does the clearing of a debt signal the end of a relationship? Is reciprocity a good thing after all? What happens when you refuse a gift? If being creditable is a respectable characteristic, why are creditors typically such villainous characters? Is being indebted a show of strength or sign of weakness? What goes into making a price? What does it really mean for a thing to be priceless? If time is indeed money, is money also in some way a form or measure of time?

This course is an intensive introduction to the anthropology of exchange through the circulation of gifts and commodities across diverse times and places. We will read a set of classical and contemporary texts that explore the complex processes and relations of gift and commodity exchange and consider the rich and seemingly endless debates that they generate for the discipline and beyond.

Kin, Friends and Enemies [SOA-2104] [SOA-2104-1]

Faculty Name
Can Evren [can.evren@ashoka.edu.in] ,Abhinav Atreya [abhinav.atreya_phd24@ashoka.edu.in] ,Benna Fathima K [benna.k_phd23@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course will introduce students to foundational theories and seminal empirical studies that have shaped how anthropologists explain, interpret, and research the diverse types of social ties that make communities worldwide. Homo sapiens is a social creature who universally builds enduring cooperative relations with fellows. While learning to become and remain a social being is a universal human process likely rooted in our evolutionary makeup, the categories and the frames through which humans relate to, socialize, and cooperate with fellow humans display great diversity across history and geography. Studying these diverse frames of relatedness and asking theoretical questions about what is constant across differences is the primary preoccupation of anthropology as a discipline. Marriage, family, and kinship, in particular, have proved to be near-universal frames, provoking generalizing theories to explain their prevalence and underlying logic. War, enmity, conflict, and rivalry, in the meanwhile, present an equally prevalent frame of relationship. Throughout this course, we will engage with key theories that inform anthropological inquiry on these diverse forms of cooperation and conflict.
