Nationalism, Ethnicity and Violence [SOA-3201/ POL-3054] [SOA-3201/ POL-3054-1]

Faculty Name
Ravindran S [ravindran.sriramachandran@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

45000 Palestinians have been killed in the past year. 80000 Ukranians have been killed since 2022. How do we begin to understand this? This course examines the historical origins and contemporary dynamics of ethnic politics in the developing world, with particular focus on the intersections of ethnicity, nationalism, and violence. Through a study of theoretical approaches, we will explore the impact of colonialism on ethnic identities, the legacy of decolonization on nationalist movements, and the challenges that multiethnic states face post-independence. Case studies will provide insight into the lived experiences behind these complex issues, from political strife in Eastern Europe and the Middle East to conflicts across Africa, and Asia.

Students will engage with key debates in the field, addressing questions such as: To what extent is ethnic identity a driving factor in political violence, or is it simply a label assigned to contemporary conflicts? How can ethnic identity, if it is a causal factor, be integrated into predictive theories? What are the origins and constructions of ethnic identity, and how do they relate to nationalist movements? We will assess both theoretical and empirical studies to critically evaluate whether existing models adequately address these issues.

Designed to equip students with critical analytical tools, this course aims to cultivate historical and theoretical perspectives on ethnic conflict. Rather than focusing on factual knowledge about specific conflicts, students will develop skills to think deeply about ethnicity and politics across varied contexts, enabling a nuanced understanding of the forces that shape ethnic politics globally.

Learning Outcomes
  • Demonstrate knowledge of theories and methodologies that can facilitate the analysis and understanding of the concept of ethnicity and ethnic conflict.
  • Have a greater knowledge of the political, economic, social and cultural issues confronting former colonies at and after independence.
  • Synthesize and contextualize ideas and arguments from different sources.
  • Produce a research paper that displays critical thinking and analytical skills.
  • Use both primary and secondary data to conduct independent research.
Grading Rubric

Each student will be evaluated on mid-term essay (30%) and final research paper 45%), class presentations (15%) and class attendance/ participation/ discussions (10%). Each student will be evaluated for understanding the basic concepts of the course, for ability to demonstrate understanding of continuity and change of these concepts over historical time periods and geographic space. Consideration will be given for the following qualities: ability to reason, breadth of knowledge, aptitude for independent study or research, and precision and ability to communicate in writing and orally.

Attendance Policy

Course requirements: This course consists of lectures and discussions. Attendance is mandatory and attending a class means coming to class having done the requisite readings. More than four absences in either of these class contexts will constitute failure. Attendance and class participation counts for 15% of the class grade.  Each student will write one (6-8 page) mid-term essay and a final essay (10-12 pages) on a topic chosen by the student after discussing it with me (or an assigned topic). These two essays count for 75% of the class grade. Each student has also got to make a presentation on one of the readings which will count for 15% of the grade (a copy of the presentation has to be submitted in the following class after factoring in the discussion in class). Any instance of cheating or plagiarism will result in an F for the course. Please refer to the Ashoka honor code in the OAA website.

All essays should be written in 11 or 12 point Times New Roman (or Arial Narrow) and should be in 1.5 space. Citations should be clearly indicated in a standard format (which will be explained in class).

All exams are cumulative. The grading criteria for the research paper and the exams will be discussed in class. I will give you feedback on your performance after each assignment. If you wish to discuss your performance at other times, you are welcome to see me during my office hours or schedule an appointment.

faculty: shivani.krishna@ashoka.edu.in  , kritika.garg@ashoka.edu.in, rimbik.chatterjee_phd24@ashoka.edu.in, arsha.rathnamt_phd24@ashoka.edu.in, satyam.gupta_phd24@ashoka.edu.in, niranjan.balagopal_phd23@ashoka.edu.in
description:
Exploring Life in the Neighborhood Lab [BIO-1002/ ES-2301] [BIO-1002/ ES-2301-1]

Faculty Name
Kritika Garg [kritika.garg@ashoka.edu.in] ,Shivani [shivani.krishna@ashoka.edu.in ] ,Arsha Rathnam T [arsha.rathnamt_phd24@ashoka.edu.in] ,Niranjan Balagopal [niranjan.balagopal_phd23@ashoka.edu.in] ,Rimbik Chatterjee [rimbik.chatterjee_phd24@ashoka.edu.in] ,Satyam Gupta [satyam.gupta_phd24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Unprecedented loss of biodiversity, anthropogenic activities, exploitation of natural resources, and globalising tendencies in recent decades threaten the balance between the intricate web of life on Earth and the processes that are pivotal to its survival. Although many efforts are being made globally, we are still far from achieving the necessary measures to restore the balance. One of the primary hindrances is the lack of general awareness of how nature drafts the code of life in our neighbourhoods and how various forms of life together respond and form the very basis on which natural forces operate in our backyard, much like a feedback loop. To fill these gaps, this course aims to bring students from various backgrounds— i.e., not limited to Biology only, but also from other sciences, humanities and social sciences— and introduce them to their local ecosystem and the intricacies of biological interactions using some basic and simplified concepts of ecology, evolution, and animal behaviour, followed by field observations as well as laboratory experiments. The course will have many open-ended exercises, encouraging students to develop small questions based on classroom discussions and observing various natural patterns (e.g., diversity of life) and processes (e.g., sexual interactions, prey-predator, disease spread, cannibalism).

Learning Outcomes

Towards the end of this course, we expect students to be more connected to their surroundings, develop an intellectual framework to answer how diverse forms of life coexist, and appreciate the nuanced biological wonders that reside in every pattern and process of the living world. Students will learn to connect bigger ecological phenomena and patterns of animal behaviours with their evolutionary origins. Besides, they will also learn how to build testable hypotheses and design experiments with appropriate sampling, as well as the importance of keeping laboratory notebooks and scientific communication.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The required reading material will be provided at the end of each class. 

Grading Rubric

Attendance and discussion (5%): Every week, there will be one class, where activities include field visits, lab exercises and discussion. Students will be evaluated on their participation in these, where participation grades will be based on quality of participation.

Weekly lab reports (90%): Students will have to submit weekly lab reports on their experiment. However, we will drop the lowest three assignment scores during final evaluation. We will consider best 9 assignments. You will be evaluated based on how structured and meticulous (and honest) you are, not entirely on the experimental results. We will also consider your critical abilities (e.g., pointing out the strengths and weaknesses of experimental methods) while writing the report.

Lab etiquettes (5%): You will be evaluated based on how you behave and follow the lab protocols in the lab.

Percentage to grade conversion: >= 90% A, 85- < 90 A-, 75- < 85 B+, 70- < 75 C+, 60- < 70 C, 40- < 60 D, <40 F.

Attendance Policy

Attendance is mandatory.  It is not possible to repeat experiments that have been missed.

description:
Sites and Sights: Museums, Exhibitions and the Making of the Art [VA-2005/ HIS-3802/ SOA-2225] [VA-2005/ HIS-3802/ SOA-2225-1]

Faculty Name
Sraman Mukherjee [sraman.mukherjee@ashoka.edu.in] ,Chitrakshi Siwach [chitrakshi.siwach_ug25@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Class Meets: Mondays and Wednesdays, 10:10 am to 11:40 am

Office Hours: Wednesdays, 1:30 pm to 2:30 pm or by prior appointment only

Course Level: 2000 to 3000 for Visual Arts  Compulsory course for Visual Arts Minor or Concentration. Course also open for credit and audit by students from any other department/ discipline

Course Prerequisites: None

Course Description How do sites and spaces of visual encounters condition our perceptions of visual images? Seeking answers to these questions, this course brings in dialogue the works of art with the spaces that such works have come to inhabit in our present world – museums, art galleries, and other spaces of visual exhibitions. Moving beyond the established trajectories of looking at exhibitions, museums, and gallery spaces as storehouses of masterpieces of Art, or merely as spaces of ordering, classifying, and displaying objects and images, we will look closely at how exhibition practices of museums and public art galleries, constitute the very category “Art” around a select body of objects and images. Beginning with early modern royal and notable private collections, and cabinet of curiosities across the world, the course will explore the specific moments of the coming into being of public museums and art galleries through fairs, “freak shows”, and world exhibitions in Europe and across different parts of the world. It will explore how politics of collection, museum acquisition, display, and repatriation are tied with larger questions of colonialism, war, loot, postcolonial nationalist reassertions, and postwar encounters with race and ethnicity. With a specific focus on Asia, the course will map the connected global trajectories of museums, art galleries and memorials as dense narratives of unfolding spatial and temporal complexes. In the process it will highlight the role of the artists, curators, and museum/ gallery visitors in the production of a complex set of dialogues around artistic, and curatorial visions. The course will end by looking at contemporary South Asia, mapping the challenges of redesigning exhibition orders of older museums and art institutions and spread of museum modes of display and viewing, with different intent, in commemorative sites, theme parks, memorials, and new temples. This co-constitution of art and art museums will be addressed during class discussions and during compulsory and graded off campus museums galleries, and site classes and   – to the Indian Museum, Kolkata (virtual), the National Gallery of Modern Art, New Delhi (on site), the National Museum, New Delhi (on site,) the National Handloom and Handicrafts Musem, New Delhi, (on site), the Rashtriya Dalit Prerna Sthal, Nodia (on site), the Swaminarayan Akshardham Complex, New Delhi (on site),  Bhai Mati Das Museum (on site),  the British Museum, London (virtual) and the Victoria and Albert Museum, London (virtual).

Learning Outcomes

On successful completion of the course, we will be able to: a) Explore the main trends in the development of Art History, Visual Culture and Museum Studies by accessing the critical essential skills. b) Evaluate the approaches of artists, art historians, and curators to the field of visual arts and museum studies c) Explore curatorial practices in the art world d) Develop the interests for a future training in art curatorial programme and critical museum studies.

This course follows a pattern of continuous assessment and grading through the entire semester including active class participation, and museum and gallery visits, and mid semester and end semester evaluations. The assessment and grading criterion are as follows:

Overview

A metric space is a set equipped with the notion of a distance. The line, the plane, the usual three-dimensional space are examples. There are others like the surface of the sphere, spaces of sequences and functions. The theory of metric spaces is the study of such spaces and of functions on them. In the logical scheme of things it follows what we have learnt in Real Analysis and comes before subjects like Functionl Analysis.

Topologial spaces are more general. They allow us to formulate notions of convergence and continuity when no natural metric is available.

This course begins with the study of metric spaces and then goes on to study general topological paces.

Understanding of the concepts of metric and topological spaces.

Deeper understanding of Real Analysis.

Developing further the ability to write mathematical proofs.

Faculty Name

Overview

This elective course focusses on questions of social exclusion and social justice in environment, with a particular emphasis on race, caste and class. The concept of social exclusion as an analytical framework has become increasingly relevant for an understanding of the notions of environmental inequality, conflicts, rights and justice. The course will capture the social exclusion structures and processes which restrict the access of certain social groups to environmental resources and entitlements. It will explain the different forms of social disadvantage – in village and community, in land and water, in space and commons, in wilderness and conservation – that persist, in multiple variants and with different intensity, across societies and nations. It will locate the agency to groups that either guard their domain of privilege or challenge the system of social inequalities and segmentation. Thus, understanding social exclusion as a condition/outcome as well as a dynamic process, the course will also examine some environmental justice movements. The course will also be contextually and temporally embedded. In the north, for example, along with African-Americans, Latino and indigenous people, the focus has been the changing nature of social exclusion in environment. Accordingly, the relevant focus groups are the new social groups, including the immigrants and ethnic groups. By contrast, in the Indian context, the problem is one of the persistent, multiple exclusion of certain social groups like Dalit affecting their basic environmental access and rights.

Learning Outcomes

The course is organized around weekly lectures and discussions based on the readings. Students will be asked to write an essay on one of the topics of the course, with footnotes and bibliography, and further readings will be given to them on their chosen topic, so that they can go in much more depth on a particular topic.

Unit 2: (Week 2-3): Race, Caste, Class and Environment: Patterns and Processes

Unit 5: (Week 10-11): Environmental Justice Movements: A Global and Indian Outlook

Unit 6: (Week 12): Environmental Politics and Policy against Social Exclusion

Faculty Name
Amita Baviskar [amita.baviskar@ashoka.edu.in] ,Twisha Sangwan [twisha.sangwan_ug25@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Since 2007, more people in the world live in urban than in rural areas. Between slums and smart cities, they inhabit a world of social conflict, ecological crisis, and contending visions of the future. As cities become even more central to social experience and aspiration, we need to understand their place in history and in human imagination. This course looks at cities through three thematic lenses: accumulation, order, and identity. It studies cities in relation to the countryside, tracing flows of people and goods that create wealth and poverty. It examines the spatial politics of managing urban populations, from planning to securitisation. It analyses cities as places where cultural identities – parochial and progressive – are formed and defended. It uses these themes to illuminate the political ecology of cities in the Global South, particularly issues around land, water, waste, and climate change.

Physics of Matter [PHY-3710] [PHY-3710-1]

Faculty Name
Garima Mishra [garima.mishra@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Overview:

Matters are all around us and we get frequent encounter with them. Some very common questions come to mind, i.e. why they behave in certain specific manner? A simple example, not everything shines but metal does. What makes glass transparent etc.

“Physics of matter” describes this world around us.  And this knowledge is used to engineer new materials and exploit their properties to change our word, semiconductor technology (whole electronic industry), is one such example of it. This course will also be the laboratory for the fundamental courses of Physics you studied in last two year.

Contents: 

Drude theory of metals:Basic assumption of theory, Equation of motion, DC conductivity, Hall effect, AC conductivity, thermal conductivity, Wiedemann-Franz law;

Sommerfeld theory of metals: Free electron(Quantum picture), Periodic boundary condition, Density of state, Fermi energy,  Fermi temperature, Ground state energy Fermi pressure, thermal properties of free electron gas (specific heat),  Wiedemann-Franz law;

 Crystal structure: Bravais lattice, primitive vectors, 2d and 3d lattices,  primitive unit cell, Wigner Seitz cell and conventional cell, packing fraction;

Reciprocal lattice: Diffraction from periodic structure, Laue condition, Reciprocal lattice vector, Brillouin zone, Lattice plane and Miller indices, Bragg formulation of diffraction, Von Laue formulation of diffraction, Bragg planes, Ewald construction;

Lattice vibrations:  1-d monoatomic Bravais lattice, Dispersion relation, Specific heat of solid: High and low temperature, Boltzmann and Einstein model, Normal mode and phonon, Debye model for specific heat, 1-d diatomic chain, optical and acoustic branches and gap, Lattice thermal conductivity: Elementary kinetic theory;

Electrical properties of material: periodic potential and Bloch’s theorem, crystal momentum, band gap (perturbation theory), Energy Band, mixing waves, Reduced and extended zone scheme, Semiconductor;

Superconductivity, Soft Matters, Magnetic Properties of Matter

N W Ashcroft and N D Mermin, Solid State Physics

C. Kittel, Introduction to Solid State Physics

M Doi, Soft Matter Physics

Anthropology's Methods [SOA-3101] [SOA-3101-1]

Faculty Name
Mekhala Krishnamurthy [mekhala.krishnamurthy@ashoka.edu.in] ,Pulari Baskar [pulari.baskar_tf@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

There are few disciplines that seem to be so deeply wedded to a method as anthropology is to something called fieldwork and to something related called ethnography. So much so that one often wonders if and to what extent anthropology is method? This course explores the relationships between anthropology and ethnography and those between question and method in the making of the discipline. Indeed, in some ways, the course could also have been named Anthropology's Questions. Here are some other questions we will ask: What might it mean to have an anthropological imagination or an ethnographic sensibility? How are they related? Where does the field of fieldwork begin and end and how does one find it? What is the relationship between a 'site' and 'sight' in constituting the field? How else does one sense the field? How long does it take to arrive at and exist in the everyday and how does one exit? How does one deal with questions of subjects and objects, subjectivity and objectivity, intimacy and scale, the actual and the virtual, power and privilege, anonymity and representation, originality and authenticity? How does one go about uncovering and establishing relationships in practice? What is the role of comparison in anthropology? What does it mean to move relationally and comparatively in conceptual and empirical terms? What are the different ways in which anthropologists approach 'the field' and 'the archive'? How does one go about conducting fieldwork and composing an ethnography? What are disciplinary codes and conventions, how are they established, when are they broken? In what ways might the limitations of anthropology's methods expand our imagination of its very possibilities?  Over the semester, this course will attempt to address these and other questions through close reading, discussion and debates on a range of anthropological texts and texts on anthropology and its methods. Students will also complete a series of methodological exercises and assignments, including crafting a short research proposal.

Faculty Name
Garima Mishra [garima.mishra@ashoka.edu.in] ,Susmita Saha [susmita.saha@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Thermal physics examines systems composed of a vast number of particles, typically on the order of 1023. Tracking the movement of each individual particle in these systems is neither feasible nor necessary. Interestingly, many properties of bulk matter are independent of the microscopic details. For example, heat flows naturally from hot to cold objects, and liquids boil more readily at lower pressures. What’s remarkable is that we can accurately predict these behaviours without needing to know the exact characteristics of the individual particles. This is made possible by thermodynamics, which adopts a phenomenological approach. Rather than analysing the complexities of microscopic interactions, thermodynamics focuses on macroscopic quantities that can be measured directly. In this course, we will examine how the fundamental principles of thermal equilibrium arise from a few basic concepts, offering valuable insights into the behaviour of these systems.

 

Topics that this course will cover include, Basic concepts: Temperature and the Equation of State,  First and second laws (work and internal energy; heat engine, Carnot theorem, Clausius theorem, entropy) thermodynamic potentials and methods (natural variables, Maxwell equations, chemical potential, fundamental relation), thermodynamics of phase transition, Kinetic theory of gases.

Reference books:

1.  Fundamentals of Statistical and Thermal Physics by F. Reif
2.  A treatise on heat by Saha and Shrivastava

3. Heat and Thermodynamics by Zemansky and Dittman

4, Thermodynamics and an introduction to thermostatistics by Callen

Learning Outcomes

It will provide a concept to understand the macroscopic behaviour of various  systems to understand the internal state of it.

Introduction to Children’s Literature [ENG-2330] [ENG-2330-1]

Faculty Name
Geetanjali Chanda [geetanjali.chanda@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What we read as children forms who we become and provides our first world view. This course provides an opportunity to critically assess the stories that shaped our understanding of morals, culture, and values, as well as those we will impart to future generations. In this discussion-oriented interactive course, we will read and review children’s books, examine the purposes of visual literacy, and write reviews on specific authors and illustrators. We will write our own children’s book to gauge all that we have learnt.

This course aims to examine how the books children read shape their outlook and emotional development. We will study the historical, creative, nurturing, emotional, and educational aspects of these forms of literature and their impact on us later in life. We will also consider why a study of children’s literature is important, and how it impacts pedagogies for children across borders.

We will examine the views of multiple theoretical thinkers and texts in conjunction with actual children's literature. We will ask the important but often overlooked questions about this particular genre, mainly focusing on Indian and Western children’s literature. The purpose is not so much to compare these two cultural offerings, but to give us a taste of both.

We shall consider popular stories for children up to 12 years old, including Harry Potter & The Philosopher’s Stone, Amar Chitra Katha, Matilda, The Little Prince, Feluda and Mulan. At the same time, we will also study theoretical thinkers such as Jack Zipes, Seth Lerer, Paulo Freire, and Bruno Bettelheim to help us navigate the complex field of children’s literature in relation to issues of culture, religion, difference, gender, and sexuality.

We will unpack the didactic intent as well as the pleasure principle that might have prompted the writers. Authorial intent is, however, only one part of our study; the other part is to see how children and parents receive these stories. Children’s literature creates moral as well as national frameworks that help acculturate young people. In examining the genre of children’s literature, we will consider various sub-genres such as picture books, fairy tales, fables, and chapter books.

Overview

With the rise of Nazism, Stalinism, and monopoly capitalism during the interwar period in Europe, a group of intellectuals came together to examine and diagnose some of challenges that came with this modernity — rise of bureaucracy, mass politics, capitalism, culture industry and the increasing obsession with astrology. While this group of scholars were influenced by Hegel, Marx, Weber, Freud, among others, their analysis moved beyond traditional approaches in political and social theory.

Focusing on the transformative and revolutionary potential of theory, the writings of Max Horkheimer, Walter Benjamin, Theodor Adorno, Herbert Marcuse, Jurgen Habermas—as critical theory—has influenced disciplines as varied as political science, sociology, gender studies, film and cultural studies, comparative literature among others.

Introduction to Critical Thinking [CT-0001] [CT-0001-2]

Faculty Name
Arpita Das [arpita.das@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

In this course, you will develop and rehearse the habits that are essential to the development of a critical mind: reading, writing, speaking, listening and, of course, thinking. In effect, you will learn to ask the ‘why’ and ‘how’ questions alongside the ‘who’ and ‘what’ queries you have been posing through your school education. You will engage with a variety of source materials and understand how to ask questions that extend and enrich your understanding—of situations, texts, institutions and people. You will explore the distinctness of academic research and writing, and participate in an active knowledge community constituted by your peers. By the close of the course, you will have a clearer understanding of what it means to be a scholar in an academic setting, and a keener sense of your own processes of learning, thinking and writing.

The theme this semester for this particular ICT course will be 'Feminisms and Masculinities' where we will read essays and extracts by Mukul Kesavan, Sanjay Srivastava, Rahul Roy, Joseph Campbell, Rebecca Solnit, Sharmila Rege, Meena Kandasamy, bell hooks, and others and explore whether there is one universal Feminism and one accepted Masculinity or is the world inhabited by multiple feminisms and several masculinities; we shall also try to look carefully for links between these multiple feminisms and varying masculinities. In exploring these questions, we will also look at a variety of popular cultural references: memes, short films, podcasts, and advertisements. 

Learning Outcomes

Reading:

1. Breaking down texts into identifiable parts.

2. Making patterns and connections across texts

3. Building reading stamina and the ability to select texts

4. Understanding textual context, genre and source material and documenting these via strategic note-making.

Writing 

1. Developing the craft of outlining, revising, editing

2. Applying form, voice, style, tone to affect writing

3. Developing logical, coherent, structured writing

4. Using explanatory, narrative and justificatory writing

Thinking

1. Practising converting thoughts into words

2. Narrowing down a curiosity or thought into a question

3. Constructing and developing a reasoned argument

4. Engaging meaningfully with multiple perspectives

Speaking-Listening

1. Aiming for confidence, clarity, coherence 

2. Practising and harnessing audience engagement 

3. Developing active and respectful listening to others 

4. Engaging meaningfully with ongoing discussions

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

You can expect to do regular reading (of academic texts and wider materials) in this course. These will be specified on a weekly basis on the schedule at the end of this outline. In addition, you can expect to write consistently, participate in giving and taking feedback, and work on medium-term projects both individually and in collaboration with your course mates.

Grading Rubric

The ICT will be graded on a rubric divided between the following parameters as per the percentages given alongside them:

1. Participation (in classes, office hours, and the weekly blog): 30%

2. Research paper (a longform argumentative paper with citations, written in academic style): 30%

3. Small summative written assignments (including a literature review mid-term) : 20%

4. Presentations in class (including a group-based semester-end Debate): 20%

Attendance Policy

For this course, you are allowed three unexcused absences (for which you do not need permission from the instructor) and two excused absences (for which you do need permission from the instructor). The penalty for any absence beyond these five will be decided by the ICT instructor on a case-by-case basis. Please note that a consistent pattern of non-attendance may include discretionary penalties such as grade cuts.
Introduction to Critical Thinking [CT-0001] [CT-0001-3]

Introduction to Critical Thinking [CT-0001] [CT-0001-4]

Faculty Name
Sidharth Singh [sidharth.singh@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

We will develop across the length of a semester, a discursive answer to a simple yet fundamental question: what is poetry? The objective of this class is not to simply interpret individual poems (though this will form part of our activity). Instead we will try and determine the ways by which a satisfactory answer to such a question may be figured out at all. The task is one of figuring out a successful definition, and in this process we will devise methods to reliably identify and study the fundamental constituents of any poem. Two such constituents, for example, are language and mind, and so we will explore ideas in the philosophy of these objects to develop an acceptable answer to our question.

As we progress you will learn and practice via exercises, some elementary aspects of logic (such as the meaning of an argument, paraphrasing to clarify and juudge and argument, and the way to describe abstract entities), and decide for yourself whether they are anywhere useful for questions about the nature and philosophy of art. Other fixed aspects of the course include discussions on the philosophy of scientific methods, the nature of human creativity and language; group discussions on the interpretation of poems; and, given this is a writing course, the composition of several essays in response to questions about ideas discussed in class.

You will find that typical academic activities will have to follow naturally for you to develop an answer. These activities include navigating citations and bibliographies; organizing your thoughts by writing essays; and relying on peers for aid and discussion. In large part, however, the trajectory of the course will be decided by collective student effort and the progress made in developing an answer to the stated question. To this end, the syllabus remains flexible and secondary, and is only one means for our progress in discovery and learning. 

Given the nature of the endeavour and the direction this class typically takes, students interested in humanistic disciplines are encouraged to join but so are those who are interested in areas typically allied to the cognitive sciences (biology, computer science, linguistics, mathematics, philosophy, psychology). In any case there are no pre-requisites at all, so regardless of disciplinary leanings, anyone may join and productively engage. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Syllabus

All texts will be provided to students either as print outs in class or as PDFs before class (uploaded to a shared drive). Modules on introductory logic will not be studied via texts. As mentioned above, this is a fairly flexible syllabus with guaranteed additions. But in one way or another, we will be touching on ideas from these following texts.

Essays and Book excerpts:

David Hume- ‘Of the Standard of Taste’

Immanuel Kant – ‘What is Enlightenment’

John Dewey—Art as Experience

Karl Marx – ‘Theses on Feuerbach’/ The German Ideology

Noam Chomsky—What Kind of Creatures Are We?

Samuel Taylor Coleridge—Notes on Shakespeare/Biographia Literaria

Viktor Shklovsky—'Art as Device’

Wilhelm Von Humboldt—Limits of State Action

William Wordsworth- ‘Preface to the Lyrical Ballads’

It will be necessary for students to read some of this material before class. However, in some cases discussions in class should suffice if one cannot read the texts.

Poems:

Mostly selections from Lyrical Ballads, and other English poetry. Since the endeavour of this class is a general explanation of poetry, students are free to suggest poems for everyone to read.

Novel:

Mary Shelley—Frankenstein. Students will have to review this novel for their mid term assignment.

Grading Rubric

The ICT will be graded on a number of elements. Your final assessment will account for your participation and performance in writing and non-writing components, and in formative work (building towards a bigger piece, or continuing a specific ‘habit’) and summative work (producing a final output). The components are below. 

1. Participation (in classes, meetings and peer work)

2. Regular Assignments 

3. Group Discussion 

4. A mid-term assignment of 800-1200 words.

5. An end-term Academic essay of 2500 words

A standard Ashoka rubric will be used in your eventual ICT grade, wherein the highest possible grade is ‘A’ and the lowest possible grade is ‘F’.In general, grades in the ‘A’ range demonstrate that you have consistently exceeded the expectations of the course; grades in the ‘B’ range indicate that you have met the expectations for the course; grades in the ‘C’ range and below, demonstrate that you have fallen short of the expectations for this course.

Attendance Policy

Typically I do not take attendance. However, you will have peer tutors assigned for this course. Missing more than two sessions with them will cause a 5 mark penalty.

Introduction to Critical Thinking [CT-0001] [CT-0001-5]

Faculty Name
Rashmi Muraleedhar [rashmi.muraleedhar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The Introduction to Critical Thinking offers you different pathways to develop your habits of thinking and communication through reading, writing and research. It considers these as essential habits that can be strengthened through repetition. The aim of this course is to expose you to source materials and themes that will provoke you to think deeply, ask questions that extend and enrich your understanding, and use writing as a means of making sense of the world. By the close of the course, you will have a keener sense of your own challenges and strengths as a writer and student, and a more robust sense of what it means to belong to a knowledge community constituted by your peers.

Learning Outcomes

Reading:

1. Breaking down texts into identifiable parts.

2. Making patterns and connections across texts

3. Building reading stamina and the ability to select texts

4. Understanding textual context, genre and source material

Writing 

1. Developing the craft of outlining, revising, editing

2. Applying form, voice, style, tone to affect writing

3. Developing logical, coherent, structured writing

4.  Producing different kinds of writing (narrative, argumentative etc)

Research

1. Narrowing down a curiosity into a question

2. Identifying credible sources for study

3. Reflecting on  method and organising the research process

4. Handling multiple sources or an archive

Communication

1. Aiming for confidence, clarity, coherence in speaking

2. Practising and harnessing audience engagement 

3. Developing active and respectful listening to others 

4. Engaging meaningfully with ongoing discussions

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Semester-long Writing Project 

Each of you is working on developing a well-researched, organized and articulated argument through the semester. In this semester-long writing project, you’re working towards writing an academic argumentative essay in staggered phases. In the first half of the semester, you will be working on a literature review for the topic you’ve selected. 

In the second half of the semester, you will be extending your literature review into an argumentative essay. Things I’m looking for in this writing project:

i. Comprehension – How well do you understand the assignment?

ii. Depth/Breadth of Research – How informed is your perspective on the topic?

iii. Organization/Structure of ideas – How coherently have you been able to order, develop and build out your ideas in your writing?

iv. Personal voice – How much of yourself do you see in your writing?

Semester-long Group Creative Project

For this assignment, students are expected to engage with their surroundings in groups and partake in an exercise of exploration, engagement and creative thinking while locating themselves as students in Delhi. The idea of this project is different from the other semester-long writing project (the argumentative essay), as the focus is on creative storytelling.

In this effort, you will be presenting a story of Delhi through your group’s particular lens.

There are several ways of interpreting ‘story of Delhi’, and I leave it up to each group to figure out the approach of their choice. I want this story of Delhi to be informed by actual visits to Delhi by each member in the group. I leave it up to you how you would like to organize these visits – whether as a group together, or in smaller groups or some combination thereof.

The final submission for this assignment will be unwritten - I’ve generally put it under the category of ‘presentation’. You’re however not limited to making a formal speech with PowerPoint slides. Your group is expected to present this story to the Class in the last week of the semester. The progress through the project is also staggered across the following steps, and the Peer Tutor will guide you through each phase.

Grading Rubric

Semester Break-up:

The ICT will be graded on student work across several components, listed below:

1. Participation – 20%

  • Participating in class discussions, Office Hours with me (5%) and the Peer Tutor (5%), in-class group work

2. Short assignments and Class blog– 10%

  • Smaller summative assignments, weekly homework, outlines, drafts, Class Reflection blog entries

3. Mid-Term: Literature Review – 20%

  • A longform synthesis paper written in academic style, 1000 words, APA style of citations

4. End-Term: Argumentative Academic Essay – 30%

  • A longform argumentative essay written in academic style, 2000 words, APA style of citations

5. Presentations – 20%

  • Individual (5%)
  • Group (15%)
Attendance Policy

This course does not have a minimum attendance requirement but operates on an honour-code with regards to absences. Students will need to communicate the reasons for their absences to the PT and instructor, and will be expected to keep up with the material discussed in class through the Peer Tutor or your classmates.

Faculty Name
Kundan Sen [kundan.sen@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The Introduction to Critical Thinking offers you different pathways to develop your habits of thinking and communication through reading, writing and research. It considers these as essential habits that can be strengthened through repetition. The aim of this course is to expose you to source materials and themes that aim to examine popular culture in a manner that will provoke you to think deeply, ask questions that extend and enrich your understanding, and use writing as a means of making sense of the world.

This specific course aims to achieve these outcomes through the theme Deconstructing Popular Culture. During the course, you will begin by questioning what it means to study the amorphous term 'culture'. You will be introduced to various material societal concerns, including but not limited to gender, caste, class, ideology, hegemony, globalisation, the attention economy. Over the course, you will examine your encounters with the above concerns through your engagement with popular culture: What does Charli XCX’s album Brat tell us about the economy? How can a
game of football be viewed as an ideological exercise? What does a walk around Hauz Khas Village tell us about gentrification? How does caste shape representations of the city in cinema? Through these questions and several others, you will not just establish a critical approach to popular culture, but sharpen your skills of reading, writing and research.

By the close of the course, you will have a keener sense of your own challenges and strengths as a writer and student, and a more robust sense of what it means to belong to a knowledge community constituted by your peers.

You do not need to have any specific kind of training in order to do an ICT course. Nor is any ICT course geared towards preparing you specifically for a career in a particular subject or field. Rather, you can expect it to guide you in transition out of how you approached academic work in school to how you might approach it in a university setting, and to sharpen your understanding of what it means to be critical, questioning and deliberate in your approach to the world.

You will also need to rehearse regular habits of reading (of academic texts and wider materials) and responding (to prompts, or given materials). Finally, as the ICT is a small cohort-oriented course, you can expect it to have a strong participation and interaction component, and can expect to work on projects both individually and in collaboration with your coursemates.

For this course, you are allowed three unexcused absences (for which you do not need permission from the instructor) and two excused absences (for which you do need permission from the instructor). The penalty for any absence beyond these five will be decided by the ICT instructor on a case-by-case basis. Please note that a consistent pattern of non-attendance may include discretionary penalties such as grade cuts.

If you are absent, the responsibility for making up for what has been missed -- by looking at class notes and/or speaking to classmates -- is yours. The responsibility for finding out about any homework that has been set for future classes is yours too.

Faculty Name
Chinmoy Saikia [chinmoy.saikia@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course will attempt to make the students think at lenght about a number of cultural valiues of our times and how they've shaped our aesthetic, political, and social preferences. The "democratisation" of taste and its subsequent commodification, for instance, will be one theme. Here, we will look at art objects and take note of the various "ways of seeing" even as we try to understand the limits of the suppossed "infinite variety" of "seeing". We will see how canons form and how they are and dismantled. We will attempt to think critically, always in the context of a looming climate crisis, about the stories we have begun to tell ourselves of late.

You will also need to rehearse regular habits of reading (of academic texts and wider materials) and responding (to prompts, or given materials). Finally, as the ICT is a small cohort-oriented course, you can expect it to have a strong participation and interaction component, and can expect to work on projects both individually and in collaboration with your coursemates.

Rather, you can expect it to guide you in transition out of how you approached academic work in school to how you might approach it in a university setting, and to sharpen your understanding of what it means to be critical, questioning and deliberate in your approach to the world.

The ICT will be graded on a number of elements. Your final assessment will account for your participation and performance in writing and non-writing components, and in formative work (building towards a bigger piece, or continuing a specific ‘habit’) and summative work (producing a final output). 

 

The components are below. 

 

1. Participation (in class as well as in meetings with the instructor and the peer tutor): 12-15% of the final grade.

2. Regular Assignments. 15-20% of the final grade. 

3. Presentations: 12-15% of the final grade. 

4. A mid-term assignment of 800-1500 words involving the synthesis of multiple sources: 20% of the final grade. 

5. An end-term Academic essay of 1500 - 2500 words : 30-35% of the final grade. 

A standard Ashoka rubric will be used in your eventual ICT grade, wherein the highest possible grade is ‘A’ and the lowest possible grade is ‘F’.In general, grades in the ‘A’ range demonstrate that you have consistently exceeded the expectations of the course; grades in the ‘B’ range indicate that you have met the expectations for the course; grades in the ‘C’ range and below, demonstrate that you have fallen short of the expectations for this course.

You are allowed five absences in the semester. The penalty for any absence beyond these five will be decided on a case-by-case basis. Please note that a consistent pattern of non-attendance may include discretionary penalties such as grade cuts.

 

If you are absent, the responsibility for making up for what has been missed -- by looking at class notes and/or speaking to classmates -- is yours. The responsibility for finding out about any homework that has been set for future classes is yours too.

Introduction to Critical Thinking [CT-0001] [CT-0001-17]

Faculty Name
Aditya Vikram Shrivastava [aditya.shrivastava@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The Introduction to Critical Thinking offers you different ways to develop your habits of thinking and communication through reading, writing and research. We will also work on refining them by repetition. 

This course engages with narratives that are haunted. You can expect bereaved mothers, searching daughters, looted trains, lost manifestos, and even the spirits of the dispossessed, to flit in and out of our classroom. We shall have the joy of being charmed by these ghosts, present and absent, in fiction, cinema, essays, and research papers, most of which are haunted by, or keep haunting our social, political, and literary imagination. We would exhume some dead questions, raise new ones, and visit the pressing issues of our times alongside them, to think deeply about what haunts our personal realities. 

The aim of this course is to expose you to archives and ideas that will provoke you to ask questions that widen and complicate your understanding, and use reading and writing as a means of making sense of the world in critical ways. By the end of the course, you will have to produce an essay that speaks of haunting in layered, articulate ways.

You are going to gain a keener sense of your own challenges and strengths as a writer and student, and a more robust sense of what it means to belong to a knowledge community constituted by your peers.

Learning Outcomes

Reading: breaking down texts into identifiable parts; making patterns and connections across texts; building reading stamina and the ability to select texts; understanding context, genre and source material

Writing: developing the craft of outlining, revising, editing; applying form, voice, style, tone to affect writing; developing logical, coherent, structured writing; producing different kinds of writing (narrative, argumentative etc.)

Research: narrowing down a curiosity into a question; identifying credible sources for study; reflecting on method and organizing the research process; handling multiple sources or an archive

Communication: aiming for confidence, clarity, coherence in speaking; practicing and harnessing audience engagement; developing active and respectful listening to others; engaging meaningfully with ongoing discussions

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

1. Class Participation (attendance, regular participation, debates, play reading, worksheets): 15%

2. Ghostly Matters (weekly journal): 10%

3. Street Haunting (a podcast submission): 15%

4. Midterm Essay (an exercise in portraiture): 20%

5. Presentation (formulating a research question): 10%

6. Final Essay (comparative analysis of a text against its archive): 30%

Grading Rubric

The highest possible grade is ‘A’ and the lowest possible grade is ‘F’. Grades in the ‘A’ range demonstrate that you have consistently exceeded the expectations of the course; grades in the ‘B’ range indicate that you have met the expectations for the course; grades in the ‘C’ range and below, demonstrate that you have fallen short of the expectations for this course.

Attendance Policy

You are allowed three unexcused absences (for which you do not need permission from me) and two excused absences (for which you must obtain permission beforehand). I shall decide the penalty for any absence beyond these five on a case-by-case basis. A consistent pattern of non-attendance may include penalties such as grade cuts.

If you are absent, the responsibility for making up for what has been missed -- by looking at class notes and/or speaking to classmates -- is yours. The responsibility for finding out about any homework that has been set for future classes is yours too.

Introduction to Critical Thinking [CT-0001] [CT-0001-19]

Faculty Name
Rukmini Bhuyan [rukmini.bhuyan@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Introduction to Critical Thinking offers you different pathways to develop your habits of thinking and communication through reading, writing and research. The aim of this course is to introduce you to subjects that will prompt you to think deeply, ask questions that develop and enrich your understanding, and to use writing as a means to explore, interpret and reflect upon the world around us.

This ICT course draws inputs from debate pedagogy to engage in critical thought and argumentation. Titled "Four Debates”, the course revolves around four questions that challenge us to think deeply about ideas that hold significance to our lives. The questions that will guide our readings, debates and writing in this course are as follows:

-Is there a true selfless act?

-Can the privileged be true allies?

-Does objective beauty exist?

-Can love be an act of will?

These questions aim to provoke thoughtful inquiry and engagement with some fundamental dilemmas of human existence. Together, we will explore how these questions (and their answers) can intersect with everyday realities.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

There is no coursebook for this reading. The material will be formed by readings. We will engage with the philosophies of Jean Jacque Rousseau, Immanuel Kant, David Hume and Jean-Paul Sartre, among others. The material will also include readings of a more contemporary nature that will substantiate the larger philosophical discussions to engage on the questions of our course in an interdisciplinary manner, bringing in studies on biology, psychology and media studies. Additionally, cinema and films will form a distinct section of the material for this course. The material will be provided at the beginning of the semester before classes begin

Grading Rubric

There are six assignments for assessment and grading in this course:

-The final assessment will be a long-form argumentative essay focused on the course topics. During the course, student will write two shorter drafts for feedback on two distinct topics. They will then choose one draft to revise and submit as their final essay. This will make 25 percent of the final grade.

-The mid-term assessment will require students to answer a set of questions. It will be completed in class. The mid-term will assess the key topics covered up to that point in the course. This will make 25 percent of the final grade.

-Class participation will be assessed across class debates. Students will participate in these debates throughout the course. This will make up 15 percent of the grade.

-Short Writing Exercise will involve classes where students watch cinema and complete writing exercises afterward. These exercises will be based on the material viewed in class. This will make up 15 percent of the grade.

-Habit-Forming Exercise will be performed at the end of each week. Students will complete these exercises to reinforce course material. This will make up 10 percent of the grade. 

-Presentation Exercise will involve students individually presenting an argumentative topic. The emphasis is on argumentation, and no PowerPoints are allowed. This will form 10 percent of the grade.

Attendance Policy

For this course, you are allowed three unexcused absences (for which you do not need permission from the instructor) and two excused absences (for which you do need permission from the instructor). The penalty for any absence beyond these five will be decided by the ICT instructor on a case-by-case basis. Please note that a consistent pattern of non-attendance may include discretionary penalties such as grade cuts.

courseTitle: From Sound to Music to Song: Introduction to Songwriting
description:
From Sound to Music to Song: Introduction to Songwriting [CPA-0048] [CPA-0048-1]

Faculty Name
Chayan Adhikari [chayan.adhikari@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

I don’t sing because I’m happy ; I’m happy because I sing - William James

Music has the power to move us – it can bring us comfort, reduce us to tears or it can be
the soundtrack to our most memorable moments. Making music can feel intimidating but,
just likeany other skill, it is possible to learn, practice and become fluent in it. Anyone
who wishes to tella story can be a songwriter - a musical storyteller.
A melange of sounds and silences is what makes music ; both of which we have easy and
abundant access to, if we so choose. One doesn’t always need access to musical
instruments or a band to start making music, it can be done with simply what is available -
our voices, our bodies as instruments and sounds found around us! Think of acapella, body
percussion and choral based artists and groups like - the pentatonix, rockapella, stomp,
the blueman group - or even the works of experimental composers like John Cage!
In this course, using our voice, bodies and commonly found objects as sources of sound,
we will learn to create rhythms, soundscapes and original musical pieces. Through group
exercises, we will explore the art of choral singing focusing on blending voices,
harmonising, pitch accuracy, ear training, and vocal coordination. We will also learn about
the core components of music making- rhythm and melody, chords, structure, and
arrangement. We will apply these concepts to write and perform musical pieces as small
and large ensembles.
Whether this is your first time engaging with music or one of many, this course could offer
alternative approaches to developing your musicianship.

The criteria for grading are the following: attendance, participation in class, and a creative project/ assignment determined by the Professor. All three criteria are equal.

As the classes are highly participative in nature, more than 2 absences will affect your grade.

Philosophy of Science [PHI-2240/ PSY-3162] [PHI-2240/ PSY-3162-1]

Faculty Name
Alexander Iain Siantonas [alexander.siantonas@ashoka.edu.in] ,Rhea [rhea_tf@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Much human effort is expended on the enterprise we call ‘science’, on the assumption that it allows us to understand, and perhaps manipulate, the world. But what, if anything, might justify this assumption? What’s so special about this enterprise anyway? Such are the questions we explore in the philosophy of science. This course will begin with some of the intellectual roots of what we now call science, in thinkers such as Aristotle and Francis Bacon (not the artist, though we may also mention Roger Bacon). Then we will review the ideas of four crucial 20th century figures: Karl Popper, Thomas Kuhn, Paul Feyerabend, and Imre Lakatos. Finally, we will explore a range of an assortment of topics such as whether electrons are real, whether the failure of past theories gives us reason to doubt the best theories of today, and what the relationship between knowledge and science might be.

Principles of Science [FC-0801] [FC-0801-1]

Faculty Name
Sourav Pal [sourav.pal@ashoka.edu.in] ,Vidya Dnyaneshwar Avasare [vidya.avasare@ashoka.edu.in] ,Damanpreet Kaur [damanpreet_phd24@ashoka.edu.in] ,Tanvi Jain [tanvi.jain_asp25@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

 

Course description:

This course throws a light on the principles of science and central role of chemistry in science. Historically, chemistry has been focusing on the variation of matter, their properties and how these matters can undergo interesting chemical transformations. The intriguing chemical and physical properties of these matters attract the attention of scientific community. Chemistry has been the building block of matters, small to large. Materials at different length scales will be addressed and how different pedagogies can explain matter at varying length scales

Therefore, in this course, we will discuss about principles of science involved in the deeper understanding of matters (from quantum dots to supramolecular arrangements) at different length scales.

Focus will be on concepts and units of lengths, change of paradigm and pedagogy as small molecules become larger molecules, polymers, biomolecules, transition from quantum mechanics to classical mechanics at a pedagogical level. General principles of thermodynamics and kinetics will be highlighted as basic principles of science.

At a chemical length scale, periodic table of elements, their electronic structure and properties, introduction to organic chemistry as a great utility in science from building blocks of life to renewable energy, healthcare, medicines, and materials with value-addition in society will be discussed to understand logic of chemical reactivity.

Learning Outcomes

Learning Outcome: Principles of Science as related to the fundamentals of chemistry and use of these in day-to-day life

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Reading materials/ Lecture notes to be shared

Total 300 Marks ( to be scaled to 100)

Endsem- 90

Midesm-  90

Quiz-       45

Assignments- 45

Model making- 15

Attendance- 15

Attendance Policy

As in the rubric.

Principles of Science [FC-0801] [FC-0801-2]

Faculty Name
Mayank Garg [mayank.garg@ashoka.edu.in] ,Anurag Agrawal [anurag.agrawal@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The principles of science manifest themselves in different ways in different domains of science, but a few things remain constant, namely the scientific method. In the scientific method, we look for internal and external inconsistencies in our models, ensuring that our beliefs are coherent within themselves (internal) and with available data (external). Health is an extremely important subject, relevant to each one of us individually and as a society, but is far more subjective than say physics or maths, where we can speak of fundamental laws of the universe that exist independent of us. Principles of health science teach us about the scientific method, but also about ourselves as a species and society, going beyond the natural sciences. Even used in the restricted context of human health, the meaning changes from birth to death, from past to present, and even from culture to culture. This course provides a view of sccientific thinking in health from multiple lenses, including physiology, digital technology, medical history, and sociology. I hope that this will serve as a model of how to scientifically analyze ‘wicked’ interdisciplinary topics where neither the questions, nor the answers, are well-defined. We will cover the following topics in the context of health:

a) The four paradigms of science: theoretical, experimental, computational simulation driven by theory and experiment, and  lastly discovery from big observational data.  For example, at different stages of human history, how would we differently think about risk of tuberculosis.

b) The disruptive effect of technologies. For example, how did germ theory and microscopes change the field of infectious diseases and public health

c) How to ask a good scientific question. For example, what are the many questions inside "How do we eradicate tuberculosis"?

d) Last, but not least, we will talk about how to go about finding an answer for a well stated question. 

A sub-theme in this course will be the future of health in a digital age, where the fourth paradigm is starting to become operational, disruptive technologies like GenAI are present, but we need to do better in terms of asking the right questions and working across disciplines to answer them. 

Learning Outcomes

Learning how to think scientifically and ask questions, and in the process learn the value of scientific thinking about health, towards better health

Faculty Name
Amrita Narayanan [amrita.narayanan@ashoka.edu.in] ,Rohit Rajak [rohit.rajak_tf@ashoka.edu.in] ,Yamini Krishnan [yamini.krishnan_tf@ashoka.edu.in] ,Yamini Krishnan [yamini.krishnan_asp22@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

We all narrate ourselves to ourselves, it’s a process that helps us make our way about the world coherently. Yet, our own biography, realistically put, is confining. We can only tell stories about ourselves using the tropes of stories we have heard, and within the limits of our available language. Reading literature allows us access to wide-ranging lives and selves beyond our own self-narrative. Literature also opens up the possibilities of language to describe the experience of the self as it encounters the world. Our course will consider how fictional works from around the world and across time mirror real world complexities: growing-up, falling in love, being happy, having sex, being faithful, losing a friend, losing a way of life and facing death. We will learn to think about books as dreams, understanding how stories change via the shifting question “Whose dream is it?”.  Over the semester we will entertain the idea that fictional characters and books mirror crucial real world-viewpoints, that books mirror each other, and that if a literary work can mirror the reality of living in the world, then perhaps our lives are more fictional than we think.

Learning Outcomes

1. Students will learn how to understand the arguement that is being made by a book or character

2. Students will learn how to re-tell a story from the perspective of another character by shifting the question "Who's dream is it"

3. Student will understand and be able to articulate what constitutes "evidence" in a literary paper.

4. Students will be able to articulate how literature deepens the reader's understanding of psychological themes.

Overview

Literature is an art of storytelling. But can storytelling bring about revolutions? Is it possible for stories to stand up against colonial abuse, fight prejudices, bring social change, impact public policy? In this course, we will talk about stories that did exactly that and did it so spectacularly that generations have remained in awe of them. We will read novels, short stories, memoirs and essays to discover that each of these works of art were responsible for protesting against the injustices of their times. And in doing so, they highlighted and gave voice to the wrongs and discriminations of today. At the heart of each of these stories, we will encounter a fierce rejection of dogma and a stubborn insistence to speak out.

Faculty Name

Overview

“Difficult Loves”

This course seeks to reflect on care and love both conceptually and experientially. What does it mean to love and care for oneself and for others? What allows us to love and care? What prevents us from caring and loving ourselves and others? What forces—personal, interpersonal, or collective and communal—regulate, prescribe and even prohibit experiences and expressions of love. As the narrator in Arundhati Roy’s The God of Small Things poignantly reflects, such questions are older than any conception we might have of “history,” and comprise at times unspoken and often unwritten “Love Laws” that determine who can be loved, how and how much.

Our primary goal in the course is to work towards developing a critical and comprehensive language around understanding care and love as the basis for any and all configurations of relationalities that both make and unmake our senses of being in the world. Beginning our journey with selections from The Symposium by Plato, verses from the Gatha Sattasai, and poetry from the Akam repertoire of Sangam literature, we will make our way through more contemporary iterations and meditations on caring and loving such as, Roland Barthes’ A Lover’s Discourse and Ocean Vuong’s On Earth We Are Briefly Gorgeous. All along the way we will be reflecting on and attempting to problematize “traditional” and “normative” structures within which care and love are usually understood and experienced.

Overview

Great Books: Satirical Animals

From the birds of Aristophanes’ Cloudcuckooland to Perumal Murugan’s goat Poonachi, animals have served as a vehicle for satire across cultures and time periods, often as mirrors reflecting societal absurdities, moral failings, human grotesqueness, and political struggles. In this Great Books course, we will get acquainted with some of these satirical animals. We will encounter them as symbols, moral agents, political figures, and detached narrators. This course will, in keeping with the ethos of Foundations courses, familiarize students with methods from the different disciplines of philosophy, history, and literature: we will learn to read closely and critically, identify and respond to arguments, appropriately situate a work in its socio-historical context, and compare texts and ideas from different moments in time and space. By investigating how animals have been portrayed in fables, allegories, and novels, you will gain a deeper understanding of the power of satire in challenging conventions and provoking thought on human nature and society. And, hopefully, it goes without saying, we will also laugh — sometimes until we’re in tears.

  • The Birds [414 BCE], Aristophanes

  • The Story of Reynard the Fox (Le Roman de Renart) [12th century CE], selected tales

In his Discourse on the Method, the philosopher Rene Descartes wrote that conversing with people of past centuries is rather like travelling. In this assessment, you will work in pre-assigned groups of 4-5 to create a short ‘time traveller’s guidebook’ to be shared with the entire class. Imagine you’re writing for someone time-traveling to ancient Rome or medieval India, for example. What are some key facts you think they’ll need to know to orient themselves? You can get as creative with the format as you’d like. You can do this for any of the periods/cultures we’re covering, but please sign up by the second week of classes to avoid clustering. Introduction to Performance Studies [ENG-2610/ PA-2610/ ENG-4610] [ENG-2610/ PA-2610/ ENG-4610-1]

Faculty Name
Vivek Venkitaraman Narayan [v.v.narayan@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sanya Sharma [sanya.sharma_asp25@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Is everyday life a performance? Are our social interactions forms of playacting? How about the ways in which we present ourselves—as gendered bodies, as students, as friends, as professors, and as so many other less nameable identities—are these too performances? What would it tell us if we were to think of everyday social interaction and self-presentation as performance? Does this mean our interactions are shallow, our relationships fake, and our personalities mere pretense? Or will it reveal aspects of everyday life that otherwise remain hidden in plain view?   

These are some questions that inspire this course to explore the social phenomenon of performance and its theoretical value to the humanities. We will investigate the ways in which our everyday behaviours and the stories we tell shape our identities and our experience of the world. We will see how thinking of, with, and through performance can help us investigate social behaviour, individual and collective identity, and embodied knowledge. 

We will do so by focusing on three recurring themes: first, the relationship between representation and performance, which will help us understand social behaviour; second, the paradigm of performativity, which is significant to theorizing identity; and third, the debate between whether performance is an ephemeral or enduring phenomenon, which is central to conceptualizing embodied knowledges. We will see, in short, how performance—as object, method, and analytic—can help us understand societies and cultures by focusing on acts of doing, ways of being, and modes of knowing. We will read Judith Butler, JL Austin, Diana Taylor, Richard Schechner, Susan Sontag, Harry Elam, Victor Turner, Bishnupriya Dutt, Erving Goffman, Clifford Geertz, Aparna Dharwadker, Ngugi wa Thiong’o, and Paulla Ebron. We will also engage with Dharamvir Bharati’s Andha Yug, Maya Rao’s Walk, and the real-life cases of Rachel Dolezal and Jessica Krug. 

(Undergrads may sign up for ENG-2610 or PA-2610, while grads are welcome to sign up for ENG-4610.)

Overview

This course seeks to examine the autobiography or memoir as a literary genre, an historical archive, and an individual/community narrative.

We will also consider how graphic novels, poems and blogs can be seen as constructions of a specific kind of persona.

As the definition of autobiography has expanded over time, different kinds of memoirs and autobiographies have liberated Identity as a singular noun to self-consciously manage our plural or even desired identities and playfully experiment with different notions of selfhood.

 

In this course, we will examine the idea of “truth telling” that is often associated with autobiographies. We also consider how the study of international autobiographies allows us a view of the local in the context of the global.

Learning Outcomes

Learn about the genre of autobiography.

See the historical development and change in the form and content of  autobiography.

Explore the diverse cultural contexts in which autobiographies are produced.

Question why autobiographies are written.

Overview

A rough set of topics is provided in the syllabus, but we can explore really any other system that people are interested in. Every week, one class will involve teaching, and the other will involve discussion and presentations. Faculty Name

Overview

CHM 1501- Topics in Chemistry     Spring 2025

Vidya Avasare and Sourav Pal

 

Chemistry is the study of interacting electrons and how these interactions give rise to a variety of chemical entities and materials that are vital to society, from renewable energy to healthcare. Historically, chemistry has been focusing on the variation of matter, properties of the periodic table, and how chemical transformation takes place, and that variation is reflected in a great variety of subjects. The topics in chemistry will explore the role of electrons, as explained by quantum principles, and how electron interactions are crucial in the transformation of substances. This includes understanding complex organic reactions and predicting their reactivity and stereochemistry. Overview

The purpose in this course is to familiarize students with significant domains of social science theory that help us think critically about relationships between media, culture, and society. We will discuss some of the seminal sociological, anthropological, political, as well as literary and other writings that influence contemporary understandings about media and its dialectical interventions with self and society. The course is structured in a manner that enables a sense of the historical flows– and disruptions– of these ideas. Our intention is not to learn theory but to use theory from a range of interdisciplinary domains to learn about media and our world in present times. 

Learning Outcomes

Over the semester, we will think about: 

1. Conceptual introductions

2. Marx and Media

3. Cultural Theory/ Postcolonialism 

4. Symbolic Interaction/ Structuration 

5. Gender and Media

6. Postmodernism/ Information Theory/ Surveillance

7. Anthropology of Media

Grading Rubric

The course is discussion and project based and your success in it depends on your commitment to complete required readings, critically reflect on them, participate in class discussions, and thoughtfully integrate these insights in your short assignments, midterm paper and final project. The reading selections for each week may range between 50 to 75 pages.  

Grading will be based on:  

Class participation (15 points): Students are expected to expected to attend classes regularly, read circulated materials and contribute in an informed manner to discussions. Please note that missing lectures and discussion sessions will significantly impact your class participation points.

Five short assignments (35 points):  

The first short assignment (5 points) is to introduce yourself in 250-300 words. What is your academic background and what have been your reading/ viewing interests? What interests/ excites/ disturbs you about the world? What do you hope to get out of this class? The first assignment should be uploaded on GC before the first class, latest by 5 PM on January 20.  

The remaining four short assignments (7.5 points each) are discussion board posts/ presentations. Students will submit a critical review/ reflection on GC of the assigned readings for the sections they sign up for (an online form will be circulated by your TF/ TA). The discussion board posts will not exceed 500 words each.  Discussion board posts are due LATEST by 5pm on the day before class, so as to allow adequate time for everyone to read them. You may choose key points that strike you in the readings (make sure that you engage with most if not all of the readings for those weeks) and discuss them in relation to broader course themes. Please read the posts of your peers before attending class,  to enable more fruitful discussions which your group will anchor. Posts will be submitted/ discussed in batches at the end of weeks 3, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12. This means that you can choose not to post for readings of up to 2 sections out of these given 6 sections.

Midterm examination (25 points): will be a take home examination where you will answer a prompt that will be put up on GC. The question will test your understanding of concepts discussed in class and ability to use/ relate them with lived contexts. Answer scripts should be uploaded on GC in both word and PDF formats by the mentioned deadline. 

End Term Group Project & Presentation (25 points): will continue your work throughout the semester in exploring different theoretical and empirical perspectives on the nature of entanglements between media, culture and society. A brief initial proposal for each final project will be discussed by the group with me; progressive feedback will be given subsequently in office hours. Final projects will engage theoretically with different sections of the course but its creative forms can be diverse. They may include work on empirical research projects, a podcast, a webpage, short films or multimedia projects etc. The research subject/ form must be discussed and approved by me. After the presentation, your final revised end term project should be uploaded on GC in both word and PDF formats by deadline, with links to anything else you wish us to review.

Faculty Name
Krishna Venkata Melnattur [krishna.melnattur@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sandeep Ameta [sandeep.ameta@ashoka.edu.in] ,Faizal Khan [faizal.khan_phd24@ashoka.edu.in] ,Rahul Kumar [rahul.kumar_phd22@ashoka.edu.in] ,Tanushree Sinha [tanushree.sinha_phd24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course aims to teach students the basic concepts of Cell Biology and Genetics.  In the first module (by Sandeep Ameta), students will be taught the concepts and experiments for Forward Genetics by subjecting microorganisms to harsh environmental conditions and observing the phenotypes. The second module complements the first module by focusing on reverse genetics using the classic eukaryotic model system – Drosophila. The course will provide students with a basic understanding and hands-on experience in handling, manipulating, and investigating cell-biology problems using genetic tools. Importantly, this is a discovery-based course, students will not simply replicate known results, but instead actively participate in generating new knowledge. The goal is to stimulate students’ interest in life sciences through inquiry-based learning. In the process, students will also advance their understanding of the field more broadly.

Learning Outcomes

During this course, the students will learn:

  • Handling/ culturing/ growth of Pseudomonas or E. coli.
  • Forward genetics screen / Random mutagenesis and isolation of conditional mutants in Pseudomonas or E. coli.
  • Exposure/ handling of Drosophila as a model organism 
  • Understanding basic genetics – dominant vs recessive markers, autosomal vs sex linked inheritance.
  • Use of balancer chromosomes, design of crossing schemes,  crossing flies
  • Use of bipartite expression systems (e.g. GAL4/ UAS) to manipulate genes, reverse genetics using RNAi
  • Qualitative and quantitative analysis of behaviour including appropriate graphic visualisation, and statistics
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Knowledge of basic cell biology, microbiology and bacterial genetics will help. Examples of some good textbooks: ‘Genetics’ by Russell, ‘Genes’ by Levin et al, ‘Molecular Genetics’ by Stent
