International History [IR-1010] [IR-1010-1]

Faculty Name
Nayan Ranjan Chanda [nayan.chanda@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

In this course, we will analyze the major events of the Cold War through the prism of three analytical lenses: interests, individuals, and ideology. We will attempt to evaluate the extent to which each of these factors, either singly, or in combination, affected decision making on inter-state relations during the decades of the Cold War.

Secondly, the course will also highlight how the progression of the Cold War decades also witnessed the making of deeper inter-connections across the globe. For example, we will consider how the distant developments of the Cold War were also of relevance in shaping India’s position in the world. Furthermore, we will examine how the developments of the Cold War were equally shaped, not just by the superpowers, but also by smaller, poorer, and recently decolonized countries. Enabling an evaluation of why developments unfolded in the way that they did during the Cold War, therefore, the course will show how the appraisal of events from more than a single point of view, is necessary to understand the impact of the Cold War more fully on present day international politics.

Finally, we will also explore the newer directions of the historiography on the Cold War, including the ways in which its debates influenced popular culture and the international perceptions of technological aid. Ultimately, we will ask, in what ways can our analysis of the Cold War help us in shaping our present day understanding of the conduct of international affairs in the present?

Overview

In this course, we will discuss the important concepts in Mechanism Design, Auction Theory, and Matching Theory. This course will be a mixture of theory and applications. In the theory part, We will cover the formulations and fundamental results. Specifically, we will discuss concepts such as revelation principle, implementation of mechanisms, incentive compatibility. We will cover the standard auction settings and revenue analysis. Finally, we discuss different types of matching settings and the fundamental Gale-Shapley algorithm. 

For the applications part, we will have in-depth discussions about real life applications where this theory have been used. We will focus on three applications: (1) Spectrum Auctions, in which the government auctions the electromagnetic spectrum (bandwidth) to the highest bidding cellular companies, (2) Sponsored Search Auctions, in which companies like Google auctions the advertisement spots to firms for each search query of the consumer, (3) Kidney Exchange problem in which Kidney donor-receiver pairs are matched while satisfying the compatibility restrictions. 

Some of the discussion about applications will be part of the student presentations.

Learning Outcomes

Rough course outline is as follows:

  1. Mechanism Design formulation: Social choice function, Direct and Indirect mechanisms, Revelation principle, Implementation in Dominant strategy equilibrium and Implementation in Bayesian Nash equilibrium 
  2. Mechanism Design with money - Transferable utility: Allocation rules, Payment functions, Quasi-linear utility, Incentive Compatibility, Vickrey-Clarke-Groves mechanisms
  3. Auction Theory: Single object auctions, First price auction, Second price auction, Revenue equivalence theorem, Optimal auctions, Multi objects auctions
  4. Applications of Auction Theory: Spectrum auctions, Sponsored search auctions
  5. Mechanism Design without money - Matching Theory: One-sided matching, Two-sided matching, Gale-Shapley algorithm

Faculty Name
Ashwini Deshpande [ashwini.deshpande@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

About the Course

This course familiarizes students with theories and empirical tools to understand and measure economic discrimination based on social group identities, such as caste, race, gender, tribal status, ethnicity and so on. The course will focus on evidence related to caste and sex in India. 

The first part of the course will take students through theories of discrimination such as statistical discrimination and taste for discrimination, based on the work of Kenneth Arrow, Gary Becker and George Akerlof.  This will lead to a discussion of the overlap between economics of discrimination and related sub-disciplines that are relatively new but are rapidly expanding, viz., “Identity Economics”, pioneered by George Akerlof and Rachel Kranton, “Feminist Economics”, and “Stratification Economics”. 

The second section will introduce students to concepts in social psychology such as stereotype threat and implicit bias that produce discriminatory outcomes. 

The third part of the course introduces students to some of the key methods of empirically gauging discrimination in market settings. This section would familiarize students with decomposition analyses applied to the labour market (what part of the wage gap between two groups is due to differences in abilities, and what part is due to discrimination), using standard techniques from Labour Economics. We would also discuss experimental methods – both field-based as well as lab-based experiments to gauge discrimination outside the labour market (e.g. housing market), or in the field of charitable giving, or even in labour markets but during the job search process (before applicants find jobs).  

Students will be familiarized with literature that applies these methods in the Indian context, particularly to the study of caste and gender discrimination. 

The final part of the course will deal with policy options to deal with group-based disparities and discrimination, with a focus on affirmative action policies. This section will outline the various types of affirmative action, including quotas or reservation, and discuss debates around affirmative action, focusing on evidence-based research gauging its impact.

This course looks at economic development primarily through the lens of food and agriculture. As we shall see, such a view can offer a powerful framework for understandingeconomic development outcomes. It is also productive in suggesting new lines of enquiry. description:
Demystifying Investments: Private Equity and Venture Capital [ENT-2034] [ENT-2034-1]

Faculty Name
Ekanto Ghosh [ekanto.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sagar Singhal [sagar.singhal@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sridhar Sethuraman [sridhar.sethuram@ashoka.edu.in] ,Amishi Gupta [amishi.gupta_ug25@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The rapid expansion of institutional capital in emerging markets, including India, has
opened up vast opportunities for entrepreneurs across multiple sectors, including
the social impact space. Institutional capital encompasses various funding sources,
such as grants, angel investments, seed funding, venture capital, private equity, and
long-term hedge funds. This course provides students with a chance to explore the
opportunities and challenges that institutional investors face, featuring India-specific
case studies and insights from successful investors and entrepreneurs. It covers a
range of industries, including real estate, fintech, social enterprises, and e-commerce.
The course is built on the core belief that every individual, regardless of their
profession, must think like an entrepreneur and investor. Whether you are salaried or
self-employed, entrepreneurial thinking is essential. The same investment principles
apply to career decisions, particularly when considering how to invest your time—the
most valuable capital. Students will learn how their post-graduation career journey
reflects the life cycle of an enterprise, from the risk-seeking stage of a startup,
through venture capital and private equity phases, to a more conservative, listed
company stage, where performance and adaptability are crucial to survival.
Though focused on unlisted investments, the course’s primary goal is to develop the
ability to: a) recognize and confront areas where we lack knowledge, b) identify the
issues critical to your success, and c) establish a mental framework for continuous
learning and understanding. Students will also encounter the paralyzing effects of
fear of failure and the feeling of helplessness that can impede success—not just in
investments but in life decisions, including the choice to commit time and effort to
this course.

Overview

The science of nutrition is becoming increasingly relevant due to its direct and indirect impact on health. This course comprehensively covers the foundations of human nutrition, exploring the metabolism of macronutrients and micronutrients, their interactions within the body, and their physiological effects. It will also cover organelle and mitochondrial integration of metabolic pathways, gut-brain axis and the effect of microbiome on host nutrition and metabolism. The course will also provide insights into molecular and physiological pathways/processes that couple nutrition and metabolic inputs with development.

This course aims to equip students with a foundational understanding of how nutrition impacts overall health and disease, emphasizing the biochemical, physiological, and metabolic aspects of nutrients.

Learning Outcomes

Upon completing this course, students will be able to:

1. Understand basics in the field of nutrition.

2. Describe the processes involved in anabolic and catabolic pathways.

3. Explain energy metabolism and its regulation with understanding the crucial role of the mitochondria.

4. Describe and discuss micronutrient sources, requirements, metabolism and function.

5. Understand the effect of microbiome on host nutrition and metabolism.

description:
Human genetic disorders: From rare diseases to cancer [BIO-4203] [BIO-4203-1]

Faculty Name
Alok Bhattacharya [alok.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in] ,Tanmoy Roychowdhury [tanmoy.roychowdhury@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Overview: It has become very clear that genetic structure and organization of an individual plays an important role in the well-being of a person. Though we do not understand the phenotypic (or functional) implications of all variations in one’s genome, our understanding of the human genome has seen great strides in the last two decades and we are now in a position to predict functional consequences of many changes that are seen in our genome. Genetic disorders are caused by changes in our genome and have been implicated in almost every disease known to man. It is said that “if one goes into details, all diseases are likely to be genetic disorders”. In this course we will recapitulate basic principles of genetics and introduce the concepts of human genetics. It is now clear that thousands of rare diseases are caused by genetic alterations and cancers are thought to be a form of genetic disorders. You will learn about the genetic basis of these diseases, how to diagnose and treat these diseases including some of the newer therapeutic approaches. Finally, you will learn how to analyse human genomic data and identify disease alleles.

Alterations in DNA sequences and their consequences

Methods and techniques in genomic analysis

Divided into three broad sections, we’ll first understand the new ways of reading that digital means offer. Then, we’ll consider creative productions such as digital games and instagram-films to study the storytelling possibilities that the digital offers. Finally, we’ll work on mini group projects making podcasts and visualizing data that help reconsider questions of representation and meaning-making.
These three rather practical sections will be set in the context of scholarly conversations that probe what the digital itself means, its colonial legacies, its gendered and capitalist underpinnings and the many new possibilities it offers to engage some perennial questions concerning cultural matters. Apart from written assignments, students will work on social digital annotations, mapping assignments, and storyboarding assignments. The course requires no prior familiarity with digital skills.

courseTitle: Revealed Texts: The Qurʾan and its Late Antique Environment
description:
Revealed Texts: The Qurʾan and its Late Antique Environment [ENG-2106] [ENG-2106-1]

Faculty Name
Sarah Yona Zweig [sarah.zweig@ashoka.edu.in] ,Amna Khan [amna.khan_asp25@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Late Antique Arabia has often been viewed as an ‘empty Ḥijāz’, culturally remote from the religious and political centres of the 7th century. However it is important to remember that the Qurʾan, while being the foundational scripture of one of the world’s largest religions, is also an important historic and literary document from Arabia of this time. In this course, we will explore the emergence of the Qurʾan (from Arabic qurʾān, ‘reading’ or ‘recitation’) and read it as a religious, historic and literary document -firmly situated within the cultural and historical milieux of Late Antiquity (ca. 3rd - 8th century CE). This course will introduce you to two exegetical worlds, the historical-critical study of the Qurʾan and Islamic exegesis (tafsīr). Notwithstanding their different approaches, premises and biases, they both share a fundamental commitment to close and patient reading, and an enduring fascination with the text of the Qurʾan. The initial segment of the course will focus on tracing the Qurʾan's origins within its historical context. We will delve into the intertextuality of Qurʾanic narratives and their Jewish and Christian counterparts. In the second part of the course we will read together excerpts from the 18th chapter of the Qurʾan, called Sūrat al-Kahf, accompanied by the seminal commentary known as the Tafsīr al-Jalālayn (15 th century CE). Sūrat al-Kahf is a particularly fitting since it offers a unique window into the rich literary worlds of Late Antiquity. Within its verses, a diverse collage of characters, motifs, and narratives unfolds, ranging from enigmatic sleeping youths and the prophet Moses to Alexander’s Doppelgänger Dhū l-Qarnayn.

Overview

This course investigates the premodern history of solitariness, as a condition and experience, and its intellectual and emotional ramifications, among them self-discovery, contemplation of God, creative inspiration, and loneliness. Readings are drawn from monastic literature, Arthurian romance, classical and medieval philosophy, Shakespeare, and the metaphysical poets. We will also explore the oppositions and overlaps of solitude with community, and the representations, in literature, of being alone amongst other people, or finding counterintuitive community in the very experience of solitude

Overview

This class will follow the literary trajectory of theory by reading the literary texts with which theorists have formulated their theories. Equally, we will read theory as it engages with the literature that
has occasioned it. We will examine the boundary between so-called primary and secondary texts. Might we be able to obfuscate the hierarchical relation between the two? Thinking about
“reading” in the most capacious sense, this course will engage with the multiple layers of textuality that make up the world in which we live. What is the relation between literature and
theory? How do we get ideas? And how do these ideas allow us to engage the worlds in which we live? In this course, we will put together literary texts and theoretical essays on those literary
texts to think of theory as both the subject and object of reading: reading both as something that theory does and that can be done to theory.

courseTitle: Religious Life and Pre-Modern Women’s Writing
description:
Religious Life and Pre-Modern Women’s Writing [ENG-4123] [ENG-4123-1]

Faculty Name
Alexandra Cassatt Verini [alexandra.verini@ashoka.edu.in] ,Shruti Subir Sarkar [shruti.sarkar_asp25@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sthitee Mohanty [sthitee.mohanty_asp25@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Books like Kate Bolick’s Spinster: Making a Life of One’s Own (2015) have received attention for highlighting women, mainly from the early twentieth century, who chose to live on their own terms. However, long before the modern desire for “a room of one’s own,” women were already involved in rejecting the bonds of marriage and claiming their own spaces. These were not best-selling authors but women who chose lives that were dedicated to God. From Catholic nuns to Sufi saints, medieval women in disparate parts of the globe found agency, community and fulfillment in single lives. Perhaps not surprisingly, the choice to live attached to God, either in community or in solitude, resulted in some of the earliest women’s writing.

This course takes a global approach to writing and criticism that emerges out of medieval women’s religious callings. From the letters of Hildegard von Bingen to the lyrics of Mechthild of Magdeburg to the vakhs of Lal Ded, we will track how devotion to god also constituted a refusal of heteronormativity. We will examine medieval writings alongside contemporary feminist, queer and theological theory to discern how celibate religious life, often lived in communities of other women, shaped medieval women’s literary culture. We will consider how the writings that emerge from these devotional ascetic contexts framed women’s relationships with God, with themselves, with each other and with the world. Finally, we will see whether these writings might offer us new frameworks for understanding gender, sexuality, and refusal today.

courseTitle: Dialectics against Despair: Frankfurt School Critical Theory
description:
Dialectics against Despair: Frankfurt School Critical Theory [ENG-4844] [ENG-4844-1]

Faculty Name
Alexander Robert Phillips [alexander.phillips@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course will serve as an introduction to the circle of thinkers loosely affiliated with Frankfurt School Critical Theory, in particular Theodor Adorno, Walter Benjamin, Max Horkheimer, and also their sometime inspiration, sometime adversary Georg Lukács. “Dialectics against despair” might be a surprising title for a course that focuses on a philosophy of negativity articulated by a group of thinkers the later Lukács famously dismissed as the “Grand Hotel Abyss.” But the versions of dialectical thought coming out of the Frankfurt School are not simply about wallowing (or reveling) in negativity for negativity’s sake. They are instead a way of keeping thought in motion and preserving a critical potential against a status quo that is perfectly able to assimilate even what appears to stand outside and in opposition to it, both in the realms of activism and theory. Perhaps, as Adorno says, “wrong life cannot be lived rightly,” but dialectical thinking can at least be a means to begin to glimpse something better, however vague and fleeting that “something better” must remain. Such thinking, Adorno argues, is at once the simplest and the most impossible thing, but is ultimately “the only philosophy which can be responsibly practised in the face of despair.” In this class we will follow this line of thinking from the 1920s through the 1960s, exploring arguments about the status of art in an era of industrial mass culture, the failure of revolution and the catastrophe of fascism, the domination of nature, and also, for the record, false happiness peddled under late capitalism. Through readings and discussion we will situate their writings historically against the backdrop of Nazism, exile, and ultimately post-war conservative restoration, while also keeping an eye on what they might offer us in our own thinking about culture.

Detecting Writing [CT-2482] [CT-2482-1]

Faculty Name
Alexandra Cassatt Verini [alexandra.verini@ashoka.edu.in] ,Abhijato Sensarma [abhijato.sensarma_asp25@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

We might think of writing as the setting down of predetermined thoughts; but, in fact, writing serves, more often and more productively, as a way of figuring out what we think. By writing (and revising and revising again) we ask ourselves questions and investigate our opinions and those of others. In this way writing, is something like solving a puzzle or even a crime. Just as literary detectives ask questions about motive, means and opportunity to discern who the killer is in a thriller, when we write, we ask and answer a multitude of questions to solve our own set of mysteries.    

By taking detective fiction as its subject, this Critical Thinking Seminar will examine works such as the short stories of Edgar Alan Poe and Agatha Christie and the 2015 film Talvar with the aim to train you in skills necessary to the process of reading and writing about literature. Each of the critical skills—from close reading to developing an argument to forming paragraphs— is paired with a work of detective fiction to help you consider that skill and give you topics for writing assignments. In addition to reading detective fiction and watching a few detective films, we will read some secondary works about the genre of detective fiction. The goal of the course overall is to hone your skills in writing about literature by examining a genre of literature that mirrors the process of writing itself.

Bad Literature: Studying Cultural Tastemaking [CT-2485] [CT-2485-1]

Faculty Name
Tanvi Chowdhary [tanvi.chowdhary_phd21@ashoka.edu.in] ,Vedika Khanna [vedika.khanna_asp25@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Instructor: Tanvi Chowdhary

Email: tanvi.chowdhary_phd21@ashoka.edu.in

Critical Thinking Seminar

Title – Bad Literature: Studying Cultural Tastemaking

What constitutes the broad, loosely defined idea of a bad book? Is it a text which is dense, complicated, and difficult to read – or a text which is frivolous, and silly, and romantic? Is a bad book one that often has themes we don’t agree with, or racist and misogynistic representations of characters? Are they texts that are sold purely with commercial purposes in mind? Put simply, what do we think of when we think of Bad Books?

Depending on class, position, level of education, or something as simple as the access to a library – our definitions of what is or isn’t bad literature changes. This course is an exploration of discourses about Bad Books, the critical history of judgement behind them, and an analysis of contemporary tastemaking. To pass critical judgement on art is not something done in isolation – it often signals social class and affiliation, in-group knowledge that is often designed to include and exclude. Additionally, Bad Books are usually considered so because they are judged largely as commodities, as opposed to art, which is a distinction frequently drawn in the process of tastemaking. Moreover, what is considered bad literature, often hides a wealth of reading practices of its own – the most relevant example of which is fanfiction, which operates on a digital economy quite separate from the publishing industry. Through this course, we will try to understand the wealth of reading practices that are the basis for the tastemaking that might deem a text such as Twilight as trash, and one like Normal People as literature.

Learning Outcomes

Over the course of this semester, I would like you to think about the kinds of biases that go into taste making – and the nature of studying literature as a whole. Since a lot of the texts we study in literature are broadly considered “good” reading (your personal and real opinions on Shakespeare, Austen, or any of the rest are welcome), it might be useful to look at literature slant, from an angle that we generally do not have the privilege to spend a lot of time thinking about.

Moreover, I would like this course to be one to bring your guiltiest pleasures, the texts you find most difficult to talk about in an academic environment – and hopefully decode what it is that you enjoy about these texts. Enjoyment is not, after all, something without theoretical force – and to have fun with reading is perhaps one of the rare affordances of studying literature that we can play with.

Novel Worlds [ENG-3368] [ENG-3368-1]

Faculty Name
Mandakini Dubey [mandakini.dubey@ashoka.edu.in] ,Priyal Navlani [priyal.navlani_asp25@ashoka.edu.in] ,Vedika Swati Mehendale [vedika.mehendale_asp25@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The most modern of genres, the novel is the book of life. It reflects worlds within and without; it registers the shifts of history and culture; it is at once escape, homecoming, and homelessness. Novels can contain revolutions (in both senses of the word 'contain') even as they redefine consciousness and personhood. They  examine reality in ways that include elements of the scientific or the philosophical, but through a distinctive mode of imaginative consideration. The novel is a shapeshifting, open-ended genre.

In this course, we will discuss the ways in which the novel and the world make, remake, and unmake each other. We will consider the history of the novel, including anachronisms and ruptures; we will think about the form of the novel, including departures and deformations, and we'll think about ways in which novels themselves reflect on acts of reading and interpretation. Our discussions and written work will take in politics and affect, aesthetics and materiality. Our focus will for the most part remain on fiction from the nineteenth century and twentieth centuries, with a few works by twenty-first century writers: canonical realist fiction (by writers such as Jane Austen, Elizabeth Gaskell, and Charles Dickens), more experimental literary fiction (including works by Virginia Woolf and  Salman Rushdie), and some works of genre fiction (horror, detective fiction, science fiction, and so on) that are yet to be decided. As we read theories of the novel alongside these narrative works, we will think about the ways in which novels encourage us to get out of our skins, inhabit other ways of becoming and being, travel through time and space, and encounter new universes--or, as we like to call them in this course, novel worlds.

 

Learning Outcomes

1. To develop an understanding of the novel that takes in history, form, and theory.

2. To develop the skills of close reading and analytical writing.

Overview

Adolescent Development and Psychopathology offers an in-depth exploration of developmental changes (biological, psychological, emotional, and social) that occur during the phase of adolescence. Equally, this course offers a comprehensive study of various psychopathologies that can emerge during this critical developmental stage. The course is designed to provide undergraduate students with a strong foundational understanding of both typical and atypical adolescent development and prepare them for advanced level courses and research pursuits in the field of adolescent development and psychopathology.

By the end of this course, you will be able to:

  • Understand adolescence as a distinct life phase and the nature of development that characterizes it.
  • Learn about the developmental changes that take in major life domains such as biological, psychological, emotional, and social aspects.
  • Learn about the nature of development of key behavioural tendencies with significant implications for adolescent developmental outcomes. 
  • Appreciate why adolescents show greater propensity for risk-taking behaviours.

Faculty Name
Simi Ghosh [simi@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course will focus on the intersections between Gender and Psychology across various domains. We will start with theoretical concepts of Gender formulations in psychology, history of gender struggle and rights movements, methodology and ethical issues in gender psychology research, and proceed towards exploring other psychological variables in gender. Throughout, the instructor will strive for a balance of introducing the class to literature that is cross-culturally pertinent.  We will critically engage with psychological literature that have dealt with essentialization of gendered attributes, sexually dimorphic models that dominate evolutionary psychology and biomedical research spaces, as well as psychological literature that focus on gender similarity and investigate the reasons behind gender differences in psychological constructs and attributes. We will discuss why intersectionality has emerged as an important perspective in gender research. This course is, expressly, not just for womxn students. It is encouraged that men enroll for this class as well, because this class will be geared towards a discussion of ALL genders within a framework of psychological thought, and no discussion on gender is complete if  half the population is excluded from it.   This is an advanced seminar styled course with weekly discussions and flipped classrooms employed  for most of the course, with didactic lectures only being a part of the entire 90 minute long class duration. 

Structure of the Course:

  • The first block of the course will provide a larger context for the class as well as gender movements and situate the importance of gender discourse in modern life. Second week onwards, the lectures will be followed by discussion classes on Thursdays where the class will be open to student presentations.
  • Each lecture class will have instructor lectures followed by discussion for the day. The instructor may conduct class activities  in small groups
  • Each student will be responsible for TWO presentations, which can be individual or [paired or grouped , based on final class size. Presentations need to be 10 minutes long with 2 min Q/A time and will be graded (Total 12 minutes). Each discussion class will have space for 7  presentation slots . Each discussion class will consist of student presentations on topics of their choosing but in tune with the topic of the week. There will be a roster alongside the course schedule spreadsheet. Students will sign up in the roster using their name and their topics of discussion. Grading rubrics will be shared with the class on the classroom website.

Prerequisites:

1.  SRM II (PSY 2002);

2.  Social Psychology (PSY2051) 

Either of the prerequisites cannot be concurrently taken with this class. 

Learning Outcomes

At the end of this course you should be able to 

  •  Differentiate between sex and gender
  • Situate the importance of gender as a discourse in life
  • Read research in gender psychology in an unbiased and critical way
  • Be familiar how gender struggles and movements have originated and evolved over time as well as within the discipline of psychology
  • Get an overview of the sub discipline of gender psychology and related research
  • Appreciate the nuances of observed gender differences and learn to distinguish between a sexually dimorphic measurement versus a socio-cognitively constructed one. 
  • Learn how the gender discourse and theories of gender inform psychological research and take it forward
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Design and Analysis of Algorithms [CS-3210] [CS-3210-1]

Faculty Name
Sandeep Sen [sandeep.sen@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sohan Biswas [sohan.biswas_tf@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Course objective: This course will introduce students to the mathematical modeling and solution of computational problems, and teach them how to design and analyze efficient algorithms.

Students will:

1. Cover the standard algorithmic paradigms like induction, divide-and-conquer, prune-and-search, greedy, dynamic programming and a toolkit of common algorithms including randomized techniques for design, correctness proofs and rigorous analysis of time and space complexity.

2. Explore different ways of thinking about and representing problems coming from diverse domains like sets, graphs, geometry, algebra and number-theory.

3. Develop an understanding of performance metrics like worst-case, average-case and expected case and how the underlying computational framework is intrinsically tied to the design of efficient algorithms and the notion of optimality.

Learning Outcomes

This course will enable students to think algorithmically and apply imporant algorithms to advanced areas, including but not limited to Computer Science. The students will understand the difference between provable guarantees of resource bounds like time and space complexity by using rigorous mathematical analysis and intuitive heuristics relying on empirical testing that can fail in critical situations. The more mature student would also learn to customize textbook algorithms for specifc applications and computational framework.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Pre-requisites: Data Structures, Probability and Statistics. We will not be using a textbook as such, but you may refer to one or the following textbooks for additional reading :

  • Design and Analysis of Algorithms - A contemporary perspective by Sandeep Sen andAmit Kumar, Pub: Cambridge (Indian edition available)

  • Algorithms by Dasgupta, Papadimitriou and Vazirani, Pub: Tata McGraw-Hill.
  • Algorithm Design by Kleinberg and Tardos Low Priced Ed. by Pearson.

Faculty Name
Bhargab Bikram Bhattacharya [bhargab.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in] ,Ananya Khemka [ananya.khemka_asp25@ashoka.edu.in] ,Anirvaan Kar [anirvaan.kar_ug25@ashoka.edu.in] ,Divyam Chaudhary [divyam.chaudhary_ug25@ashoka.edu.in] ,Karnav Popat [karnav.popat_asp25@ashoka.edu.in] ,Santosh Adhikari [santosh.adhikari_asp25@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Computer Organization and Systems (CS-2710), Spring 2025

Understanding the principles of computer organization and systems lies at the foundation of computer design. The aim of this course is two-fold: to introduce (i) the basics of computer organization and architecture (COA), and (ii) the fundamentals of operating systems (OS). In the COA-part, students will learn how programs written in a high-level programming language are executed on a physical machine. What is the hardware-software interface? Does the underlying “organization” of physical resources define the “architecture” of a machine, or vice-versa? Which factors need to be considered for designing the Instruction Set Architecture (ISA) so that the performance of the machine is optimized? We will highlight techniques for designing instruction set, and pipelining mechanism for the best utilization of hardware. Special emphasis will be given on RISC (Reduced Instruction Set Computer). In the latter part, students will learn how OS acts as an intermediary between computer hardware and the user for running applications. How the computer's resources, such as the CPU, memory, storage, and input/output devices are managed to ensure that everything runs smoothly and efficiently. How multiple processes run on the same CPU without conflict?

During the course we will walk through a selection from the following topics:

Introduction: Evolution of computers, hierarchical design of computer systems, hardware/software interface. Models of computation, overall system organization: Basic functional blocks of a computer - CPU, memory, I/O subsystems, control unit. Instruction set architecture (ISA): registers, execution cycle, addressing modes.  CPU Performance Equation, Amdahl’s Law. RISC versus CISC machines.

Instruction sets: Introduction to MIPS: operations, operands, and op-codes; MIPS assembly language.

Computer arithmetic: Number systems – Fixed and floating-point binary number representation; Integer addition and subtraction, design of arithmetic logic unit (ALU):

Processor design and Pipelining: Data path and control unit design, simple pipeline, hazards.

Operating systems: Elementary concepts of an OS, process management, inter-process communication, threads and concurrency, CPU scheduling, the critical-section problem, semaphores.

Memory management: Memory hierarchy; Cache architecture; Main memory; Virtual memory.

Multi-Core and Multi-Processing (if time permits): Vector processing; Multithreading, Shared-memory multiprocessors; Graphics processing units; Clusters and cloud.

Learning Outcomes

At the end of the course, students are expected to learn how a complete processor is designed in order to support an instruction set architecture as well as how the OS runs in the background overseeing all operations.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Suggested Reading:

1. D. A. Patterson and J. L. Hennessy, Computer Organization and Design - the Hardware Software Interface, 6th Edition, Elsevier, Morgan Kaufmann, 2021.

2. Smruti R. Sarangi, Basic Computer Architecture, Version 3.05, 2025.

3. A. Silberschatz, P. B. Galvin, and G. Gagne, Operating System Concepts, Tenth Edition, Wiley, 2018.

Grading Rubric

Assessment methods include homework assignments/group projects/classroom engagement (30%); Quizzes (30%); Mid-Term Exam (20%); Class-Test (20%) that cover the course material. There will be no Final Exam.

Attendance Policy

Trustworthy AI [CS-5440] [CS-5440-1]

Faculty Name
Aalok Dhaval Thakkar [aalok.thakkar@ashoka.edu.in] ,Subhashis Banerjee [suban@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

In the last few years machine learning techniques have been extremely successful in applications such as image recognition and object detection, autonomous guidance, natural language understanding and translation, radiology and medical diagnosis, targeting and recommendation systems, credit scoring and risk assessment etc. They are also beginning to see applications in health analytics, econometrics and policy. As the scope of applications expand beyond computer science into data driven decisions about humans and policy advocacy, we need better understanding of the risks and potential negative fallouts. This course will be a formal enquiry into ethics of data driven decision making that affect people.

In the first  part of the course we will analyse the shortcomings of the `prediction only' paradigm. We will try to formalise the notions of predictability vs reliability, and examine the possibilities of defining suitable reliability measures. In this context, we will study adversarial attacks and the possibilities of Out-Of-Distribution (OOD) samples. We will also investigate to what extent `causal inference' can enhance reliability. We will try to examine the ethical issues in building `autonomous systems'  -- such as self driving cars or even weapons -- based solely on high prediction rates of modern machine learning systems (deep convolutional neural networks).

In the second part of the course we will concentrate on fairness and bias. We will try to fomalise the criteria of fairness based on the understanding of discrimination that exist in the social sciences and law. We will see that unless the data lie in narrow well-behaved manifolds, most reasonable characterisations of fairness are impossible to achieve in data driven decision making. We will also study the various types of biases that can creep into algorithmic decision making - including data bias, algorithmic focus bias, processing bias, transfer context bias and emergent bias.

We will review the spate of algorithmic interventions that have been proposed to ensure fairness and reduce bias and discuss the limitations of these approaches. We will have open discussions on how then to promote fairness and contain bias risks in data-driven decision making, and discuss the related notions of privacy, accountability, interpretabilty and transparency. We will also discuss the obvious question that follows - alternatively, is it possible to achieve fairness by being data blind?

Finally, we will focus on the role of measurements in mitigating both reliability and fairness risks.

Learning Outcomes

Basic understanding of the risks and possible mitigations of  data-driven decision making.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The course will assume basic familiarity with introductory machine learning and basics of computational thinking.  It will also assume some good common sense.

The course material will be based on selected papers.

Grading Rubric

The course will have reading, discussions and quizzes for the entire semester. In addition, each participant will be required to scribe all topics and do a term-paper. Evaluations will be based on peer and instructor review of class participation, quality of reports and presentations.

Medicine, Movies and Literature [SOA-3146] [SOA-3146-1]

Faculty Name
Harish Naraindas [harish.naraindas@ashoka.edu.in] ,Abhishruti Sarma [abhishruti.sarma_phd23@ashoka.edu.in] ,Serene Jessica Joshua [serene.joshua_asp25@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course is an experimental attempt to bring together medicine, movies (as in all moving images) and literature (fiction/nonfiction/comics). It is an attempt to cross- fertilize and open up the possibility of doing an anthropology of medicine by carefully examining aesthetic objects such as literature and movies, and to introduce those who may be interested in movies and literature to the anthropology of medicine.

There are roughly four provisional modules: epidemics/pandemics; trans-corporeality; psychiatry; pharmaceuticals. Or the movement of germs/viruses, body parts, mind/consciousness/souls, drugs/vaccines. Unlike possibly other courses, we intend, in large part, to shift the emphasis to the Anglophone world, particularly the United States of America, as the analytical object in an attempt to wean students away from India as an ethnographic object and towards a country with an abiding religious undercurrent, although it is formally a secular democracy and ostensible trend-setter of the contemporary world. This is partly to emphasize that it may be interesting to make the US rather than India labour under the trope of religion, and, thereby, befuddle received anthropological categories.

We intend to do this by starting with a war game called Dark Winter run by the Department of Homeland Security in the US. Played purportedly in “real time”, with a sitting US senator playing the President of the US, it simulates a smallpox attack on the American Homeland. We will pair this with a movie on the Ebola virus, which escapes the nuking of an African village and arrives in the US piggy-backing on exotic pets shipped from the Congo to California. Against the backdrop of the lived experience of the pandemic, and the just concluded presidential election run as a “Book of Revelation horrors”, we will ask if epidemic imaginaries are harbingers of the apocalypse – as is the case with climate change – and how religion, especially late-nineteenth century American Dispensationalism, informs epidemics and pandemics. We may buttress this by drawing attention to the apocalyptic novels of the Left Behind thriller series, which by 2017 had not only sold 65 million copies but had spawned a mini industry of movies, video games, etc.

We then intend to traverse the world of transplants: body parts, embryos, gene editing, double mastectomies; then move up the body to the ineffable entity called consciousness, which seems to perpetually slip away and evade capture by either medicine, philosophy, or religion, except perhaps by the Amerindians who seem to know where it is as they appear to make trans-corporeal soul transfers to make their dogs dream better; and finally, end with the pharmaceutical industry: one that promises redemption from pain and suffering, and even the possibility, through psychedelics, of tangible meetings with God; and, in the bargain, seems to deliver addiction and iatrogenesis.

We invite students to step up and co-curate this experimental and neoteric effort by bringing visual and literary material to the table so that the modules and the trajectory sketched above may be brought to fruition. We would be more than happy to widen the ambit beyond the four modules if – given the constraints of time – we are persuaded to do so.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

description:
What is Globalization? [SOA-3147] [SOA-3147-1]

Faculty Name
Can Evren [can.evren@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What is globalization? How do anthropologists/sociologists study global phenomena? The concept of globalization has two distinct meanings. On the one hand, globalization denotes an ever-intensifying connectivity between societies, cultures, and regions across planet Earth. On the other hand, globalization denotes a normative project, one that empowers multilateral alliances and international law for governing cross-border connectivity. While scholars and the world public increasingly speak of the demise of globalization in the normative sense, societies are ever more connected, and transnational flows and crises are faster and more intense each day.

This course introduces students to the main concepts, definitions, and theories that shape the scholarly conversation over globalization. However, the course is not merely theoretical. We will read essays on methods and examples of empirical research that inspire anthropologists and sociologists to design research proposals to study global phenomena in their interactions with local and national scales of social activity. By the end of the semester, students will develop a research proposal to study a global phenomenon of their preference by applying the main ideas and frameworks in the syllabus.

description:
Re-Enchanting Expertise: Affecting the Rational [SOA-3148] [SOA-3148-1]

Faculty Name
Amrita Achamma Kurian [amrita.kurian@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

More than a century ago, sociologist Max Weber declared that the expanded rationality of modernity had disenchanted the world. Since the Enlightenment, “mysterious incalculable forces” have been replaced by accountable and calculable forces. Logs, metrics, models, and experiments replaced God, myth, and magic to render the world transparent. Yet, even as colonialism expanded Enlightenment values beyond Europe, the grotesque and the mythical survived the test of time. New and old enchantments, from raging wildfires to opulent godmen and shamans, proliferate modern society.  This course will explore how our social worlds and institutions have been shaped by this overarching narrative of modernity- disenchantment. We will also examine how subjectivity, the affective, and the mythical are not rationality’s evil other but rather are integral to its survival. Could re-enchanting scientific progress produce new forms of expertise in our modern world?

courseTitle: Body, Emotions and Politics in Spinoza
description:
Body, Emotions and Politics in Spinoza [PHI-3424] [PHI-3424-1]

Faculty Name
Arindam Chakrabarti [arindam.chakrabarti@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Can a real democracy be non-secular? If humans are naturally bodily, emotional, yet thinking, reasoning beings, what sort of government do they need or deserve? Given that "political morality" is an oxymoron (a la Kant), can there be moral politics in the 21st century where artificial intelligence and unrestrained greed are more prized than natural other-caring intelligence and public distributive justice? This course will raise these timely questions in the context of two pivotal philosophical texts by Baruch Spinoza (1632-1677) -- a Dutch radical rationalist philosopher who was excommunicated both by Jews and Christians for his pantheistic metaphysics and anti-establishment political views. The link between Spinoza's metaphysical monism and ethico-political pluralism will be explored in light of his deterministic promotion of individual freedom and his rich and complex theory of emotions and conatus (striving, drive to survive) and his anticipation  of the idea of "general will". This course should be interesting to all advanced undergraduates who are seriously bothered by the rampant "Hatred of Democracy" (cf: Ranciere) that has become  globally "viral" now amidst both the extreme left and the extreme right.

No prerequisites, but having taken one Intro to Philosophy or Introductory Political theory class would help

1. Ethics and Tractatus Theologico Politicus --by Baruch Spinoza

2. Spinoza--Gilles Deleuze

3. Looking for Spinoza: Joy, Sorrow and the Feeling Brain,--by Antonio Damasio

4. Spinoza's Political and Ethical Philosophy --by Robert A Duff

courseTitle: What are Thoughts, exactly? Proposition, Judgment, and Truth from Descartes to the Present
description:
What are Thoughts, exactly? Proposition, Judgment, and Truth from Descartes to the Present [PHI-3435] [PHI-3435-1]

Faculty Name
Till Alexander Guntar Hoeppner [till.hoeppner@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

To be taught by Professor Till Hoeppner.

Thoughts or propositions play important roles in our understanding of our thinking, believing, and saying the things we think, believe, or say (for instance, <the earth revolves around the sun>, <bodies are divisible>, or <2+2=4>). These roles are as follows: 

(i) A thought is that which is true or false such that beliefs and (declarative) sentences are true or false in virtue of the thought believed or said being true or false.

(ii) A thought can be accompanied by the attitude of believing as well as by other acts of persons like entertaining, denying, supposing, etc.

(iii) A thought can be expressed through (declarative) sentences persons can understand and use to say something. 

(iv) A thought can be numerically the same across persons and times and hence shared.

(v) A thought consists of various constituents forming a unity truly or falsely representing things as being some way.

What exactly are thoughts or propositions such that they can play these roles? This seminar will take both a historical and a philosophical approach to this question, considering the classic views on thoughts or propositions as they were developed in the period from Early Modern philosophy to Early Analytic philosophy, and then considering how (some of) these classic views have been taken up in various ways in contemporary debate. 

Among other things, we will discuss the following classic views and questions about the nature of thoughts or propositions: Are they the objects and features (or facts) that are thought through acts of thinking, believing, or saying? If so, what about, say, false or empty thoughts? Or are they rather these acts of thinking, believing, or saying themselves, or more precisely, types of such acts? If so, what kinds of acts are they exactly (judgment? predication? …?), how can we explain their truth or falsity, and how are such types of acts related to their instances (tokens)? Or, again, are they rather the representational contents of such acts? If so, what exactly are these contents: how do they exist, how do we access them, and how do they represent in a way that is true or false? Are they independent of minded subjects and their abilities and acts of representation or are they somehow dependent on such subjects, abilities, and acts? And is the relevant mind finite (human) or infinite (God)? How exactly do thoughts relate to the (declarative) sentences that express them? Are they sentence-like or maybe even in some sense sentences themselves? If so, what about the fact that sentences seem to have their truth-conditions only contingently, while propositions have their truth-conditions necessarily? Are they perhaps rather (types of) uses of sentences? 

The primary readings for the seminar will range from Descartes to Wittgenstein to the present. We will likely focus on the following authors, depending on our progress and interests in the seminar: 

- Early Modern Philosophy: René Descartes, Nicolas Malebranche, Antoine Arnauld, Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz, John Locke. 

- Modern Philosophy: Immanuel Kant, Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel. 

- Early Analytic Philosophy: Bernard Bolzano, Gottlob Frege, George Edward Moore, Bertrand Russell (early and later), Wittgenstein (Tractatus).

- Contemporary analytic philosophy: Jeffrey King (as taking up and developing early Russell and Wittgenstein), Scott Soames (as taking up and developing later Russell and Wittgenstein), Peter Hanks (as taking up and developing Wittgenstein), Friederike Moltmann (as taking up and developing later Russell), Till Hoeppner (as taking up and developing Kant and Frege).

All readings for the seminar will be made available to participants in electronic form. 

The readings for the first week are as follows, to be read carefully by the participants in preparation for the sessions:

Edition: René Descartes, Philosophical Essays and Correspondence, Edited, with Introduction, by ROGER ARIEW, Hackett Publishing Company, Inc. Indianapolis/Cambridge 2000. 

Please number the paragraphs of the Meditations I-IV! 

Tuesday, January 21: René Descartes, including excerpts from the Meditations (III): 

1. Background reading: Meditation I, paragraphs 6-9; Meditation II, paragraphs 2-3, 6-9. 

2. Meditation III, paragraphs 1-27. 

3. From replies to first objections (Caterus): pp. 149-151 (“First of all…” to “…more fully.”)

4. From replies to second objections (Mersenne), Definitions I-X: pp. 162-163, Axioms IV-V: p. 164. 

5. From third objections (Hobbes) and replies: Against Meditation III: Objections V-VIII and replies: pp. 171-174. 

6. To Mersenne, Idea Defined and Discussed: pp. 207-209. 

Thursday, January 23: René Descartes, including excerpts from the Meditations (IV): 

1. Meditation IV, paragraphs 1-17 (= the full meditation). 

2. From Principles of Philosophy, Part I: paragraph 9 (pp. 232-233), paragraphs 32-43 (pp. 239-242). 

3. From Notes Directed Against a Certain Program: pp. 288-291 (“In article twelve…” to “…corporeal image.”). 

If students have trouble accessing these texts in advance, they can email the instructor and request them.

courseTitle: Space, Causation, and Objectivity. Kantian Themes in Analytic Metaphysics and Philosophy of Mind
description:
Space, Causation, and Objectivity. Kantian Themes in Analytic Metaphysics and Philosophy of Mind [PHI-4487] [PHI-4487-1]

Faculty Name
Till Alexander Guntar Hoeppner [till.hoeppner@ashoka.edu.in] ,Madhav Gupta [madhav.gupta_ug25@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

To be taught by Professor Till Hoeppner.

A longer title for this course might have been: "Bodies, Space, Causation, and Objectivity. Humean and Kantian Themes in Analytic Metaphysics and Philosophy of Mind". 

This seminar deals with analytic Kantianism, an important tradition within analytic philosophy. This tradition, which properly begins with the work of Peter F. Strawson in the late 1950s and 1960s, establishes a philosophical dialogue that continues to this day between the analytic tradition and the theoretical philosophy of Kant – especially his Critique of Pure Reason – regarding philosophical problems first formulated and solutions to these problems first attempted by Kant. In this context, other early modern philosophers who were important to Kant, mainly Leibniz and Hume, become part of this dialogue. We will also use passages from Leibniz, Hume, and Kant themselves when it seems helpful to do so. Note that no prior knowledge of Kant is required to participate in the seminar. 

The focus of the seminar is on theoretical philosophy and lies, more specifically, at the intersection between metaphysics and philosophy of mind. The readings and discussions in the seminar will centre on questions concerning the representational relation of mind to reality. A major recurring theme of the seminar concerns supposedly fundamental features of our representational relation to the world, say, that we represent it as containing or constituted of bodies (individual material things), that we represent these bodies as standing in spatial and causal relations to each other and to us, and that we understand these features as (in some sense or other) objective features of the world. Some Kantian (‘transcendental’) questions that we will discuss are the following: Are these mind-independent features of reality (=realism)? Or do some of them, in some way or the other, depend on minds (=idealism or subjectivism)? Are these facts, say, that we represent the world as containing or constituted of bodies, or these bodies as standing in spatial and causal relations, somehow necessary or indispensable for any objective representation of the world, or could all or some of them have been otherwise? Are there alternative conceptual schemes to the one we use? And if some of these features turn out to be necessary or indispensable, what does that mean? Does it mean that the world really has to be as we represent it because we cannot represent it otherwise, or does it just say something about our representation of the world?  

The seminar's primary readings range from Strawson to the present. We will focus on major works by four authors – P. F. Strawson, Barry Stroud, John McDowell, and Tyler Burge – which will be discussed over several sessions each. Some of these works, parts of which will be studied in detail, are as follows: 

- P. F. Strawson's Individuals. An Essay on Descriptive Metaphysics (London 1959), chapters 1 (Bodies), 2 (Sounds), and 3 (Monads); his The Bounds of Sense. An Essay on the Critique of Pure Reason (London 1966), Parts One (General Review) and Two (Space and Time, Objectivity and Unity, Permanence and Causality); and his Skepticism and Naturalism. Some Varieties, ch. 1 (Skepticism, Naturalism, and Transcendental Arguments), which among other things responds to Stroud's critique (see below). 

- Barry Stroud's highly influential article "Transcendental Arguments" (The Journal of Philosophy 1968) on chapter 1 of Strawson's Individuals (Bodies); his article "Kantian Argument, Conceptual Capacities, and Invulnerability" (1994), in which he responds to Strawson's response (see above); and his Engagement and Metaphysical Dissatisfaction. Modality and Value (Oxford 2011), chs. 1 (The Metaphysical Project), 2 (Causation), 5 (Indispensability), and 6 (Metaphysical Dissatisfaction). 

- John McDowell's Mind and World (Harvard 1996), chapters 1 (Concepts and Intuitions), 2 (The Unboundedness of the Conceptual), and 3 (Non-Conceptual Content). 

- Tyler Burge's Origins of Objectivity (Oxford 2010), chs. 1 (Introduction), 2 (Terminology: What the Questions Mean), 3 (Anti-Individualism), and 6 (Neo-Kantian Individual Representationalism: Strawson and Evans). 

Beginning with Strawson's foundational writings, the seminar will trace their reception, development, and critique by subsequent authors, the reception, etc., of those authors' views, and so on. The syllabus will accordingly have an emphasis on philosophical debate and discussion. Thus we will see Stroud objecting to Strawson, who responds; McDowell taking up Strawson's reading of Kant; Burge discussing what he calls Strawson's individualism, and so on. Depending on our progress and interests in the seminar, other texts by these four authors and texts by other authors who engage with these four may be discussed: Among others, Gareth Evans on Chapter 2 of Strawson's Individuals (Sounds) and Strawson's response; Jay Rosenberg on transcendental arguments in Strawson and Stroud and on sounds in Strawson; Richard Rorty on Strawson on objectivity; Stroud on McDowell on perception; Stroud on McDowell on the Tractarian and supposedly idealistic notion of the world; Stroud on Burge's anti-individualism and Burge's response; Thomas Nagel on Stroud on indispensability and objectivity; Anil Gomes on Strawson on objectivity. 

All readings from the seminar will be made available in electronic form to seminar participants. 

The readings for the first week are as follows, to be read carefully by the participants in preparation for the sessions:

- Tuesday, January 21: P. F. Strawson, Individuals. An Essay on Descriptive Metaphysics (Routledge: London/New York 1959), Introduction and Ch. 1, Part 1 (Bodies: The Identification of Particulars).

- Thursday, January 23: P. F. Strawson, Individuals. An Essay on Descriptive Metaphysics (Routledge: London/New York 1959), ch. 1, parts 2 and 3 (Bodies: Reidentification, Basic Particulars, the latter focusing on the beginning, i.e. [6]).

courseTitle: Anthropology of Religion: Animism, Hylozoism, Panpsychism, Techno-Sacramentalism
description:
Anthropology of Religion: Animism, Hylozoism, Panpsychism, Techno-Sacramentalism [SOA-3150/ SOA-6125] [SOA-3150/ SOA-6125-1]

Faculty Name
Harish Naraindas [harish.naraindas@ashoka.edu.in] ,Nandini Bohra [nandini.bohra_asp25@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What is religion in the anthropological canon? Why has religion been addressed, either tacitly or explicitly, in conjunction with magic and science? Are magic, religion and science epochal moments in mankind’s evolutionary ascent, or are they coeval in time? How has anthropology, starting with Tylor, Frazer, Durkheim and Malinowski, attempted to come to terms with it? Does the religious history of these European thinkers, with the Reformation as a watershed, have a bearing on why they have been addressed together? Or were they led to invoke the category of magic through a colonial encounter with cultures – which the New World Encyclopaedia charmingly calls “newly contacted societies'' – that they designated primitive, which in fact is the title – Primitive Culture – of Edward Tylor’s celebrated work of 1871. The work where Tylor christens such cultures as animistic, thus setting in motion the formal study of religion through the concept of animism: a concept that inaugurates and virtually sets in stone the distinction between Us and Them, or between European and non-European cultures, or between the European past and its present, or between an enchanted, magical, pre-modern and primitive world, and presumably a disenchanted, secular and modern world. It is through the concept of animism, along with its cognate concepts of hylozoism and panpsychism, that this course will trace the genealogy of the study of religion and interrogate its consequences. We will, after running through the canon from Tylor to Evans Pritchard, examine contemporary but “conventional” ethnographies in “primitive” or “polytheistic” settings such as Vitebsky’s “Dialogues with the Dead” in Orissa, or Sax’s religion, affliction and healing in the Himalayas. We will then look at Ram’s “Fertile Disorder”, and her “provocation of the modern”, that extends and attempts to call this trajectory into question. We will pursue this questioning by turning to witchcraft in post-war Germany, and then turn to the fusion of magic, religion and science – or “techno- sacramentalism” – in twenty-first century German Hospitals. We will then, through Keith Thomas’ work, mark the presumed decline of animism and magic, not in primitive cultures but in European Catholicism, through the assiduous work of the Protestants and their Religion, thus offering us a different vantage point on why animism/magic/superstition were so important to Tylor (a Quaker) and Frazer (a Presbyterian) in framing their theories that the discipline has been historically saddled with. We will end the course by asking – through the “animistic turn” and Jason Storm’s work – whether the supposed exit of animism, which presumably inaugurates European modernity and sets it apart from the non-European world, spawning in the bargain ethnographic objects and explanatory moves, is indeed true, and, if not, how are we to rethink the future of not only religion as an object of enquiry, but of our very disciplines and their founding premises?

In Health and Materiality in the Indian Ocean World 1600‐2000: Medicine, Material Culture and Trade. Edited by Gerritsen, Anne and Burton Cleetus, London: Bloomsbury Press.
27. Sethi, M., Escaping the World: Women Renouncers among Jains, New Delhi, Routledge, 2012.

Grading Rubric

The readings – provisional – are listed below and will also be listed in an Excel Sheet, which will also contain links to soft copies of the readings. Each student is expected to present roughly 4 to 8 readings (the exact number will depend on the size of the class). A “reading” will be either two chapters or an article. They are expected to present it in class on a designated day as specified in the Excel Sheet. The class presentation essay must consist of three components:

1) a summary essay of 500 words,

2) a discussion essay of 500 words in which the students may raise questions of the text/authors, relate it to other bodies of work, or offer interpretations/critiques in the light of their personal experience and/or general reading,

3) a 100-word abstract each of the summary essay, and the discussion essay, respectively. In short: 500+500+100+100 = 1200 words. All the components of the class presentation essays must be merged into a single file and uploaded to Google Classroom by Sunday midnight for the Wednesday class, and by Tuesday midnight for the Friday class. It must also be sent to me and the TA/TF on our e-mail IDs. On the designated day of presentation, students must present only the two abstracts (100+100) to the class in 5-8 minutes. This will constitute two credits of the four-credit course. All students are expected to read the assigned texts and the essays written by their classmates prior to the class. The other two credits will be for an end- term essay of 4000-5000 words on a mutually acceptable topic chosen in consultation with me. The in-person class presentation essays, and the end-term essay, are both mandatory. Late submissions of either will attract a grade cut.

Faculty Name

Overview

This course will cover the role of government in modern economies. We will dig deep into the study of various instruments used to generate government revenue and analyze efficient ways to spend government monies. You will also be exposed to microeconomic models that are used to study the reaction of agents to government policies.  This course will serve as an introduction to various empirical tools used in modern public economics. Government expenditure, externalities, public goods, taxation, social security programs,  are some of the topics that will be covered in this course. Abstract concepts will be mapped to real-world examples to develop your public economics intuition.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The main course material will be papers assigned during the course. In case you haven’t studied public economics during undergraduate studies, please refer to the following textbook:

Gruber, J., Public Finance & Public Policy (I am using the 5th edition).

A list of topics that will be discussed in the course are given below. Please note that subject to time constraints, topics may be added or deleted from this list. List of topics are: Introduction to Public Economics; Defining and Measuring Inequality; Theoretical and Emprical Tools for Public Economics; Tax Incidence and Efficiency costs of Taxation; Optimal Labor Income Taxation; Taxes and Labor Supply; Externalities; Public Goods; Taxes on Capital and Savings; Behavioral Public Finance; Political Economy; Social and Health Insurance; Education and Discrimination.

Grading Rubric

Homeworks: Ungraded 

Exams (Mid-term and Final): 70% (35% for each exam)

Class presentation: 15% 

Attendance: 15%

Attendance Policy

 The students are expected to attend all the classes and actively participate in the class discussions. However, students can remain absent for a maximum of 5 classes in the semester without getting penalized. After that they will loose 3 marks for every class missed for a maximum of 15 marks. Hence, if a student misses less than 5 classes, then they will get 15 marks.

Overview

The objective of this course is to equip students to develop an understanding and capability to analyze important economic issues in resource economics. We will review recent empirical evidence on the various causes of natural resource exploitation. We will also discuss the social and economic impacts of resource exploitation and environmental degradation. The subject will focus extensively on developing the ability to think about issues and problems in resource economics through empirical models. Students must be comfortable with mathematics for economists, basic statistics, and econometrics.

Grading Rubric

Student grades have two components: A final empirical research project of 30% weightage to be done in groups (depending on class size). One data assignment of 30% weightage. Group presentations based on research papers/reports with 30% weightage. The remaining 10% weightage is for class participation and engagement. Students will consult the instructor to decide the topic for the empirical project and papers/reports for presentation. The syllabus for data assignments will be discussed in class. Students should use office hours for any extra help or resources they require.

Attendance Policy

Attendance is not compulsory, but 10% of the grade will depend upon class participation.

Faculty Name
Abhishek Rai [abhishek.rai@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Why do countries trade? Who gains and who loses from international trade? How have the global trade patterns evolved in the last three decades? What is the relation between international trade and Economic growth? We will study these questions both empirically and theoretically. In particular, we will cover the Ricardian theory of comparative advantage, the Heckscher-Ohlin Model of factor endowments, and trade driven by Economies of scale. Next, we will study the welfare consequences of trade, including empirical literature from the last decade and the role of trade policy. Finally, we will study the relationship between trade and economic development.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

International trade : Theory and Policy by Krugman, Obstfeld and Melitz 10th edition (required)

Grading Rubric

2 exams worth 25 and 30 percent 
1 concepts/key ideas presentation worth 15 percent
1 empirical project + its presentation worth 25 percent 
class participation : 5 percent

Overview

The course begins with exploring game theory, examining strategic interactions and Nash equilibrium, and providing students with analytical tools to assess decision-making in various economic scenarios. It then moves on to study its applications to industrial organization investigating the nuances of monopoly, oligopoly, monopolistic competition, and perfect competition. The analysis extends to understanding market failures caused by externalities and the provision of public goods, followed by a focus on information economics and labor markets. Applications of dynamic games of complete information include bargaining and repeated games. Throughout the semester, students engage in critical thinking through problem-solving assignments, and discussions, fostering a deeper understanding of microeconomic principles and their real-world applications.

Overview

This practical course enhances students' understanding of experimental chemistry concepts and boosts curiosity and observations. OC2). Different methods of purification of organic compounds

         i) Crystallization ii) distillation iii) sublimation

AC1). Preparation of stock solutions and dilution to different normalities/molarities.

Faculty Name
Sourav Chatterjee [sourav.chatterjee@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Considering the growing interest and importance of chemical biology/biological chemistry, it is felt that basics of biochemistry should be taught to the UG level students opting for chemistry as major subject in their higher studies throughout. In fact, biochemistry is based on knowledge acquired through all branches of chemistry with special emphasis on chemical reactions taking place in living cells. It has tremendous contribution in biotechnology and modern molecular medicine. description:
Foundations of Modern China: The Qing Dynasty in World History [CHI-3205/ HIS-3535] [CHI-3205/ HIS-3535-1]

Faculty Name
Sayantani Mukherjee [sayantani.mukherjee@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Modern China is among the world’s two largest countries by population, two largest by economy, and its fourth largest by geographical size. As a state, it follows centuries of imperial dynasties whose complex legacies it sometimes claims and sometimes rejects. In the last two hundred years, China has experienced some of the most dramatic social and cultural transformations and some of the most violent conflicts of any region of the world. As it was incorporated into an international system dominated by Europe and the United States, it became an integral part of global history in new ways and, increasingly, a shaper of that history. Often imagined as a monolith, it is in fact deeply heterogeneous, home to multiple languages and ethnicities, countless local traditions, millions of adherents of major world religions, and sizable foreign communities. Today, China is the site of crucial questions concerning geopolitics, the environment, global health, and human rights. At the same time, it has inherited and continues to produce immense bodies of art and literature, distinctive belief systems and intellectual movements, and delicious food. In these and other capacities, it also informs the identities of millions of people of Chinese ancestry living around the world.

            This course examines the Qing Dynasty (1644-1912) and the early days of the Republic of China. It makes reference to Tibetan, Taiwanese, diasporic Chinese, and global histories as well. It offers systematic coverage of Qing expansion and crisis, Qing culture, encounters with Asia and the West, the emergence of nationalism, and the transition out of the dynastic state. In the process, it gives special attention to questions of race and ethnicity, gender, frontiers, global connections, and nation-building. Instead of a chronological overview of the Qing era, this class will deal with historical processes between 1644-1912 through the four themes of statecraft, agriculture and commerce, ethnicity, and gender. This course design emphasizes historical thinking skills (e.g. understanding causation, contingency, agency, anachronism, meaning, and so on) and highlights the voices of historical figures, both powerful and ordinary, through translated primary sources. No prior knowledge is required.

Learning Outcomes

Course Objectives

This course has two objectives. One is to develop productive familiarity with some of the most representative themes, questions, and sources associated with the study of Qing history. The other is to cultivate the ability to ask historical questions in an intellectually responsible and rigorous way. We will focus on skills of critical thinking, reading, and writing (including textual, contextual, conceptual, comparative, and synthetic analysis), as well as habits of reasonable, respectful, and inclusive discussion. By the end of this class you should be able to:

Summarize academic monographs in East Asian studies and introduce salient points in notes and in speech.

Draw connections between works to gain an overview of scholarly and historiographical debates in the study of Qing China.

Trace theoretical or methodological trends across multiple empirical contexts.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

You are not required to purchase any materials for this course. All readings will be provided in PDF via email. Some weeks will list additional optional material, please reach out to me if you would like a copy of those texts.

Wm. Theodore de Bary and Irene Bloom, eds., Sources of Chinese Tradition, 2nd edition (New York: Columbia UP, 2000). [SCT]

Optional Reference Text

A more detailed textbook that may be a useful reference for essay assignments is:

Comparative Political Economy [POL-3113] [POL-3113-1]

Faculty Name
Anustubh Agnihotri [anustubh.agnihotri@ashoka.edu.in] ,Christina Paul [christinapaul_asp25@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Course Description:

The Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) is about to start slashing the budgets of the US government departments and reducing the scope of the government. Javier Milei seems to have succeeded in stopping the downward turn of the Argentinian economy by reducing government spending. It is a crucial time to study how markets function and what is the role of government regulation in the functioning of markets. To understand the present, we must revisit the past.

What is capitalism and how do we define markets? How do politics, society, and markets interact with one another? This course is designed to introduce students to theoretical works from prominent intellectual debates in 20th and 21st century political economy that engage with these questions. It examines the interaction between politics, society, and markets, linking theory to current policy debates. It particularly emphasizes the ways in which markets are embedded in social and political institutions.

The course can be broadly divided into two parts. In the first half, we survey some of the most influential works from multiple disciplines, including sociology, political science, economics, history, geography, and law. In this part of the course, we will read the classics – Smith, Marx, Polyani, and other authors whose perspectives, when juxtaposed next to each other, provide deeper insights into how markets and capitalism are conceived. We review theories of neoliberalism, neo-Marxism, law and political economy, racial capitalism, and feminist economics, among others.

In the second part, we apply theories of political economy to some of the greatest challenges of our time, including inequality, climate change, the Covid-19 pandemic, the rise of big tech, and the tension between capitalism and democracy. In the second part of the course, we will also focus on regions or nation-states (China, India, and Latin America) as well as events that are central to understanding capitalism (fall of the USSR, the 2008 financial crisis)

 

Learning Outcomes

To acquire a deeper understanding of how capitalism and markets are imagined across disciplines. The course will also prepare the students to intellectually engage with discussions around the role of markets in contemporary policy debates.  

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

PREREQUISITES

You need to have taken Introduction to Comparative Politics and have been exposure to some introductory economics (even high school is ok). If you are keen on taking the course and haven't taken Introduction to Comparative Politics, please reach out to me for a waiver. The course does not have any empirical component and knowledge or coding or data skills are not an requirement.
