Faculty Name
Maya Mirchandani [maya.mirchandani@ashoka.edu.in] ,Ahana Bhalchandra Walanju [ahana.walanju_ug25@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Good journalism is an iterative process. Building on Introduction to News Reporting (MS-1101) that familiarizes students with journalism’s first principles and teaches them the very basics of journalistic writing, the Advanced News Reporting course aims to encourage students to learn how to look for their own stories, and develop their kernels of ideas into exploratory, rigorous and well crafted stories through practical exercises throughout the semester.

In a rapidly changing technological environment, students will also experiment with different formats of news dissemination and whether they prioritize information accuracy, context and ethics of news and newsworthiness. Through an analysis of the current news media landscape they will be able to learn the value of staying true to these tenets.

The classes will be conducted as part lecture, part editorial meeting and part fieldwork. Students are expected to arrive in class having read at least two of the day’s major newspapers and scoured through news websites that offer both text and video formats of news. Deadlines will be taken seriously, and any delays in story submissions will be penalized.

 

MS 1101 - Introduction to newswriting is a pre-requisite for this course. 

Learning Outcomes

The course will introduce students to the art of layering their news reports by exploring the intricacies and contradictions in the engagement between a free press, the public and government. Students will understand the concepts of news beats, and specialized reporting, developing contacts and sources, interviewing, and using data effectively as a research tool. They will learn to distinguish between hard news, features, and narrative journalism styles.

Students will also experiment with writing news for television and other audio visual formats online, as well as learn the importance and craft of “live reporting” in which social media is often used to communicate stories with a sense of urgency and immediacy. Students will complement written articles with multimedia tools in the process. Those who have taken audio visual production, sound or photography courses are encouraged to use those skills while working on their stories.

courseTitle: Though This be Madness: Theories of History-Writing
description:
Though This be Madness: Theories of History-Writing [HIS-5900] [HIS-5900-1]

Faculty Name
Aparna Vaidik [aparna.vaidik@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This graduate seminar  is inspired by the famous line in Shakespeare’s play Hamlet ‘“though this be madness, there is method in’t”. This line captures the bewildering number of methods that historians have conjured up or drawn on to practice their craft. We will read ten historical texts written over a period of 50 years (from 1960s to 2010s) that engage with historical processes and also conceptualize their method for studying the process. For instance, Robert Darnton's book on 'Mesmerism' examines an exotic theory of healing that immediately seized the imagination of the general populace. Darnton’s juxtaposes this to the utter failure of Rousseau's Social Contract in rousing the masses. The question he asks is: if the greatest political treatise of the age failed to interest many literate Frenchmen, what form of radical ideas suited their tastes? This question serves as a doorway into study of popular culture and, it also questions the general historical assumption that it is the works of big theorists that move history. Paul Feyeraband in his book Against Method takes the example of Galileo to make a case that science should have an anarchic method. He poses the apparently simple but not-so-innocuous question: How does science differ from witchcraft? He demonstrates how Galileo used rhetoric, propaganda, and various epistemological artifices  to support the heliocentric position. Agnes Heller, author of A Theory of History conceptualizes the idea of 'chance' as a significant element of historical method. She draws on Jules Verne’s book Captain Grant’s Children (1867), where the children find a bottle in a the belly of a shark. The bottle has a message which is wet and not fully decipherable. They find the lost ship (from which the bottle with the note came) completely by chance and not by piecing together the evidence. Similarly, Marshall Sahlins writes about the significance of 'co-incidence' and Carlo Ginzburg about 'conjecture' as central element of historical method. I am imagining this seminar as a lively conversation that we will have as we read and engage with these books. The objective is to think deeply about the historian’s craft and to understand one's own practice. Please join the course only if you are willing to read deeply and if you enjoy conversations.

Class Format: Each student is expected to ‘adopt’ two texts (one before the mid-term and one after) and come prepared to present the main questions the books raise, their arguments, the sources they draw on and the vantage point of the historian, and finally what they made of the text.

The books:

1. Robert Darnton, Mesmerism and the End of Enlightenment in France

2. Fann, K. T., 1970. Peirce’s Theory of Abduction, The Hague: Martinus Nijhoff]

3. Agnes Heller - A Theory of History

4. Lucien Febvre,  The Problem of Unbelief in the Sixteenth Century: The Religion of Rabelais

5. Paul Feyeraband - Against Method: Outline of an Anarchist Theory of Knowledge

6. Marc Ferro, Cinema and History

courseTitle: Philosophy as a Way of Life
description:
Philosophy as a Way of Life [PHI-2109] [PHI-2109-1]

Faculty Name
Aditi Chaturvedi [aditi.chaturvedi@ashoka.edu.in] ,Vedant Santosh Deshmukh [vedant.deshmukh_ug25@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

“There are nowadays professors of philosophy but not philosophers…yet philosophy is admirable to profess because it was once admirable to live.” In this course, we will take Thoreau’s words seriously and read a range of philosophical texts with an eye not just to mastering the language and methods of philosophy but also seeing why philosophy matters in our everyday lives. While contemporary philosophical practices might lead one to regard philosophy as a technical discipline concerned with theorizing about fundamental questions, many philosophers — the world over and acrosstime periods — have regarded it, instead, as a transformative practice. Seneca spoke disparagingly of those who taught us how to argue rather than how to live. For Montaigne, our duty was to compose our characters rather than books. The Buddhist eight-fold path was not a speculation of merely intellectual import, but intended as a guide for the right way to live. The arguments of the Analects were intended to indicate a path towards self-cultivation. In this course, we will study the various ways in which philosophy can be conceived of as a way of life. We will also consider whether such conceptions of philosophy can be valuable, or even defensible, in the twenty-first century. This is a course in comparative philosophy and we will study a range of philosophical traditions to learn how philosophy was — and can be — lived.

Language and Society [SOA-3151/ SOA-6126] [SOA-3151/ SOA-6126-1]

Faculty Name
Kathryn Collins Hardy [kathryn.hardy@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

All humans use language, and of course, we often use language to describe the world. But is that all we do with language? In this course we will examine language as a dynamic social phenomenon, fully embedded in the world of human activity. Language emerges, is maintained, and changes through its use, but language also shapes and alters the very social world it is part of. We must look at language in use, empirically, in order to understand how this works. 

To do so, we will learn and use the tools of linguistic and semiotic anthropology in order to carefully question: what is language? How do we draw lines between languages? How does language function in society? How does it shape politics, history, literature? We will be concerned with classic questions posed in the empirical study of language, from the seeming stability of “codes” versus their dynamism and change; modes of interaction and communication; language ideologies and language differentiation; referentiality and indexicality; register formation and social value. We will also approach questions around multilingualism, language politics, and “mother tongue,”  as well as any other topics pertaining to the research of the course participants (in any discipline). As we will see, language is always political, and questions about politics (and history, and literature, and society in general) are always also questions about language. 

This course is intended for interested graduate students in any discipline and advanced undergraduates with permission of the professor. No previous training in linguistic anthropology is necessary — we will build our technical vocabulary and repertoire of concepts from the ground up.

The Ottoman Empire 13th -17th centuries [HIS-3531/ POL-3110/ IR-2062] [HIS-3531/ POL-3110/ IR-2062-1]

Faculty Name
Seema Alavi [seema.alavi@ashoka.edu.in] ,Rubab Ali Punjabi [rubab.punjabi_asp25@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The Ottoman Empire-13th to the 17th centuries

Instructor: Seema Alavi

Evaluation: 25% class discussions; 25% mid -term assignment; 50% end term assignment

The Course

The study of the Middle East assumes huge significance as its turbulent politics today draws global attention. Vast parts of this world were integral to an expanding   Ottoman Empire that began its innings in the 13th century and survived until the first world war. It was this Ottoman world that left its indelible impression on the modern Middle East when the post war British mandates framed the region.

This course studies the making of the Ottoman Empire from the 13th to the beginning of the 18th centuries to offer historical insights to the making of the modern Middle East.  It focusses on the complex network of alliances, and forms of communication that sustained and reproduced empires in the pluralistic and diverse socio-cultural settings embraced by the early Ottomans. It discusses the making of Ottoman political sovereignty and economy in the early modern period in the backdrop of the many challenges faced by the Empire.

The course has a comparative edge, and encourages us to think about the deep cultural and intellectual affinities that the Ottoman empire had with the Mughals and the Safavids in India and Iran respectively. It throws light on how these trans- imperial entanglements help us under better the geo-politics of the modern Middle East world.

Reading Persian Manuscripts [HIS-5015] [HIS-5015-1]

Faculty Name
Nadeem Aktar [nadeem.akhtar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course is meant for Ashoka students who have successfully completed two years of Introductory Persian Courses at the University. The courses are designed particularly to equip PhD students in reading and interpreting historical texts for their research.

Classical Persian Texts and Contexts
Persian literature written before the nineteenth century differs from modern literature both in form and content. The language of classical Persian literature is replete with Arabic words and literary phrases. They also have rich literary embellishments and artistic expressions. All this makes these texts very different from modern Persian texts. This course introduces these classical Persian texts to the students. It trains them to analyse these texts from a literary point of view and to enhance their skill of reading them in their historical contexts. This course will help the students negotiate the texts, documents, and archival materials of medieval and early modern periods in their PhD research.  


Codicology
Museums, libraries, and archives are full of Persian manuscripts and documents which are treasure houses of information and knowledge about the past. These Persian texts were written in various scripts by scribes, artists, statesmen, poets, and writers. Aside from texts, there are also additional documentary material – like flyleaf, colophon, endorsements, and seals – that are useful to understand the past. Many of these texts are not legible and can be read only by experienced readers. One of the challenges of modern times is to discern these writings and make the texts legible and translate them into English or vernacular languages. Many of the manuscripts lying in archival collection are still waiting for their readers, editors, and translators. As such, they are hidden from the public domain. This course on codicology will train research students in reading these manuscripts and using them for historical and literary research.

Inscriptions
In medieval India, the usage of Persian language was not limited to the writings of administrative documents and literature; it was also used to write inscriptions on walls of forts, tablets of mosques, tombs, and gardens. Inscriptions in Persian language also adorned many swords, knives, armours, and cannons.  Coins minted by the rulers also bear inscriptions in Persian. Museums and archives have vast collections of such coins and artifacts. All these inscriptions comprise extremely valuable sources for historical research and can be read only by trained scholars. This course equips research students to read and interpret inscriptional records to decode the past. 

Learning Outcomes

The course enables PhD students of History to read and understand the Persian sources

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Computing in the Cloud [CS-4622] [CS-4622-1]

Faculty Name
Manu Awasthi [manu.awasthi@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Public Clouds are ubiquitous. A majority of SaaS (Software as a Service) applications are being deployed on public clouds owing to numerous benefits they offer – reduction in operational and deployment overheads, and a seemingly better economic model.

The number of public cloud providers is increasing (AWS, GCP, Azure etc.), with each provider offering an even larger number of services starting from barebones, but configurable VMs to serverless (Function as a Service, FaaS) computing offerings all the way to highly available, managed relational databases and data lakes. Public clouds have created an entirely new economic model where users are charged explicitly for every component of the computer system they use –  storage and memory costs (charged per GiB), compute costs (charged per vCPU and its “type”) and network inflow and outflow traffic, among many other such a la carte charges. 

The course will be divided into two parts. The first part will be an introduction to the  foundational technologies that have made public clouds possible. We will discuss topics both at the hardware and the system software level, starting with the basics of warehouse scale computing, the design and deployment of large scale datacenters and the innovations in CPU, memory, storage and network architectures. Next, we will discuss system software technologies like virtualization, containerization and software defined networking, which in conjunction with hardware innovations like IOMMUs have allowed physical resources to be efficiently shared across multiple tenants while maintaining performance.

In the second part of the course, we will build on these foundations to discuss the major components of developing SaaS applications and the various tradeoffs that software architects have to consider while designing and developing these apps for scaling up. Typical tradeoffs include choice of the technology stack, deciding whether to create an application as a monolith or a collection of microservices, incorporating high availability and high performance into application design and use of caching and tiering in application design. We will also discuss the various security considerations and the reasons why application developers must pay attention to them right from the start, rather than an afterthought. Finally, we will discuss data management, data lifecycle, data security of applications: the various factors that application developers should be cognizant of while designing and deploying applications to ensure data safety and integrity.

The tentative, and possibly exhaustive list of topics to be covered in the course is below. The list will be revised with exact topics closer to the start of the semester. 

Basics of Cloud Infrastructure and networking, Virtualization and Containers, Datacenter server architectures

Deployment architectures: Monoliths vs. Microservices

Application deployment considerations: N-tier architectures; Load Balancers, Application and Caching layers, Data management layers

Data management basics: ACID properties; Consistency; transactions in DB architectures; Schema Design and optimization; query construction and optimization; Replication / Sharding and when to use them

Data management layer: Choice of Relational vs. NoSQL options; In Memory DBs and Caching; Fine tuning existing DBs for performance 

Fault-tolerance and High Availability: Basic concepts, Implementations by Cloud providers

Application monitoring and alerting: Basics of observability; what to monitor, when to alert; Application logging for performance and debugging

Security considerations: DDoS prevention, firewalls; Basic security measures for all deployments: port scanning, internal and external IP addresses, tunneling, consideration of performance overheads due to security.

Basics of Cloud Economics: Understanding cloud billing; performance / dollar for your application.

Implications of privacy laws (GDPR e.g.) on application design and deployment; Reading and Understanding DPAs.

Learning Outcomes
  • Understanding of basic technologies that make public clouds possible
  • Aspects of deploying software in public clouds
  • Hands on experience with deploying applications in/for public clouds.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Course Prerequisites: 

  • Computer Organization and Architecture,
  • Operating Systems,
  • Computer Networks, 
  • Familiarity with tools like Git, Docker, Shell scripting

Or equivalent of the above courses, if you are a PG/PhD student.

Note: This will be taught as a 6 week course, with classes being held every alternate week. 

Grading Rubric

Students will be organized into teams. Each team will be responsible for developing and deploying a complete application from scratch, and will be graded on the overall quality of the application and the deployment. 

Attendance Policy

Attendance is not mandatory but students are highly encouraged to attend all lectures.

Overview

This course will introduce students to the idea of designing and crafting a scale model of a habitable space of their choosing. During the course of the semester students will be introduced to the meaning of space and how it has been crafted through precedents over time imbibing cultural and social values and how those parameters can influence its design and usage. We will be looking at a historical timeline from cave dwellers, emperors as patrons and modern-day architects and how they have created spaces varying in scale to create habitats over time. Keeping these in mind, students will begin to explore what space means to them individually and how each person’s idea of space will be different depending on their cultures and histories. Their assignment will be to design a single habitable space for themselves. Students will make sketches and scale models through the design process that best represent their design intent. Materiality – the study of how different materials express different intent - will be explored so that the models that each student makes best represent the space that they are designing. The class will then be split up into larger groups where the possibility of amalgamating different individual designs/ spaces into a larger coherent spatial experience will be explored.

Faculty Name
Monia Acciari [monia.acciari@ashoka.edu.in] ,Rahul Sugatdas Uthale [rahul.uthale_mls25@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Welcome everyone to Cinemas of the World. This course is a virtual journey across the world, to study, view, and curate films that have made an impact globally.  

This course examines key theoretical and critical concepts, as well as debates, that are essential for a comprehensive historical and contextual understanding of World Cinema. It emphasizes contemporary developments and case studies through specific films, regions, and/or directors. The current period is widely regarded by critics as a golden age for emerging "new cinemas," directors, and transnational trends, including popular exportable genres, new multicultural genres like migrant and accented cinema, "new" realisms, and "slow cinema." Recently, World Cinema Studies and Transnational Film Studies have emerged as distinct academic fields. The aim of this course is to provide you with a well-rounded understanding of the diverse range of World Cinemas beyond the structures of Hollywood, exploring the transnational and transcultural contexts of production, circulation, consumption, and reception of "World Cinema" films today. These aspects have been shaped by factors such as new digital technologies, the internet, global media convergence, economic and cultural globalization, and political transformations, all of which will be addressed in this course. Alongside a theoretical and analytical component, the course will also introduce you to practical notions of curatorship, to  understand how the exhibition industry works in relation to creative programmes of world cinema. Some of the key films we will study are from regions such as Africa, Italy, Iran, Korea, and China, among others.

Learning Outcomes

On completion of this course, students will be able to:

1. Gain an understanding of key theoretical and critical concepts, models and debates relevant to the study of both national cinemas and transnational developments within World Cinemas, and had opportunities to apply these. (Research Dossier, Curatorial programme, and audio-visual diary).

2. Engage in depth with selected film/cinema case studies (national, transnational, thematic/issue based, or director-focused). (Research Dossier and Curatorial programme).

3. Gain an informed sense of the institutional, economic, political, cultural and wider contextual issues around contemporary ‘World’ filmmaking (from questions of history, identity and representation to the impacts of globalisation and new technologies) and the ways in which these may shape the themes, style, production, circulation and reception of non-Hollywood ‘World Cinema’ films. (Research Dossier and Curatorial Programme).

4. Build competence in, selecting and applying relevant concepts, arguments and contextual understanding appropriately in (i) discussion and evaluation of trends, movements and/or case studies within World Cinema at national and transnational levels, and (ii) critical discussion and/or textual analysis of specific films. (Research Dossier and Curatorial programme).

5. Demonstrate a critical, practical and historically informed appreciation of the different ways in which film industries may be conceptualised in both national and transnational terms.

Grading Rubric

The course comprises of two assessments as follows:

2. Curatorial Programme: The final assessment of this course is a creative production. The students are required to put together a viewing programme of international films, from a variety of world cinemas in which notions of: the national, the transnational, the postmodern etc. is narrativized through a curated digital catalogue for a public event. courseTitle: Roots and Routes: Experiencing the Language and the Culture of the Roma through Songs, Sounds, Stories and Cinema
description:
Roots and Routes: Experiencing the Language and the Culture of the Roma through Songs, Sounds, Stories and Cinema [CLA-0054] [CLA-0054-1]

Faculty Name
Punita Gurpreet Singh [punita.singh@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

A mysterious people arrived in Europe towards the late Middle Ages speaking a different tongue, wearing strange outfits and practicing rituals unfamiliar to those around them. Called Gypsies, Egipcyans, Atsingani, Moon People and other odd names, linguistic clues eventually revealed their link to India and helped identify their migratory routes. In this course we will review historical sources that first established the Indian roots of these people—now called ‘Roma’—and explore how the Romani language evolved over a millennium as its speakers passed through various way stations, adopting ‘loan words’ from other languages encountered en route. The Romani language in turn also influenced and enriched the languages it came in contact with. Through root-recognition activities, we will investigate if Romani is comprehensible to present-day speakers of particular Indian languages. Through songs, stories and cinema, we will experience the sound, structure and expressivity of Romani and observe how it has been used to convey identity, community values and resilience, despite historical persecution and marginalization of the Roma. We will also discuss the diversity of dialects, the challenges posed to linguistic unity, and modern efforts to preserve and revitalize the Romani language and keep it alive for future generations.

description:
To see, to tell, to show [CVA-0101] [CVA-0101-1]

Faculty Name
Anni Kumari [anni.kumari@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The quest to discover new visuals and new ways of seeing, narrating, and experiencing a story is nothing new. Yet we continue exploring newer ways of creating visuals, narrating, re-narrating tales, and sharing them with the audience. Through deft use of mediums, materials, skills, and techniques, artisans, artists, and craftsmen in different times, regions, and traditions have manifested ways of engaging their audience in storytelling through a repertoire of visuals, oral poetry, body movements, sound, and light.

Among India's many storytelling traditions, the Bengal pata and the Rajasthani phad are exceptional in combining the visual, the oral, and the performative elements into a comprehensive experience.

In this course, we will look at some interesting examples of visual compositions based on the epics, the Bhagavata Purana, stories of local folk heroes and deities, and those on secular themes and contemporary issues. Involving processes of drawing, painting, collaging, paper cutouts, assemblage, and mask-making, we will work collectively towards a visual narrative performance.

Students will gain a rudimentary knowledge of speaking, reading, and writing Kashmiri, while becoming familiar with the historical and cultural contexts that have shaped its literature. Alongside this, we will examine how this foreign literary genre has evolved within Kashmiri cultural and literary context, reflecting both its adaptation and transformation over time. No prior knowledge of Kashmiri language is required — just a curiosity for languages, literature, and storytelling.

description:
The Cry of the Gazelle: Love and Indian Music [CPA-0104] [CPA-0104-1]

Faculty Name
Vighnesh Hampapura [vighnesh.hampapura_tf@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course follows the polemical suggestion that all music is about love. Most obviously, we might focus on the ghazal, and learn compositions from traditions of ghazal gayaki—for its explicit renditions of separation and love’s painful endurance, for its translations into other languages and forms including that of bhavageete in Kannada, and for its influence on early Hindi film music that was invested in building rich tableaus of love. But are not the compositions of Jayadeva, for instance, also ghazals, not in their literary structure but in their emotional and musical thrust? So we will learn music that might not have clear historical connections but surprisingly share the same motifs of love. Indeed, the braiding of the devotional and the erotic in the ghazal allows us to ask questions about forms of music like the Karnatik that are only framed as projects of bhakti. As we add new compositions to our repertoire, dipping into different genres and thinking of their lyrical resonances, we will attend to the musical movements that might themselves be considered gestures of longing—of lament, of depression, of stasis, of relief, of agony, an anxiety, the many states of love. Before or after the ghazal, are we all crying like the gazelles?

Signaling Games of Social Networks [CS-4911] [CS-4911-1]

Overview

Networks and "network-centric thinking" have become ubiquitous in our modern society. Their utilities have been enhanced by their ability to generate massive amount of transactional data that are accurately stored, efficiently verified and rapidly disseminated. But, these information-asymmetric private data have been frequently misused. For instance, the World Wide Web, Distributed Ledgers, GPT/genAI and Personal Data Markets enable information flows among vast number of humans; facebook, LinkedIn, etc. connect small groups of friends, colleagues and acquaintances; amazon, ebay, etc. provide opportunities for trading; uber, airbNb, etc. create platforms for sharing economy; silkroad, agora, etc., create systems for anonymous and often illicit trading, etc. These networks determine our information, influence our opinions, and shape our political attitudes. They also link us, often through important but weak ties, to other humans. Their origin is biological: going back to quorum-sensing, swarming, flocking, social grooming, gossiping, etc. Yet, as we have connected our social networks to traditional human institutions (markets, justice systems, education, etc.) through new technologies, the underlying biology has become obscured, but not dormant.

We will select Use Cases of interest to the audience to design a new environment ab initio.

Motivation We are motivated by the following goals:

Understand the evolving environment (e.g., wealth management and investment banking services)

Model utilities and risks (robust hypotheses, driving rapid and scalable testing and learning: e.g., A/B testing, boosting and reinforcement learning, hallucination and guardrails)

Interact strategically and rationally (use case development, hypothesis testing and production of new value for clients and the firm within and across divisions)

Design mechanisms such that all stake-holders interact strategically but in a mutually beneficial manners ("good" Nash equilibria; Shapely values, "Cellularization")

Topics

[Introduction to Networks] (Biological, Social, Economic and Communication): where we study important binary relationships (e.g., friendship, followership, P2P, B2B, etc.) among entities: such as users, objects, contents. Network effect and Tipping points. Degrees of Separation.

[Computer science:] where we study historical developments culminating now in ubiquitous social-technological networks: fundamental concepts such as computational universality, undecidability, exponential growth (e.g., Moore's law). Limits and powers of computer science.

[Graph Theory:] where we study evolving Social Networks, using theories of combinatorial, probabilistic and algebraic graph theory.

[Graph Laplacians*:] where we study modern algebraic graph theory to compute Social Ranks (e.g., PageRanks).

[Game theory:] where we study strategic interactions among informed and uninformed stake-holders (sender-receiver signaling games); Signaling, Costly/Honest Signaling and Deception.

[Nash equilibria*:] where we study the solutions to games: such as Stable Separating vs Babbling/Pooling Equilibria.

[Mechanism Design:] where we study various ways to guide strategic interactions among stake holders. (Tools: Costly Signaling, Recommender-Verifiers)

[Signaling:] where we study how communications and data analysis may be organized, especially, via LLM (Large Language Models).

[Digital Market Places:] where we study traditional and emerging/disruptive ideas in Market Micro-structure.

[Crypto-Coins and Payment Systems:] where we study: Distributed Ledgers, Identity and "Insider Threats" etc.

description:
Banish the poets [POL-2127] [POL-2127-1]

Faculty Name
Mohammad Amir Ahmad Khan [mohammad.khan@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Banish the Poets

Can poetry save the world? 

From the Epic of Gilgamesh to Homer’s Iliad, from the Mahabharata to the Song of Deborah, humans have often made sense of the world around them through poetry. The earliest accounts of politics- that is war - were recorded in these epics and poems. They were composed to project heroes, create myths and engage with ideas of right and wrong, life and death and the mundane and the transcendent. Poetry has also always been used to dissent, protest, critique and resist. From the anti-legalist poetry of Attar and Rumi to the anti-establishment poems by Percy Bysshe Shelley, Habib Jalib and Maya Angelou, poets have taken considerable risk to be the voice of the voiceless.  Unafraid of speaking truth to power, they have been censored, banished, imprisoned and even killed. The power of the spoken word is even acknowledged by kings, potentates, tyrants and leaders who sought to project themselves as poets: Mao published 18 poems in the inaugural issue of a journal called Shih-k’an, Saddam Hussain wrote poetry towards the end of his time in prison, often sharing it with his guards, and Radovan Karadžić’s poetry was seen by some as tantamount to war crimes. Rulers and states have always been wary of poets. Plato envisaged a republic in which certain poets would be banished if they did not write the ‘right’ kind of poetry, with poetry being closely related to song, drama and performance as well. The Quran emphatically states that the Prophet was not a poet and then warns believers against poets ‘except those who believe, do good, remember Allah often, and ˹poetically˺ avenge ˹the believers˺ after being wrongfully slandered.  

The function of poetry has been varied. Poetry can soothe or provoke, give hope, arouse anger, agitate or calm, bind otherwise diverse people, instil courage and importantly ask questions while creating the possibilities of multiple answers. Poetry has been every(wo)man’s philosophy, a portal to the sacred and a medium for the profane, poets have become the sloganeers of revolutions and their poems have shaken the thrones of tyrants. Adorno said that to write poetry after Auschwitz would be barbaric. Refaat Al-Areer  wrote ‘If I must die’ in 2011 while living under occupation and shortly before he was killed in Gaza, almost presciently, he reshared his poem.

 In this course we will read about what makes poetry so powerful: its forms and cadences, meters, sonic and phonic aspects, silences, uses of images and metaphors, its power to articulate what is felt in novel and arresting ways and of course its spaces. We will therefore also study the work of poets from different ages and parts of the world whose poetry was marked by protest and dissent. While one part of the course will be structured in order to equip ourselves with the tools to understand the broader theoretical frameworks of poetry, the other part will be the consequence of us choosing which poets and case studies we seek understand.

Understanding audio visual production [MS-1567] [MS-1567-1]

Faculty Name
Natasha Badhwar [natasha.badhwar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course will introduce students to audio and video production at an introductory level. Through a series of viewings of historical and contemporary documentary films and readings, students will understand the formats, power and tools of audio visual communication, grasp basic concepts and terminology around production and be introduced to media ethics.

The course will explore the increasing predominance of visual media in contemporary life and the various ways in which traditional narrative forms of storytelling are being replaced by visual forms of storytelling in journalism, photojournalism, film, television, the internet, video games, anime, graphic novels, and advertising. Students will view and analyse films on the basis of  documentary modes as proposed by documentary theorist Bill Nichols - poetic, expository, observational, participatory, reflexive, and performative.

Students will receive basic training in professional video production and use of equipment, as well as post-production practices and software, with an emphasis on establishing effective communication and collaborative skills. Special emphasis will be paid on composition, light and texture in photography and its affective impact on the viewer. The use of movement, sound and transition techniques in editing will be observed and put into practice.

Through a series of practical exercises, they will learn low-budget production methodologies including basic studio production - and the many open-source software tools and platforms that can facilitate video production.

Learning Outcomes

Students will become familiar with the long arc of the history and development of audio-visual expression and the technologies that have enabled them.

They will learn about the power and resonance of audio-visual expression through guided exercises in components of photography, videography and video editing.

Faculty Name

Overview
Introduction to the Documentary
Encounters with reality: deconstructing and understanding non-fiction cinema
 
The course will unravel various dimensions of the documentary form as it has developed over time, till the present. We observe the nature of the document as it emerges in the documentary, analysing the binaries of subjectivity and objectivity, and the truth claim that much documentary practice asserts. Is documentary information and education? Or is it also activism, observation, experiment, poetry and art? Exploring several thematic preoccupations and narratives within the documentary, we discover the richness that the form holds. Discussing tropes that documentary often rests on, and conceptually navigating ethical, aesthetic aspects, the course examines the politics of representation.
 
The sessions will include viewing, critical analysis and participatory discussion. The course will culminate in student presentations on chosen aspects of documentary cinema. The presentations will be intensively mentored, with a view to facilitating further exposure and proactive learning.
Learning Outcomes
Knowledge, perspectives and attitudes with respect to documentary:
  • Recognising common documentary tropes and elements
  • Reflecting on conceptual, theoretical and aesthetic aspects
  • Learning ways of analysing and critiquing nonfiction cinema
  • Understanding the integral connections between content and form
  • Learning to recognise the role of image making, sound and editing
  • Understanding ethical dimensions that are critical to documentary practice
  • Responding to varied documentary narratives that have emerged over time
  • Learning basic research skills, developing conceptual rigour and synergy with a team, while working on the final group presentation

Overview

This course is an introduction two computational pipelines that we use every day. 

1. Imaging pipeline: what goes on when we take a photo on our digital (phone) cameras (or other sensors). (30% of course)

2. Graphics pipeline: what goes on when text, images, shapes are rendered on our displays. (70% of course)

Computational imaging systems have a wide range of applications in consumer electronics, scientific imaging, HCI, medical imaging, microscopy, and remote sensing. We discuss digital imaging pipeline and inverse problems in imaging such as demonising in this course. 

Computer graphics is a core technology in digital photography, film, video games, digital art, cell phone and computer displays, and many specialized applications. We will introduce the technical concepts behind creating synthetic computer generated images —vector math, ray tracing, basics of texture mapping, graphics pipeline, splines etc.

Overview

Everything in the universe contains the atoms of at least one or more elements. These elements and their isotopes contain valuable information that is helpful in archaeology and heritage studies, such as the identification of fragmented and weathered archaeological objects, reconstruction of ancient technologies, past climate, ancient food and culinary practices, health and migration to name a few. In order to comprehend how these cutting-edge methods might be applied to recreate different facets of ancient societies from the fragmented material remains, this 5000-level advanced course will cover the numerous applications of elements and stable isotopes in archaeological research. We will cover some of these techniques and their use in detail in this seminar course.

There is no pre-requisite for this course, but a general idea of archaeology and chemistry would be helpful.

courseTitle: Shaping the India Way: Foreign policy institutions, sites and forces
description:
Shaping the India Way: Foreign policy institutions, sites and forces [IR-2061] [IR-2061-1]

Faculty Name
Constantino Cristovam Hermanns Xavier [constantino.xavier@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

As a rising power India is deepening and expanding its ties with the rest of the world across different domains, from climate and technology to trade and security, culture and sports. There is a growing and diverse flow of goods, capital, people and ideas moving across India’s territorial borders amidst an uncertain, fractious geopolitical order. India’s foreign economic and security policies are also assuming electoral salience at home, as well as a growing extra-territorial dimension, including a 30-million strong diaspora. India now aims to be a “voice of the Global South,” reform multilateral institutions and host the 2036 Olympics. Whether it is artificial intelligence, health, outer space or the Internet, Indian officials are now increasingly involved – or expected to be present -- at the global “high tables” setting new global standards and regulations. This increasingly complex, fast-paced international environment is posing new challenges for India to define and pursue its interests abroad.

Yet while we know much about the rising ambition, expanding scope and accelerating pace of India’s international engagements in recent years, there is less knowledge about the growing number of institutions, sites and forces that shape its foreign policy behaviour. This course introduces students to the broader yet also less visible ecosystem in which Indian foreign policy is made or “begins” at home: What traditional and new organizations are involved in defining India’s international posture? What are the main institutional sites and locations of decision-making, at different levels of government and across the country, from New Delhi to border regions? How do different domestic, non-governmental forces and actors shape the ideas and interests that drive India’s international engagements?

The course is divided in two parts, focused on specialized readings, class discussions and different types of oral and written assignments to map the different institutions, sites and forces that shape the India way of diplomacy. The first part explores the traditional, state-centric perspective including the role of different ministries and the bureaucracy, the armed forces, intelligence organizations, the parliament and regional states. The second part examines the non-state perspective, including the role of political parties, the private sector, civil society organizations, media and think tanks.

By tracking these different levels of analysis, focused on case studies across time and space, we  will also assess how this environment has changed in recent years, reflecting issues of Indian state capacity, policy coordination, organizational change and accountability that are rarely studied in Indian IR. This will help students to a) familiarize themselves with both old and new institutions, sites and forces that are shaping Indian foreign policy, b) connect (or apply) theoretical concepts and learnings from foreign policy analysis, international political economy and historical institutionalism to the case of India, and c) develop insights and analytical skills that are required for most public policy professionals focused on India.

Digitality: Ethnographic Approaches [MS-3090/ SOA-3152] [MS-3090/ SOA-3152-1]

Faculty Name
Chitralekha Dhamija [chitralekha@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sana Bashir [sana.bashir_asp25@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Ethnography provides an irreplaceable lens to study the lived relationships of digital technologies with human life and cultures, and their constitutive linkages with what it means to be human. While the idea of the digital may be used to refer to binary connections, the computational, electronic, or anything that is internet mediated, ethnographers are interested in the imbrications of these technologies in everyday life and the consequences of the digital for the human condition- in online worlds and in their entanglements with lived realities in physical places. Ethnographic approaches in other words help us explore human interactions with digital devices, the making of human connections in cyberspace, coproduction of notions of the real and the virtual, or the conditions of living and being in a digital culture- that might be called `digitality’. We will examine possibilities of these human engagements in diverse sites and contexts. 

The course will be taught over three sections. 

We first chart some of the conceptual dilemmas in the terrain. How do we approach understandings of `digitality’? In what ways may the digital mediate human life and culture? Are they any different from prior mediations? 

The second section engages with methodological contestations that ethnographers of digital media grapple with. These include existent questions of power, subjectivity, or reflexivity in ethnography in general, but also those that address specific dilemmas in digital ethnography. What does it mean to do ethnography in digital worlds? What may be its analytic advantage to study sociality or politics? Can virtual worlds be studied on their own terms- without ethnographic engagement in the physical worlds that actors in digital places also belong to? What does it mean to conduct multi-sited or multi-timed fieldwork on specific congeries of media practices, forms and agents? How does ethnography help us approach closer towards understandings of digital media in everyday life that is ‘non-media-centric’? Can the study of media beyond media content, as part of the sensory, embodied and affective routines of everyday life, help us arrive at thicker understandings of the possible role of media in social life and change?

Finally, we engage with a range of ethnographic studies of lived histories and vernacular cultures of digital media, exploring local meanings to digital genres of work, gaming, dating, memes, blogging, or hacking for instance, but also their intersections with existing cultures of class, difference, disability, gender and sexuality etc. 

Learning Outcomes

Students will acquire a theoretical grasp and methodological acquaintance with: 

1. Digitality and its (ethnographic) Dilemmas 

2. Ethnography in/ of Virtual Worlds 

3. Ethnographic Contexts 

Grading Rubric

Your grade in the course depends on your consistent commitment to complete required readings every week, critically reflect on them, participate in class discussions, and thoughtfully integrate these insights in your short assignments, midterm paper, and final project. The reading selections for each week may range between 75 and 100 pages. 

Grading will be based on: 

Class participation (15): Students are expected to attend classes regularly, complete assigned readings and contribute to discussions. 

Two short assignments (2.5 + 7.5): 

The first short assignment (2.5 points) is to introduce yourself in about 250 words. What is your academic background and what have been your recent reading/ viewing interests? What interests you about the world? What do you hope to get out of this course? Your first assignment which helps me get to know you has a turn it in grade and should be uploaded on GC before the first class, latest by 5 PM on January 20. 

The second short assignment (7.5 points) is a (single) discussion board post. Students will submit a critical review/ reflection on Google Classroom of the assigned readings for the section they sign up for (an online form will be circulated by the course TA). The discussion board post will not exceed 500 words. Discussion board posts are due by 5pm on the day before class, so as to allow adequate time for everyone to read them. You may choose key points that strike you in the readings (make sure that you engage with MOST if not all of the readings for those weeks) and discuss them in relation to broader course themes. Please read the posts of your peers who have signed up on the day before attending class, as they will likely be a starting point for class discussions which your group will anchor. Posts will be submitted/ discussed in batches at the end of weeks 3, 5, 7, 9, 11.

Midterm examination (25%): The mid-term assessment will be a take home overnight examination where you will answer a prompt that will be put up on Google classroom. The question will test your understanding of concepts discussed in class and ability to use/ relate them with/ in emperical contexts. Answer scripts should be uploaded on GC in both word and PDF format by the mentioned deadline.

Digital Ethnography Project (50%): Project grade will be based on components of (provisional) proposal, theoretical care, ethnographic rigor (to be discussed in tutorial discussions), final project and presentation. Ethnographic location in virtual/ physical worlds/ both- is open, as is the subject of inquiry. Faculty Name
Aryya Ghosh [aryya.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Overview: This course will describe the basic concepts of gases, Liquids and solids. Students will learn how to apply the first law of thermodynamics to the open systems. They will also learn how to apply the first law of thermodynamics to the nozzles, diffusers, turbines, compressors, throttling valves, mixing chambers, heat exchangers, pipe and duct flow . They will learn how to calculate thermal efficiency and coefficient of performance for heat engine, refrigerators and
heat pumps.

Syllabus:
The states of gases : Ideal  and real  gases, the van der Waals  equation, critical temperature, the principle  of  corresponding  states, Kinetic  theory  of gases. (3 lectures)
 Liquid states : Surface tension, Viscosity, temperature dependence on surface tension. (1 lecture)
Solid states : Crystal structures, Bragg’s law, crystal  lattices, cubic  lattices (Face-centred,Body-centred etc.) (2 lectures)
Laws of Thermodynamics: Intensive and extensive variables; state and path functions; isolated, closed and open systems; zeroth law of thermodynamics; Concept of heat, work, internal energy and statement of first law; enthalpy, H; relation between heat capacities, second law of thermodynamics, entropy , free energy (G). (7 lectures)
Thermochemistry: Standard states; Heats of reaction; enthalpy of formation of molecules and ions and enthalpy of combustion and its applications; Laws of thermochemistry; bond energy, bond dissociation energy and resonance energy from thermochemical data, Kirchhoff’s equations. ( 4 lectures)
Chemical cells, reversible and irreversible cells with examples. Electromotive force of a cell and its measurement, Nernst equation; Standard electrode (reduction) potential and its application to different kinds of half-cells. (2 lectures)
Rate of a reaction, order and molecularity of a reaction, determination of order and rate constant of the reaction, Arrhenius equation ( 5 lectures)

Learning Outcomes

1. Describe basic concepts of gases, Liquids and  solids.

2. Apply the first law of thermodynamics to the open systems.

3. Assess thermodynamic applications using second law of thermodynamics.

4. Apply the first law of thermodynamics to the nozzles, diffusers, turbines, compressors, throttling valves, mixing chambers, heat exchangers, pipe and duct flow

5. Calculate thermal efficiency and coefficient of performance for heat engine, refrigerators and heat pumps.

Faculty Name
Arghya Bhattacharya [arghya.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in] ,Maitree Jain [maitree.jain_asp25@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sameer Rangwala [sameer.rangwala_asp25@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course focuses on the pricing of financial assets. We will talk mainly about the pricing assets in the equity market, but later, we will also discuss options (puts & calls). The course revolves around different models, methods, and approaches that might help us identify mispriced financial assets, which could help us design a reasonably good portfolio. These methods and models have some economic or accounting rationale behind them, and some are based on groundbreaking papers published in the last century. Despite all that, a student in this course would eventually realize that no one model/ method is enough to help us understand the true value of a financial asset. In fact, it is extremely hard to explain why a given object has a particular value and check whether that object is overpriced/ underpriced. Renowned statistician George Box once said - "all models are wrong, but some are useful." That is what we will try to do in this course - study some models that have been useful in the context of asset pricing. To be specific, we will start with a modern interpretation of Talmudic investing strategy, Markowitz portfolio selection (and maybe some of the later variants if time or your interest permits), factor/ index models, capital asset pricing model (CAPM), and its variants, arbitrage pricing theory, Fama-French three-factor model (maybe briefly discuss the more recent 5-factor model), efficient market hypothesis, equity valuation models, and later we will study options, put-call parity, Black-Scholes' options pricing.

This is a rigorous course, a math- and statistics-based course. If such things tire you, if you are looking for a storytelling, case studies-based approach, or only a DCF-based approach, then this course is probably not for you.

This course is especially useful for forecasting business time series such as sales, and expenditures, and macroeconomic time series such as GDP, interest rate, inflation, etc.

The course will introduce some of the basics of time-series econometrics before moving on to the main topics in forecasting. You will learn the ways to examine and prepare data before forecasting. Faculty Name
Ekanto Ghosh [ekanto.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ,Nikhil Sud [nikhil.sud1@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sagar Singhal [sagar.singhal@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Product management is one of the most sought-after functions in today’s organizations, whether in technology product firms or elsewhere. Technology firms differentiate from their competitors based on how user-centered their products are, and non-tech firms such as banks similarly aim to stay competitive by implementing product-based thinking in their technology offerings. 

Digital product managers who can drive product vision and business growth have hence become critical to modern firms. Initially a Silicon Valley phenomenon, the growing importance of product management – a cross functional discipline which comprises of a deep focus on customers and design, emphasizes the centrality of data in making decisions and the importance of keeping abreast of evolving technological and market dynamics, and utilizes business metrics to evaluate the success of technological innovations – now means that product managers can be found in firms across sectors and industries. The product function is hence a critical differentiator that determines whether a technology product satisfies user needs in a seamless way, ensuring rapid adoption by customers, or becomes a hindrance towards achieving business goals. 

This product management course will teach important skills necessary to be an effective product manager and build, launch, and grow successful digital products. Key focus areas include assessing customer pain points, designing a compelling product vision, leveraging product analytics, and working effectively across functions, including engineering, UX and senior management. Students will engage in group exercises and case discussions.

Faculty Name
Deepali Singh [deepali.singh@ashoka.edu.in] ,Ekanto Ghosh [ekanto.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ,Rahul Bhasin [rahul.bhasin@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sagar Singhal [sagar.singhal@ashoka.edu.in] ,Anushka Mittal [anushka.mittal_asp25@ashoka.edu.in] ,Siddharth Chandak [siddharth.chandak_ug25@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

"Do you have questions like: Should I invest in bonds, stocks, real estate, mutual
funds, or gold? Should I invest in a company that is fundamentally strong, or one that
is currently very cheap in the market? How do I judge whether the current share price
I see on the Zerodha screen reflects the true value? The market companions are
trading at a very high P/E ratio compared to this stock—does that make it a good
investment? Which technological innovations will yield extraordinary returns? What
characteristics make a company adaptable to change? As a student without access to
management, how can I analyze a company? What should I look for in an annual
report? How should I think about an industry? What checklist should be followed
before making an investment? People say this company will grow by 20%—how did
they arrive at that number? Can management turnarounds happen? What are the
different profit models, and how do you identify them? How did investors like Warren
Buffett make money? What did they see that others did not? What is the concept of a
'moat'? What’s the difference between the value and price of a share? Which stock
should I buy?.........
You'll find answers to all these questions and many more in the course.
The Fundamentals of Investing course offers a thorough exploration of investment
principles, designed to prepare students for both personal and professional
investment management. Spanning 26 sessions and worth 4 credits, the course is
structured into four comprehensive modules that cover a wide range of investment
topics and strategies.
The course content begins with an introduction to various investment options,
including deposits, debt, equity, private equity, real estate, mutual funds, and
commodities. Students will learn to evaluate the relevance and potential payoffs
associated with different asset classes while understanding the psychological factors
that influence investment decisions. Key financial concepts such as the time value of money and discounted cash flows are introduced early on, providing a solid
foundation for further study. Additionally, students engage in practical exercises,
including asset allocation strategies and stock-picking frameworks, enhancing their
analytical skills in real-world contexts.
The students will go through an intensive checklist and learn different tests to
evaluate stocks. These include, but are not limited to, the macro test, value test,
growth test, profitability test, timing and transaction strategy, and over 25 other
considerations in the market. Students will not only learn various parameters and
how to apply different tests to stocks, but they will also build assumptions and learn
how to forecast the parameters in these tests.
This course is applicable in numerous settings, from personal finance management to
corporate investment strategies. Students will develop critical skills such as risk
assessment, valuation techniques, and behavioral finance insights. These skills are
essential for making informed investment decisions and understanding market
dynamics. Furthermore, the course emphasizes the importance of macroeconomic
factors and government policies on investment returns, equipping students with a
holistic view of the investing landscape.
Industry relevance is a core aspect of this course. Taught by experienced
professionals like Rahul Bhasin, Managing Partner at Baring Private Equity Partners
India, and Deepali Singh, an expert in corporate finance and investment banking,
students benefit from insights drawn from real-world experiences in private equity
and financial markets. The faculty's extensive backgrounds ensure that students are
exposed to current industry practices and challenges.
Throughout the course, participants will delve into advanced topics such as venture
capital dynamics, leveraged buyouts, and the implications of technological
innovations on market structures. They will also explore environmental sustainability issues related to investments, preparing them for contemporary challenges faced by
investors today.
The course will conclude with a stock presentation on international stocks, where
students will need to understand the fundamentals of every aspect of a new country,
market, and its people. This exercise helps them grasp how small factors can have a
significant impact and learn to think from scratch, setting aside any biases.

Overview

Course Title: Mapping Environmental Change: Concepts and Skills

Level: 2000 level

Instructor Details: Dr. Madhusudan MD
Office Hours: Thursday afternoons

Course Description:

Discover the dynamic stories of our changing planet in this elective course, where science meets technology to unravel environmental shifts. This course dives into the conceptual challenges of monitoring environmental change, alongside imparting practical skills in geospatial analysis and remote sensing. It combines hands-on lab sessions involving data exploration with critical discussions on the causes and consequences of land and water transformations. By the end of the semester, students will grasp the essential concepts and perspectives, and gain an insight into tools and skills needed to analyse environmental changes and tell their compelling, data-driven stories of our changing planet.

While the course is proposed in the context of environmental changes, the concepts and skills are agnostic to disciplines and can be used for mapping changes in various other fields across social sciences.

Tentative Progression Plan:

  1. The Planet In State: understanding the earth’s climatic, biophysical, and socio-ecological dimensions
  2. The Planet In Flux: understanding what on earth is changing, how and why; describing patterns, understanding processes
  3. The Planet In Representation: representing the earth’s climatic, biophysical and socio-ecological patterns and processes as geospatial data; understanding data structures, algorithms, visualisation & modelling
  4. Working with Planetary Points, Lines and Shapes: an introduction to vector data and basic vector data creation, analyses and visualisation.
  5. Working with Planetary Pixels and Stacks: an introduction to raster data, Analysing and visualising variation over space, and change over time.
  6. Making Maps: Showing change, telling stories; reflections on positionality, rigour and bias in map making and story telling.
  7. [Optional Advanced Topic] Simplifying and Automating Work with Code

Overview

The present course uses gender as a lens for looking into the history of medieval and early-modern South Asia. It especially looks at the categories of ‘masculinity’ and ‘ femininity’, how these were constructed and mapped during the period, in relation to one another. In doing so, it considers how evolving ideals of manliness came to inform kingship and domesticity in the Sultanate and the Mughal period. To what extent was the courtly and domestic spaces segregated? What were the ways in which the royal women responded and negotiated with the prescribed norms and participate in politics and court society ? How had art and architectural productions served as sites of gendered patronage, aesthetics, labour and performance ? These are some of the questions that we will address in this course. The course will also explore the non-royal social and political groups, the concubines, dancing girls, women slaves and labourers as well as the gender-liminal figure of the eunuch. The processes of gender marginalisation and defiance of gender normativity will also be taken up, particularly through a study of some of the women saints who challenged societal hierarchies in their pursuit of spirituality. The course will culminate with a discussion on how the medieval notions of gender normativity were reoriented and subverted at the wake of colonialism in the eighteenth century.

Overview

In India, the first moveable printing press was set up in Goa by a Spanish Jesuit missionary in 1556. Prior to Print engages with various dimensions of writing systems and cultures of record-keeping in the Indian subcontinent for approximately two thousand years until the introduction of this technological innovation in the middle of the 16th century. Through a wide array of premodern historical sources—stone and copper plate inscriptions, normative texts, letters, biographies and autobiographies—the course explores questions around articulations of historical consciousness, the relationship between orality and literacy, conversations between texts and visual images, and the materiality of writing. Included among such sources are two unique texts—a 15th century manual for scribes and professional letter writers as well as a delectable cookbook of the early 16th century. Designed as an advanced research course for fourth-year students, this course, through its focus on the production and circulation of various sources, foregrounds aspects of kingship and courtly cultures, networks of merchants and pilgrims, and the establishment of language orders and literary cultures in premodern India.

How did the material medium of paper facilitate this literary flourish? These are some of the questions that this course will address. The course will culminate by charting the rise of Urdu literary tradition as reflective of the political flux of the eighteenth century. By the end of the course, students will have an overview of the literary history of history writing in medieval and early modern South Asia.

Faculty Name
Tithi Bhatnagar [tithi.bhatnagar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The Psychology of Subjective Well-Being focuses on the strengths and virtues which enable individuals and communities to live fulfilling lives. On the individual level, the focus is on subjective well-being (SWB), which is generally referred to as happiness. The term subjective well-being (SWB) refers to people's evaluations of their lives including cognitive judgments such as life satisfaction and affective evaluations (moods and emotions) such as positive and negative emotional feelings. People are said to have high SWB if satisfied with their life and experience frequent positive and infrequent negative emotions.
In this age of rapid transformation, societies are changing and there is chaos. A person otherwise very efficient and capable can suffer a breakdown in the absence of handling himself or herself psychologically. It is about individual well-being. Understanding this concept can be very beneficial for leading a rewarding life in every sphere of an individual's life, both internal and external. The understanding of well-being/happiness (used synonymously) can be a key differentiator towards leading a rewarding life in every sphere of an individual's life. It helps individuals identify what is important for them to lead a good and meaningful life. It helps them realize their inner potential and the strength of their psychological treasure to mitigate life circumstances – how to develop the right approach to face and deal with adverse conditions. The course aims to equip students with strategies to optimize their SWB.

Learning Outcomes


● To understand the basic concepts, theories, frameworks, correlates, and measurement issues in Subjective Well-Being
● To facilitate the understanding and definition of students’ sense of well-being.
● To learn concepts that help develop a positive approach toward life and life events.
● To develop a knowledge of well-being interventions and critically engage with them to find one’s best fit.
● To appreciate, assess, and apply the various strategies that can be used to optimize SWB.

Climate change has played a critical role in shaping the biological diversity in our planet. This course aims to introduce participants to the effects of climate change to biotic diversity, biogeography and human evolution focusing specifically on:

a. evolution and diversity in the last few million years, and

b. the contribution of genetics and genomics in understanding the evolution of natural populations during this period.

Overview

In autonomous vehicles, robots, and many other physical settings, at any state a number of decisions need to be made. Each decision comes with an immediate reward but more importantly leads to another probabilistically selected state. In reinforcement learning, we learn optimal decisions through trial and error where good decisions are reinforced and bad ones are punished. This learning regime, especially when combined with deep learning, is an incredibly powerful tool for artificial and augmented intelligence. In this course we will study the underlying theory and learn to code-up many practical and intricate applications.

Topics covered:

Markov Chains, Markov Decision Processes, Dynamic Programming, Value and Policy Iteration, Temporal Difference Learning, Q-Learning, functional approximations,  Bandit methods, Neural Networks and Deep Q learning, other deep RL methods

Overview

"Whether it be in the urban dystopias of Wakanda in the Black Panther films or in the sinister brooding forest landscapes of Ghana that become the mise-en-scene for staging the brutal violence of West African armed insurgencies in Beasts of No Nation, representations of “Africa” in contemporary “global” media often tend to reduce the complex and diverse lived realities of the peoples of this continent to mythic binaries of victimhood and resilience. This course attempts to unpack such an “Image of Africa”, as Chinua Achebe famously described it, through a closer examination of African literary modernities and the larger colonial and postcolonial histories of African nations around the time of their formations as independent sovereign states. Focusing primarily on the novel as a marker of and vehicle for the “modern” in African literary cultures, with the example of writers such as Ayi Kwei Armah, Assia Djebar, Camara Laye and Ama Ata Aidoo, we will be working towards understanding the experiential pluralities of colonization and postcoloniality that underscore African literary modernities."

courseTitle: Liberalism, Empire, and the Nation-State: A View from South Asia
description:
Liberalism, Empire, and the Nation-State: A View from South Asia [POL-3114] [POL-3114-1]

Faculty Name
Sushmita Nath [sushmita.nath@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sana Chowdhury [sana.chowdhury_asp25@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Canonical ideas and institutions in modern political thought, such as the state and the civil society, nation and nationalism, liberal rights and equality, democracy and citizenship are generally considered to have emerged in the modern Western world of Europe and North America. At the same time, unmodern or retrograde institutions and practices, such as the caste system or communal politics, are assumed to be culturally and historically embedded in South Asian thought and practice unrelated to the expansion of the Empire and colonial conquest. The underlying assumption of all this being that modern emancipatory and universal ideas originated in the West – the Enlightenment being the well-spring of these modern universals. As such, when the non-West or the so-called global south is engaged within such contexts it is either to retrieve “raw data” or practices which maybe contrasted to the (Western) universals as “alternative” ideas and practices, or to point out the “degraded” versions of  the “original” ideas and institutions of the West.

The burgeoning field of global history however seeks to highlight the relational constitution of the modern world by unearthing global entanglements of ideas, institutions, people, and things. It points out how even European universals were shaped as a result of the colonial encounter. While global history highlights the interconnected nature of the modern world, comparative social and political theory challenges the dominant assumption that concept-formation and theory-building is exclusively the remit of Western political theory. In short, universalizable ideas and ideals can also be found in non-western thought. Comparative theory, or “theory from the global south” therefore draws attention to non-western thought, such as in South Asia, Africa, China, and Latin America, and shows how socio-political actors in the global south or in post-colonial societies did not simply inherit ideas and institutions as derivative of the West. Rather, it was not only that the non-Western world actively engaged with canonical ideas and practices and in that process reshaped or rejected them but also that universal ideas and ideals emerged in relation to and in the context of colonialism and conquest. 

With a focus on modern South Asia, this course brings together insights from global history and political theory from the global south to not only demonstrate the co-constitutive nature of ideas, concepts, institutions and practices but also retrieve forgotten or recessed emancipatory ideas and practices of the non-western world, which were marginalised as a result of the expansion of the empire and colonial domination in the eighteenth and the nineteenth centuries, and the emergence of a new world order in the twentieth century based on the model of the Westphalian system of states. We will begin with an examination of liberalism’s relationship to the Empire and colonialism, then look at subject-formation in the context of colonialism, the emergence of the modern state, nationalism, and civil society, and finally look at the effects of such modern ideas and institutions on traditional social formations, such as caste and patriarchy. Students are expected to read approx. 80-100 pages per week as preparatory readings.

 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Please note: Regarding prerequisites, a background in Introduction to Political Theory or related courses is desired but not necessary. 

Required Readings, Background Readings, and Suggested Readings

For this course it is highly recommended (but not necessary) that you have basic knowledge of political theory, especially aspects relating to nationalism, state, power, democracy, and civil society, as well as a basic understanding of theories of Liberalism (like, Locke, Mill, Rousseau etc.), Marxism, and Feminism. In the syllabus, apart from the required readings, I have also mentioned, where needed, “background readings,” in order to give you an idea of the kind of theoretical knowledge you are expected to have. We will discuss some of these background readings (where necessary) but these readings are NOT formally part of the syllabus and therefore you are not expected to read them. Similarly, the suggested readings are also not part of the syllabus but may help you to think through issues that we will discuss in this course.

The presentation will be graded by peers present in class. The details of this will be explained in class. Apart from this, you will have a mid-term take home exam in the form of an essay that will count for 30% of your final grade. Your final take-home exam, also in the form of an essay, will count 40% of your grade. The mid-term essay should be 1800 words and the final essay should be 2800 words. description:
Empire, Utopia and War in the Twentieth Century (1900-1950) [POL-2128/ IR-2064] [POL-2128/ IR-2064-1]

Faculty Name
Dilip Simeon [dilip.simeon@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Empire, Utopia and War in the Twentieth Century

We learn history not in order to know how to behave or how to succeed, but to know who we are - Leszek Kołakowski, The Idolatry of Politics

It seemed to us that we were witnessing a total break in the evolution of mankind, the complete collapse of man as a rational being - Heda Margolius Kovály, Under a Cruel Star: A Life in Prague 1941–1968

History is the odyssey of the unhappy consciousness - Stanley Rosen, G.W.F. Hegel: An Introduction to the Science of Wisdom

Elie Halevy's book on the period following the Great War of 1914-1918 is named The Era of Tyrannies: Essays on Socialism and War (1938). His interpretation of the war and its aftermath was prescient: it included the nationalisation of economies, and the emergence of militant populism. This course will be an introductory survey of major historical developments in the first half of the twentieth century as something unprecedented in their significance for human society. These developments include the Great War; the Bolshevik Revolution and the consolidation of the USSR; the rise of Fascism and Nazism; the crises of the 1930's (such as the Great Depression, the Spanish Civil War, the Chinese Revolution, and the Sino-Japanese conflict); and the Second World War - the imperial contest which Richard Overy has described as the last imperial war.

The events we shall study include the collapse of multinational empires; the reorganisation of the world order; the rise of militarist nationalism and economic autarky, and the emergence of despotic regimes in the USSR, Italy, Japan, and Germany. 

I will also introduce students to ideological currents such as political theology, romantic nationalism, existentialism, historicism and the subversion of justice. Thinkers will include Sigmund Freud, Vladimir Lenin, Carl Schmitt, Ernst Fraenkel, Hannah Arendt, Ernst Junger, Martin Heidegger, Leo Strauss and Mahatma Gandhi. 

The course will be taught in an interlinked manner; and proceed in chronological sequence, with digressions into ideologies, moral and political philosophy, geopolitics, and questions of law.

As a note of caution, the wide scope of our course will require hard work.

Students should avoid the use of smartphones and laptops in class, as they distract me; and I would like us all to make full use of the time we have at our disposal.

NB: 1/ As a note of caution, the scope of our course will require hard work. You will have access to a PDF archive, which you will be free to use and download, in part or entirely. 

2/ In addition, I ask my students to avoid the use of smartphones and laptops in class, as they distract me; and I would like us all to make full use of the time we have at our disposal.

3/ Grading policies will be provided later. Broadly speaking, you will be given a list of prompts (rather than questions), and asked to comment on them. I have always evaluated final assignments personally and will continue to do so.

4/ Representative samples of general readings are given below. A detailed reading list is attached in a PDF below. This is an extensive list; be assured that all of it is not required reading, but made available in order for you to get an idea of the scholarship on the subject. So do not panic. Specific readings along with AV materials will be given to you prior to each class
