A closer understanding of the history of a momentous period of human history; whose ramifications -  both geopoltical and idelogical, and philosophical - are still unfolding in the contemporary world.

Overview

Too often UG theses are composed under pressure in the final weeks of a semester. This seminar is a two credit course that aims to prevent this from happening. Using extended discussions, in addition to writing and reading tasks in weekly seminars, all tailored to individual projects, ASP students will receive a secondary support to their thesis which will ensure they stay on track and produce a thesis of merit. By all means, students will set the content of the course but the seminar will set the pace. This means that the seminar will be tailored to six individual theses but will give them a reliable path to pursue along. 

Learning Outcomes

The outcome shall be an enhanced thesis document in terms of clarity, and an ability to explain and present this document in a succinct manner.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Students need to have written their thesis proposals, and identified a specific thesis project they wish to work on and develop in order to be admitted to this course. Other than this, there is no other pre-requisite.

 

Given the cross-disciplinary constitution of the class, reading will be secondary to personalized and active work on individual projects. However, some classes will be dedicated to going over readings such as Umberto Eco's How to Write a Thesis or Willard V.O. Quine's 'Two Dogmas of Empiricism'.  Such texts will help encourage clearer writing and clearer thinking.

1. Participation in the seminars (engagement with the process and the work of the peers) - presentations, class discussions, in-class assignments.

Overview

This is a seminar for ASP students across disciplines who have chosen to write a thesis, so that they may better fulfill their subject-specific requirements. This will function as an incubatory environment for their work and as a structured mechanism for feedback and support during the writing phase. Participating in this seminar will mean that thesis students receive an assured level of writing mentorship, participate in a scaffolding and systematic process of composing a long-form work, and gain access to a writing cohort. They will develop techniques that will help in their thesis writing, structuring, and presentation. This will run as a 2-credit course that students take once a week for 90 minutes. The class size has been kept small in order to produce sustained engagement with thesis projects over the course of a semester. The Instructor is not a thesis supervisor nor a subject matter expert. Instead, their role is to provide a space for fourth years that functions like an ICT: a shared community where students who are all in a similar position can learn generalisable techniques that will enrich their academic work in their major of choice.

Over the 13 weeks of classes, students will read example theses across different fields, learn techniques of note-making, participate in argument-clarification exercises, work on writing-specific techniques (chapterisation, transitions, framing arguments, writing introductions,), do multiple presentations of their work (including a mock viva).  At the end of the course students should be expected to produce writing of a high standard, communicate their work to those outside their field, connect and learn from ASP students across disciplines, and reflect on their own research trajectory.

Graduate Writing Seminar [CT-6001] [CT-6001-1]

Faculty Name
Devapriya Roy [devapriya.roy@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Learning to Write Writing to Learn in the Sciences

Students need to identify a specific individual writing project, in order to be admitted to this course (eg: a detailed lab report, an early-PhD research report, a literature review, an essay for a popular science journal, a chapter from their PhD thesis, a grant proposal, or other). The course will help them to realise this project by providing structured and systematic engagements with writing in a classroom environment, and sustained mentorship. This will include various W-T-L (Writing to Learn) exercises, short writing assignments, studying the structure of an academic paper, reading exemplar papers within the student’s chosen form, narrative-building, using Generative AI, communicating research findings. At the end of the course, students should be expected to have a clear understanding of the form in which they are working, produce writing of a good standard, be able to communicate their work to others, and reflect on their own research trajectory. 

 

Learning Outcomes

The course will have two components:

a reading-and-writing component designed in classic ICT mode, where we will take students through the conceptual elements underpinning research, coupled with W-T-L (Writing to Learn) exercises that include short writing assignments to a wide range of prompts.

the project component, where students will work on their individual projects on their own but maintain a short reflection log on how they solve the narrative problems they encounter while working on their projects.

It is almost as though the course has a braided format, where the first strand is meant to help illuminate – and solve – the specific writing problems that occur in the practice of the second. But the link is not a direct one. In fact, we will mix up the more “useful” components – the structure of scientific research papers, say, or analyzing argumentation moves in an “Opinion” piece published in Nature – with ones less apparently “useful”. For example: Can you write three paragraphs describing exactly what you do in the lab? Be as specific in your descriptions as possible. (There is enough evidence to show that low stakes writing exercises of this sort, specifically deployed in STEM classrooms, help students become much better writers in their high stakes writing projects, such as their PhD thesis, journal papers or grant applications.)

 

 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

This will be a 4-credit class that will meet once every week for three hours. The faculty member working with the students is not a subject-matter expert. Instead, their training is in writing pedagogy and, specifically, in providing critical feedback to a student through a structured mechanism of meeting. They will respond to the particular needs of both the group as a whole and the individual student. The student will be graded on their familiarity with the components of research writing; a portfolio of all the formative low-stakes writing exercises; a presentation of their work to a mixed audience; a process journal that records their writing struggles with their main project. The students’ mentor/supervisor will need to be apprised of this course’s aims and methods and may be consulted by the faculty member teaching the course.

Grading Rubric

To be provided at the beginning of the course.

Attendance Policy

The class will meet once a week for three hours. The standard Ashoka rules on attendance and academic integrity will apply.

courseTitle: Dots and Dashes: The Politics of Space, Territory, and Maps
description:
Dots and Dashes: The Politics of Space, Territory, and Maps [POL-2129] [POL-2129-1]

Overview

Earlier than I could learn,
The maps had been coloured in
When I pleaded, the kings told me
Nothing was left to explore
- Margaret Atwood


Does a map belong to a country or does a country belong to a map? How do we imagine or visualize the body of the state? Do borders prevent people from coming in or getting out? The carving of the world into empires and then states and their territorial representation as political maps, is a specific and recent historical development. This course seeks to trace this development by examining the intersection between geography, power, and politics, as showcased in the ways in which we understand spaces, places, and territories. In the process, the course hopes to explore how we embody space as individuals, citizens, and humans. Along the way we try to ask some fun questions, such as - does cartography represent the physical or the ideological conception of a nation? Does empire’s shadow still impact the ways in which the world functions today? Does cyberspace exist as a virtual abstraction or is there a material politics that undergirds its existence? And finally, is radical geography even possible and if so, what would that entail?

description:
Punjabi Poetry, Singing and Mystic Dancing [PA-2024/ ENG-2784] [PA-2024/ ENG-2784-1]

Faculty Name
Navtej Johar [navtej.johar@ashoka.edu.in] ,Yashika Pawan Singla [yashika.singla_asp25@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course will focus on the blending of love, mysticism, politics and performativity that has historically remained integral to the poetry of Punjab. Beginning with the works of Baba Farid (12 century), we will proceed to read Baba Nanak along with a host of Sufi poets: Shah Hussain, Sultan Bahu, Bulleh Shah, Waris Shah, Hashim and Quadir Yaar. Amongst the moderns, we will read Puran Singh, Munir Niazi, Amrita Pritam, Faiz Ahmad Faiz, Shiv Batalvi, Surjit Patar and finally the fiery Paash.  

Touching upon the history, ethos and metaphors of both, the undivided and divided Punjab, as well as the lilt and cadence of various dialects, the course will offer an introduction to different genres of recitation, singing, even mystic-dancing that has accompanied poetry in Punjab over the centuries. We will listen to some existing recordings and even attempt to recite or sing select poems—just to be able to (re)wrap our tongues around the language. The readings, the practice and the improvisations will all be geared to explore the fluid give-and-take between the body, language, terrain and historical context. The underline thrust of the course would be to see how the poetic word touches and moves the body, evokes social, cultural and spiritual resonance, and how history may be reflected through poetry. Special attention will be placed upon the sacred-erotic nature of Sufi poetry of Punjab, which in some cases can also be homoerotic.  

 

Learning Outcomes

The students will be introduced to Punjabi poetry (12 century onwards) and also learn about the time periods of the respective poets.

We will read the works of major poets of Punjab, listen to recordings of some, and attempt to recite, sing and improvise to some of the poems.

We will be focusing on different poets each week and the students will be required to post their weekly reflections (150-250 words) on the readings, improvisations and readings of the week; and submit a final paper (2000 words) at the end of the term; the proposal for the final paper will be due in the first week of April.

Overview

This course examines the making of cities during the Sultanate and early Mughal periods. Students will learn to interpret architecture as both cultural expression and technical accomplishment. The creation of a city reflects a society’s power, wealth, knowledge, and imagination, often embodying its aspirations through the built environment, spatial organization, and ecological relationships. In Islamicate cultures moreover, oral narratives, Sufi lyric traditions, and illustrated manuscripts are crucial in defining cities. They shape the discourses through which cities are perceived and remembered. This course integrates architectural, visual, poetic, and narrative materials that inform the spatial imagination of early modern South Asian cities.

Learning Outcomes

Students will learn to:

1. Understand the cultural exchange and innovation that defined Sultanate and Mughal Architecture.

2. Analyse how local and global influences, and environmental factors intersect in urban design.

3. Explore the representation of cities in art, literature, and history.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Readings will be shared in class. Students will be required to participate in Two Onsite Workshops ( Itineraries subject to modifications). Attendance for the field trips is compulsory.

1. Tughlaqabad, Tomb of Ghiyasuddin Tughlaq, Begampuri Masjid/Khirki Masjid, Kotla Firoz Shah/Hauz Khas (Date: Early/Mid-February)

The Tughlaq heritage of Delhi is pivotal to understanding the evolution of planned cities in the region. However, it is often overlooked in architectural histories, which tend to focus on early Sultanate and Mughal architecture. The workshop will aim to bring this heritage into focus.

2. Agrasen ki Baoli, Dinapanah (Purana Qila), Khair-ul Manzil (Maham Anga's Mosque), Monuments within Lodhi Gardens/ Humayun's Tomb Complex (Date: Early March, before mid-semester break)

This workshop will provide an understanding of the diverse functions of urban structures such as stepwells, forts, mosques, and tombs, while exploring mid-16th century Delhi's architectural transition between Lodhi, Suri, and early Mughal styles.

Faculty Name
Kalyan Sekhar Chakraborty [kalyan.chakraborty@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

‘You are what you eat’ is a well-known truism, but what we are and what we ate both have undergone a major transformation during the course of human evolution and recent history. The study of ancient foodways is not merely an understanding of what people ate in the past rather it’s a process of understanding the interrelation between human diet and ecological, biological, social and ideological processes. Therefore, the study of foodways can potentially provide us with sufficient evidence to reconstruct the social, cultural, political, economic, technological, and ecological aspects of ancient societies. Once regarded as a rather unexciting field of studies associated with basic subsistence, paleodietary studies have been rejuvenated in recent years by both recent advances in scientific methods and new theoretical perspectives. In this course, we aim to first understand the major shifts in human food practices, and the major theoretical and methodological advancements to reconstruct ancient diets and then how the information gathered can potentially be used to reconstruct social, political, climatic, and economic aspects of past societies and the health and wellbeing of the indigenous population practicing traditional diet.

5 Reading Reviews: (5*5) = 25 (You have to submit at least 6 out of which the best 5 will be counted towards the final marks)

Before class begins, you will submit a short synthesis (approx. 1 page single-spaced) on that week’s readings. The reviews should be written with the weekly theme in mind, synthesize material, and provide a critical evaluation of ideas. Students are expected to submit Six reviews throughout the semester (i.e., you may choose particular weeks that interests you), however, only the best five of them will be marked. This one extra opportunity will give you some extra room if you miss any submissions or score poorly than expected. The presentation should include summative information like research goals and objectives, data analysis, interpretation etc., but also demonstrate the development of critical thinking skills. Each presentation should include at least one example or case study that matches the topic but are different from the case studies included in the readings, a popular example would be appreciated, but students are advised to be aware of websites and popular articles that include inappropriate information. References must follow the Society for American Archaeology style guide, and at least 10 references should be cited. Details of this assignment will be discussed during the first week of the class.

Faculty Name
Devesh Roy [devesh.roy@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Course Overview:

In recent times, a series of technological, institutional, and political developments have fueled a significant globalization of production processes across countries (Antras, 2020). Firms are organized on a global scale (for example, in the production of iPhones and bicycles) and choose to offshore parts, components, or services to producers in different countries. Global Supply Chain (GSC) and Global Value Chain (GVC) analysis have been the leading frameworks for analyzing and understanding market integration and the linkages between globalization and development.

This course is designed to equip students with the essential tools used in GSC and GVC analysis, and to apply these tools and knowledge across various countries and industries. The course will cover the theories, methodology and case studies across different contexts. The course will utilize a wide variety of readings on theoretical frameworks from international trade, and then deal with empirical developments, focusing on participation and positioning in GVCs (both at backward and forward GVC).

The course will also explore some specific governance issues within transnational supply chains, and assess the economic, social and environmental effects of globalized supply and value chains across agriculture, manufacturing and services. Students will be required to prepare papers on country-based or industry-specific GVCs, with at least one case relating to developing countries or emerging nations, and one to developed or emerged economies. As part of the policy role in specific GVC integration, we expect students to produce a set of policy briefs and studies, mainly to ensure the participation and positioning of different groups and regions in moving up the value chains.

Learning Outcomes

The course will introduce the idea of transformational change in which the exchange takes place beyond looking at gross exports into trade in value added flows where countries settle on a point in value chains that themselves transcend international borders. The main objective of the course is to help students learn and understand the supply chains in all commodities ranging from an airplane to cell phones to a chocolate where before becoming a final product they crosses international borders several times. The course is mildly theoretical in understanding the concepts but is largely applied and empirical. This course is designed to give students the essential tools used in Global Supply Chain analysis, and to apply these tools in writing an integrated course papers either individually or in a group for a country and industry (decided with consultation). Course intends to familiarize students with theories, empirical  instructors are intimately familiar with the theories, empirical methodology and real world applications.

The first half of the course will introduce students to the idea of global supply chains drawing both from economic theory but also management science. The course will cover both the historical evolution of global supply chains in different contexts that bear on outcomes  sector outcomes and policies; as well the way ahead as wide ranging technological and institutional revolutions take place. The second half of the course will study real world examples that are applications with different contexts in market outreach, expansion and in response to shocks. It will dwell in the interplay between domestic and foreign value added.  We will try to understand the evolution of the key concepts and how they relate to the evolving supply chains.

Students will be using basic skills in simple software like excel and Stata. Exercises will be given heavily focused on case studies seeking analytical perspective. A very good resource that we will refer to is https://www.globalvaluechains.org/. There are other resources from OECD, UN organizations.

As outlined in global value chains center at Duke we will be looking at GVC lead firms and their global supply chains; and (2) country upgrading trajectories, which define how countries are tied into global industries, and their economic, social and environmental impacts.

Archaeology derives from the Greek term arkhaiologia, meaning “the study of ancient things.” It is the scientific study of past peoples and cultures through the analysis of natural and cultural remains. Over the years, archaeology has evolved into a highly interdisciplinary field, integrating contributions from disciplines such as History, Anthropology, Physics, Chemistry, Environmental and Spatial Sciences, Biology, Mathematics, and Computer Science to name a few. Whether your major is in the sciences, social sciences, or humanities, if you are curious about the nuances of human history and eager to learn how your field can contribute to the study of the past, this course is designed for you.

Theories of Democracy [POL-2126/ PHI-2775] [POL-2126/ PHI-2775-1]

Faculty Name
Vivek Yadav [vivek.yadav@ashoka.edu.in] ,Gauri Malhotra [gauri.malhotra_ug25@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What democracy is depends to a large extent upon what we understand it to be. However, instead of a consensus on what democracy is or what it ought to be, these questions are marked by a recalcitrant disagreement. Over the course of its two hundred and fifty years long history, modern representative democracy has been understood in different ways by its admirers and critics. These different interpretations of democracy, which in many ways are at odds with each other, do not fit together into a unitary theory of democracy, but constitute a complex, internally differentiated, body of thought. This course offers an introduction to this polyphonic tradition of modern democratic thought. It is organized in the form of a debate and dialogue between different competing interpretations of democracy. We shall read the various strands of contemporary democratic theory--the minimalist, deliberative, epistemic, representative, republican, populist, and plebiscitary conceptions of democracy--and their mutual disagreements. 

Learning Outcomes

The course aims to provide students a firm grounding in contemporary democratic theory, equipping them with conceptual tools to navigate a wide range of current debates and issues.

courseTitle: An Empire of Tales: The Alexander Narratives of the Ancient World
description:
An Empire of Tales: The Alexander Narratives of the Ancient World [ENG-4144/ HIS-3030] [ENG-4144/ HIS-3030-1]

Faculty Name
Sarah Yona Zweig [sarah.zweig@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Alexander the Great is one of the most iconic figures of the Ancient World. Each age and culture makes its own Alexander. Depicted as prophet and proto-Jesus or demi-God and demon, each Alexander mirrors the spirit and desires of the host culture. Following in the footsteps of Alexander we will travel through time and space, traversing the width of Eurasia and two millennia in tales. Together with Alexander we will encounter topless Amazons and nudist Brahmins, venture into the Land of Darkness and search for the Source of Life. Our class will be an excursion of intrepid explorers who venture into unknown (literary) territories. In the course of this journey we will read excerpts from the Bible, Plutarch, Josephus, the Babylonian Talmud, the Quran and the adaptations of the Greek Alexander Romance in Syriac, Ge’ez, Persian and the languages of mediaeval Europe. We will analyse the transformation of Alexander’s legends in visual culture from manuscript illuminations to their depictions on the screen. We will read texts in fine-grained detail and also learn to zoom out for an overview of the developments of narratives and motifs. Though we will study literature on Alexander in translation, we will supplement our reading with references to the source languages and their literary contexts. In the course of the seminar you will be exposed to topics in historical criticism and narratological studies — What is a stemma? What is an Urtext? How and why do motifs transform?

courseTitle: The Reconstruction of Thought: Muhammad Iqbal and Friedrich Nietzsche
description:
The Reconstruction of Thought: Muhammad Iqbal and Friedrich Nietzsche [ENG-3331/ ENG-4331] [ENG-3331/ ENG-4331-1]

Faculty Name
Huzaifa Omair Siddiqi [huzaifa.siddiqi@ashoka.edu.in] ,Gowri N [gowri.n_asp25@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Friedrich Nietzsche’s philosophy seems to have had two dominant effects in the theoretical currents that sought to recover his thought from Fascist appropriation in the 20th century: a suspicious and cautious deconstruction of given metaphysical systems or the speculative and playful construction of concepts. The question of what is noble, which is perhaps Nietzsche’s most interesting question, is what is repressed in this project (and as such returns to vitiate its egalitarian claims in various ways). In this course we will see how one of South Asia’s first readers of Nietzsche, the Urdu and Persian poet Muhammad Iqbal, gave a centrality to this problem in both his poetry and his philosophical prose. In this course we will read both Nietzsche’s works as well as Iqbal’s poems (in translation) and prose along with some other thinkers of that period like Henri Bergson and A.N. Whitehead. The objective of this course is to come to an understanding of what Iqbal meant by reconstruction and what that entails for our understanding of a political and philosophical position that takes the question of nobility seriously.

Truth and Beauty: Indian Epistemology and Aesthetics [PHI-4365/ VA-4034] [PHI-4365/ VA-4034-1]

Faculty Name
Arindam Chakrabarti [arindam.chakrabarti@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Our cognitive life aims at Truth (even in the post-modern and post-truth era) while our affective, creative and aesthetic life, broadly speaking, aims at Beauty. Though it is fashionable to call both truth and beauty culture-relative and subjective, in recent philosophy as in art-theory, objectivism and realism about aesthetic values are making a slow but steady comeback!  Classical South Asian philosophy has extremely rich-- analytic as well as phenomenological--theories of knowledge/ truth and art/beauty. In this course, we shall first study the main debates in Indian Epistemology (mainly between the Nyāya and the Buddhist schools); and then we shall discuss Indian Aesthetics and Philosophies of Art (the debate across four alternative phenomenologies of aesthetic enjoyment --in literary, visual, dramatic and musical arts), mostly in the context of recent resurgence of interest in the aesthetic epistemology of the 11th century Kashmiri philosopher Abhinavagupta. Just as every Indian theory of truth has to have a nuanced theory of error, Indian  theories of beauty come with sophisticated theories of ugliness and disgust, which we shall discuss in detail, applying Rasa-theory to modern European art, poetry and theater---which is seldom done.

  • Get an overview of some key ideas in global political philosophy.
  • Form some thoughts about the key ideas that we discuss.
  • Get practice with reading, writing, talking about, and thinking about philosophy.

Grading Rubric

There are 4 kinds of assignments in this class: reading quizzes, Perusall annotations, 1,250 word papers, and paper consultations. Late quizzes will have a 10% lower score for every 24 hours they are late, with a maximum reduction of 50%. Late Perusall annotations won’t be accepted. There is no penalty for late papers except that they cannot be revised (and you need some number of on-time papers for certain letter grades).

Reading Quizzes are to help you focus on the important parts of the reading and to get instant feedback on whether you have understood the reading. There is one quiz per reading. The quiz is due 10:00 AM the day we discuss the reading but you should complete it much earlier. The lowest 6 reading quiz scores will be dropped.

Perusall Annotation Assignments allow you to collaboratively annotate the readings by sharing thoughts and questions with fellow students. Canvas has a document detailing examples of annotations you can make on Perusall. Your Perusall annotations are due 10:00 AM the day we discuss the reading but you should write them far earlier. The lowest 6 Perusall annotation scores will be dropped.

1,250 Word Papers give you practice thinking about and writing about important aspects of the topics we cover in this class. They have a word limit of 1,250 words. Prompts for these papers are available on Canvas. Papers will be graded as satisfactory or not yet satisfactory. A satisfactory paper is roughly equivalent to a B+ paper. Any not yet satisfactory paper can be rewritten and turned in again up until the end of the course (May 10 2025). You can only submit two papers per week (including resubmissions), so if you want to rewrite papers, do not leave all your papers until the end.

Paper Consultations consist of discussing your paper with me. These exist to discourage AI use and to give you practice talking about some topic thoroughly and in detail. They are graded satisfactory/unsatisfactory. These are optional. You can request a paper consultation for any paper you’ve turned in.

description:
Biosignals to Well-Being: Exploring Biometrics in Mental and Physical Health [PSY-3027/ BIO-3414] [PSY-3027/ BIO-3414-1]

Faculty Name
Dipanjan Ray Ray [dipanjan.ray@ashoka.edu.in] ,Arijit Bhattacharya [arijit.bhattacharya_phd23@ashoka.edu.in] ,Khushi Mohta [khushi.mohta_ug25@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This interdisciplinary course provides a comprehensive exploration of biosignals and their applications in understanding mental and physical health. The course covers key physiological signals such as Heart Rate Variability (HRV), Galvanic Skin Response (GSR), Respiratory Rate, and Eye Tracking, integrating theoretical foundations with practical, hands-on training. Students will investigate the physiological basis of these signals, learn techniques for data acquisition and analysis, and critically examine their use in clinical and research contexts.

Emphasizing real-world applicability, this course also includes research projects where students design and implement studies to explore health and disease using biosignals. Designed for the new generation of clinical psychologists, health researchers, and professionals, this course bridges the gap between physiological metrics and evidence-based practices for well-being.

Topics to be covered:

Introduction to Psychophysiology and Physiological Measures

Neural Basis of Autonomic Responses

Cardiovascular System and Heart Rate Variability (HRV)

Galvanic Skin Response (GSR) and Electrodermal Activity

Respiratory System and Respiration Measures

Eye Tracking: Basics and Applications

Clinical Applications of Physiological Measures

Designing Psychophysiological Experiments

Ethical and Practical Challenges

Current Trends and Future Directions ( wearable devices, AI integration, personalized medicine, biofeedback)

 

 

 

 

 

Learning Outcomes

By the end of this course, students will be able to:

1. Understand the physiological basis and theoretical foundations of biosignals such as HRV, GSR, respiratory rate, and eye-tracking.

2. Acquire hands-on skills for collecting and analyzing biosignal data using specialized tools and devices.

3. Evaluate the clinical and research applications of biosignals in health and disease contexts.

4. Design and implement research projects that incorporate biosignal analysis to address psychological and physiological questions.

5. Integrate biometrics into modern clinical and health research practices to promote well-being and inform interventions.

6. Critically assess the limitations, ethical concerns, and future potential of biosignal-based technologies in psychology and health sciences.

Grading Rubric

The primary evaluation components consist of  (1) a multiple-choice exam focused on the theoretical discussions primarily covered in the first part of the course, and (2) a group-based research project involving actual data collection including a final presentation of the project.

Rethinking Development and Sustainability [SOA-2243/ ES-2006/ POL-2130] [SOA-2243/ ES-2006/ POL-2130-1]

Faculty Name
Mitul Baruah [mitul.baruah@ashoka.edu.in] ,Anandi Laxmi Somiah [anandi.somiah_ug25@ashoka.edu.in] ,Misha Dutta [misha.dutta_ug25@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course critically examines the processes of “development” and “sustainability,” and the ways in which they interact with each other. The course provides a critical overview of development theories, including classical political economy, modernization theory, dependency theory, postdevelopmentalism, feminist theories of development, sustainable development, and so on. It traces the ideas of development from the 19th century onward, with a particular focus on development thinking in the post-World War II period. At the same time, the course examines certain development projects for a more grounded understanding of how “development” occurs, to whose benefit, and why there is little consensus on what development entails. The course also engages with the multiple ways in which development processes interact with and reshape the environment, thereby affecting the realities of people around the world, and the Global South in particular. To this end, the course specifically focuses on debates and theories around sustainability. It problematizes the idea of sustainability in a world governed by neoliberal development paradigm and faced with both environmental crises and injustices. Upon completing this course, students are expected to learn: 

a. A set of theoretical tools and analytical lenses by which to understand the processes, relationships, and phenomena involved in what we call “development” and “sustainability.”  

b. The distinct implications that different theories of development have for policy, academic work, and social activism and change.

c. The environment-development relations across geographic scales and their planetary and local impacts.

Some of themes will include:

- Theorizing development

- Histories and institutions of development

- The Marxist impasse and the rise of postdependency, and grassroots approaches

- Power, knowledge and development

- Gender, environment and development 

- Sustainable development

- Agriculture and development 

- The gift of Chinese development 

- “Smart city” and India’s developmentalenvironmental challenges     

Learning Outcomes

The learning outcomes of this course include the following:

a. A set of theoretical tools and analytical lenses by which to understand the processes, relationships, and phenomena involved in what we call “development” and “sustainability.”  

b. The distinct implications that different theories of development have for policy, academic work, and social activism and change.

c. The environment-development relations across geographic scales and their planetary and local impacts.

Faculty Name

Overview

Understanding the structure, expression, and dynamics of a genome allows us to correlate structure with function and help to find molecular correlates of different phenotypic characteristics. Recent developments of high throughput technologies have opened an unprecedented level of data for dissecting a genome that has opened up new ways of deciphering genotype-phenotype correlation. We will expose the students to these new ways of understanding genomes and show how the genomic data can be used to understand functional features. Building on the genomics foundation, the next section of this course focuses on functional proteomics. This field explores the protein content and modifications that are crucial for regulating cellular functions. We will begin by examining the fundamentals of protein folds and structural elements that determine protein function. Additionally, we will touch on key software tools used for sequence analysis and protein structure visualization. In the following part, we will explore experimental approaches for proteomics analysis, including various high- throughput techniques.

Learning Outcomes

Basic concepts, methods, and applications in the light of modern biological problems.
Students will learn about the genomes and history of genomic analysis including some of the next generation sequencing (NGS) technology and the evolution of various NGS platforms. They will be exposed to the various “-omics” data and its applications to both model and non-model species.
The proteomics course will introduce the students to the basics of protein chemistry and structures and different methods to analyze the protein components and modifications of the biological samples. This course will also make them familiar with in silico tools to analyze protein structures and functions.
